The almond brittle was a real wow and the crunch was tremendous.  

I had a perfect night with my amazing fiance. I'd love to go back and try their other rotating dishes - maybe a seafood item or even the burger!
author: Jing D.

description:
My boyfriend and I decided to try out The Richmond for a Saturday dinner date, and it did not disappoint.  The ambiance of this restaurant is really small and cozy; I think there were maybe 10 tables max in the entire place.  Our waiter was really nice and attentive, and the chef even came by after to express thanks for stopping by (nice touch of class).  I ordered the cheeseburger and fries, which were delicious.  The hand cut fries were really crispy and savory, and the burger was great, too -- my only flag was that the burger was a bit too big for my liking (1/2 lb), and due to the size, it soaked through the bun as the meal went on, and became a bit difficult to eat.  The taste made up for that small inconvenience, however.

I'd definitely recommend The Richmond as a great date spot -- quiet, great food, cozy.  Just great.
author: Mel G.

description:
I've eaten here twice and both times it has been an amazing experience. The food is fantastic, especially for the price and the chef always adds a few extra dishes to ensure a great eating experience.

I recommend it to all my friends. I will definitely be back again.
author: Sean F.

description:
My Date and I were celebrating our first month anniversary 
so we pick this place 
that was a great choice 
we sat by the window had  a wonderful meal 
Paired w a nice wine.
We had an excellent service
author: A. M.

description:
We were looking for a place with sustainable food that would be delicious, and we found just that at The Richmond. The amuse bouche was a delicious cantaloupe soup. The appetizers were great with the butternut squash soup being the best I have ever had.  The braised short rib was also particularly great. 

The service was wonderful and the atmosphere delightful and cozy. the only reason this place did not get five stars was that the main course was not quite as good as the appetizers. My mother didn't finish the salmon and said it was just not flavorful. 

Still, when we come back to San Francisco this place will definitely be one to remember.
author: Haley R.

description: The Richmond has always held a special place in our hearts, holding many memories of intimate date nights combined with fantastic food and wine. So when we started looking for a venue to host a celebratory dinner following our city hall wedding, The Richmond was a natural choice. We gave John complete liberty to plan the menu based on whatever was fresh and in season and we were not disappointed. Would definitely do it again for the next special occasion!
author: Shalin P.

description: Not only was our food and service excellent, and both food and wine reasonably-priced, but the place is actually quiet enough to have a relaxed conversation with one's dinner companions.
author: Peter B.

description:
Saturday, 8:00PM.
Chef: John, Server: Rudy

Quickie:
+Great service
+Intimate setting
+Variety of menu options
+Clean joint
+Delicious food

And then...?
AWESOME.

**********
More grub deets:

1. Fresh baked rolls
     +Tough to beat warm carbs

2. Crispy skin pan fried chicken with celeriac puree
     +DROOOOL

3. Bacon-wrapped filet mignon
     +The heart attack will be worth it
     +Each bite had a twist of bacon with followed by tender steak
author: Chuck N.

description: i moved to new york 4 years ago and i still think about this place. it was my go-to first date place, and for anyone else i wanted to impress. the most amazing food, greatest service, and the owner/chef comes out to say hello. i miss you guys
author: Michael N.

description: We ate there last night.  If they are not crowded, they try to avoid seating diners at adjacent tables.  The food was imaginative and very good.  We tried the Braised Duck and the Salmon + Shrimp Croquet combination.  Very Nice.  Equally as important, the owner/chef visits the diners, helps with selections, giving very detailed descriptions of how dishes are prepared as well as an explanation of why they are done that way.  He also knows his wines, and will bring as many tastes as you request until you find the one you prefer.  Besides the good food and friendly helpful service, the place is also very conversation-friendly.  The only downside is that it is in an area where parking may be difficult.
author: Carl L.

description:
My friends are I were sorely disappointed by our dining experience at The Richmond last night.  The food was decent, but the service is desperately in need of improvement.  It's understandable that requests cannot always be accommodated (I asked to have the meat left off of a short ribs-scallops combo) and the server said the kitchen wouldn't do it.  That's fine.  But usually there is some sort of apology and/or explanation but neither was offered.  We got the same reaction when my friend asked if they had a black napkin because the white one was leaving a lot of lint on her black pants.  It's ok to not have black napkins but a "sorry" would be nice.  

The food (beet salad, butternut squash soup, crab cakes, salmon, short rib and scallops, chocolate peanut butter torte) was all fine but nothing special.  Wine was pretty good and very reasonably-priced.
author: melita s.

description:
Wow.  This unassuming establishment has no bells and whistles, just some unique art and low lights for a quiet sophistication, a great wait staff, and consistently excellent fare. And, everyone's right about the wine list ... many great bottles for a bargain!  

This place is small and it feels intimate, not cramped.  I've seen eight lavishly-dressed adults seated comfortably not far from a table of four energetic kids and 3 parents, all enjoying themselves with my friend and I just six feet away ... the acoustics are surprisingly accommodating.  

We've eaten here five times and it is a pleasure to be treated to the free, surprise appetizer; good bread with three varieties of butter; thoughtful, palate-awakening first and main courses that are downright generous in proportion considering that one may easily pay double for half that gorgeous amount at more upscale addresses.

I selfishly hope The Richmond will not move to a larger, high-end space with which this dining experience could deservedly pair. I love it that it is truly a "neighborhood gem", rather undiscovered and low-key.  The Richmond is a worthwhile exercise--from the spare decore, to the kitchen, to the billet (tab)--that should please everyone.
author: Vicki O.

description:
John, the owner and chef, is a true MASTER at his craft. You can tell just by speaking with him that his motive/drive for the restaurant is 10% business and 90% passion for delivering memorable fine dining experiences.  Places like this are rare and not to be overlooked in a city with over 3000 restaurants. 

I went with 5 of my friends this past Friday and we were all impressed, full and satisfied after 3 course meal with a couple orders of the seared foie gras. The appetizer- diver scallops with short ribs on polenta was devine. The steak was delicious as well. No complaints. 

 We will all be back for sure so long as the the Chef/ownership doesn't change.
author: John S.

description:
Hmmm...maybe i'm missing something.  The food was 'ok' and not really seeing the 5 stars that other reviewers have noted.  

Maybe it was the service...definitely 5 stars but things i didn't get or like:

* Place is cramped, and not for the claustrophobe...let's just say the bathroom on Southwest airlines was bigger than the unisex bathroom here. 
* You can also listen in on the next tables conversation...especially when bottles of wine are flying
* Food was ok....
   - oxtail with scallop plate with polenta...it was "different" and didn't get the combo..is it seafood or is it meat....meat or seafood or is this surf and turf
   - hangar steak -  maybe its only prepared one way....very rare...if you don't like blood...oozy meat juices....etc. don't get this dish
   -  Dessert - apple turnover...looked like the kind you get from Costco bakery, nuked and served with a scoop of ice cream

Price for 4 with no drinks, 2 appetizers, 4 entrees and 1 costco dessert:  $125 without tip...reasonable but probably won't return any time soon.
author: Cheryl M.

description:
Last minute after Valentine's day dinner with the boyfriend at 5:30pm.  

Complimentary bread with 3 butters (sea salt, olive, herb)-  the herb was the best one.
Amuse Bouche- potato chip with some kind of cream.  I'm always ready to eat =/; Next time, I'll put my fork down, close my mouth, and listen to our server present our dish.
Oxtail with Scallop-  The perfect combination.  It's hard not to put the whole thing in your mouth at a semi fancy restaurant.
Crispy Skin Pan Fried Chicken-  So tender, so crispy!  I'm surprised I didn't see this item on Yelp reviews.  
I wanted the Pork with Meatballs but since it's a seasonal item, I settled for the Burger-  As simple as it looked, the flavors spoke for itself.  The bread was buttered and toasted.  The 1/2 patty was juicy.  The veggies fresh.  And the fries were nicely seasoned.
Warm Chocolate and Peanut Butter Torte- You really can't go wrong with molten cake.  It was chocolatey.  I only had one bite but it sure was delicious.
Coffee Semifreddo-  Coffee ice cream with coffee granite and bits of brittle.  Skip this and get another chocolate cake.

This place is small, service was great, and food was good.  Not to mention, an inexpensive meal.  I'd come back once the pork returns to the menu.
author: Linda N.

description: Food was amazing - the service was not - after being seated and waiting a long time to be approached - after our order was placed we were asked to change tables - we brought our own wine - paid the corkage fee - but the waiter never poured any wine for us - overall a disappointing experience
author: Melissa M.

description: Neighborhood gem. Incredible wine selection. The owner is especially a really sweet guy who isn't afraid to give you a little background on every meal and wine. I wish I could go more often!
author: Roman H.

description: A bit of neighborhood heaven.  My colleague and I were really impressed by the food and the service.  We had a miscommunication which caused me to show up half an hour early, and Chef John noticed I was waiting, came over, introduced himself and poured me a little "waiting" bit of wine.  The food was spot on and amazing. Foie gras to perfection, and the short rib/polenta/scallop dish (which I would never think about putting together) was a bit of tasting heaven.  Service was spot on, and a good balance of caring and non-intrusive.
author: Sheri B.

description:
Even when gas prices are up or the economy is bad, you have to take sometime to spoil yourself was some fine wine and dining. It was an honor to get to eat at this local treasure in San Francisco for my boyfriend's birthday. We both hadn't eaten this fancy in awhile and decided to go all out - this place was never a disappointment.

Brush up on your table manners before you get here so you don't look silly when they change your forks, etc. ;)  It is definitely a complete dining experience - especially if you order their tasting menu. My boyfriend and I opted for the 5 course tasting menu including wine pairing - so worth it! 

To start off as a 'palate cleanser' we were given melon and watermelon. Their bread comes with three choices of butter - sea salt, olive and herb (the herb/green butter was my favorite!). The bread comes out fresh but gets a little hard - but don't feel like you have to fill up because a number of plates are to come...

Next we were given a soup that was a mix of squash and topped with some roasted pumpkin seeds and fresh cream - tiny cup of delicious. 

To start off the tasting menu was the beet and carrot salad topped with a phyllo pastry stuffed with cheese - thought I am NOT a huge fan of beets, this was very pleasant and offered very different flavors at one time. The Chardonnay to pair was light and good even by itself. Their heirloom tomato salad had some of the BEST corn I have ever tasted (which sounds weird but you just had to try it) - Pinot Gris was not my favorite but went well with the dish. 

The Oxtail was really to die for and their polenta was cooked to perfection. It is served with a beautiful Pinot Noir (my FAVORITE wine of the night). By the Oxtail I was almost full already but truly enjoyed the petite Lamb with potato, and I ALWAYS enjoy a good Cab ;) 

By the time dessert came I was already stuffed, but the coffee semifreddo was unlike  anything I have eaten before. It is literally served with some flavored ice but the cream and the almond brittle plus ice cream blend together 

I could go on and on but a couple things I want to hit on:
1. Service is superb and you see the dedication of the owner as he visits your table.
2. The wine pairing is WORTH it. They claim to give 3oz per taste however we were topped off a couple times - it is definitely a culinary experience that you have to experience sometime in your life.
3. Tiny place with so much personality and class. Great for special occassions where you want to treat yourself to something nice! (Kind of a 'save up for date night' kind of place) 

:) Worth the splurge. Foodie senses... SATISFIED.
author: Tracy Joy K.

description: We had a really nice evening at the Richmond.  The food was excellent - standouts for our party were the short rib and scallops appetizer and the salmon entree.  The owner/chef was amazing.  It was my dad's birthday and he was so attentive - really wanted to make sure everyone was enjoying themselves. The complimentary bittersweet chocolate with ice cream was a huge hit with the kids.  This place deserves all the wonderful reviews it gets. :)
author: Debbie W.

description:
Been here a few times and it's always a wonderful meal with attentive, courteous service. We dined here the other evening and decided on the tasting menu - which, by the way, is the best way to go! The tasting menu gives you the most bang for your buck and you enjoy all the kitchen has to offer. 

The oxtail served with scallop was delicious and so was the rib-eye steak served with a potato hash. Every course of the menu was good and the timing of the service was spot-on. 

The Richmond is a great place serving top-notch food that won't break the bank. Good value for the money and I look forward to our next meal there.
author: Grayson E.

description: Loved this restaurant - the owners/chefs were wonderful, the food was delicious, and the atmosphere lovely. I shall definitely return and bring other friends to enjoy!!!!
author: Elena G.

description:
A real gem that you wouldn't expect out of the residential Richmond district. A  very cute and dainty-like place to come for dinner.

I brought my mom and sister here for a celebration and we all had the 5-course menu.  I decided to take it up a notch and got my course menu with wine pairing.  Our waiter was very generous with the wine and all of the dishes were delicious.  The three in-house made butter that came with the bread was pretty awesome.  It was 5 full course menus with pallet cleansers in between two.  The staff was very attentive and gave us an explanation on every course that came out.  

What I actually liked most was that the owner/chef actually came out to greet us and made sure everything was A-okay and perfect.  This is quite admirable because it really shows that the chef cares about his customers.  Soo...WOW!  Great Service.  Great Food.  A real Catch and wonderful experience.

I can't wait to come again!
author: Shirley T.

description:
My date and I left here happy and full.  They had a very intimate/romantic vibe which could be more attributed to it being a weeknight but I'd like to check it out on a weekend too to make sure.  The staff was extremely helpful with questions we had regarding both their food and their wine selection.  

The meal itself was superb. Everything was fresh and perfectly cooked for both of our meals.  Great tastes complimented each returning bite.  Will definitely be back!   

Word of warning: parking can be a pain in this area, so if you're driving, allow an extra 15 minutes.
author: Luke W.

description:
One star for the good food.

ZERO stars for how rude the owner/chef/waiter/does everything guy

I went for a birthday dinner last night and you know with a HUGE group of people (24) Someone is bound to cancel last min. Things happen all the time and they should have acknowledged the fact that 3 out of the 24 couldn't make it. People do have emergencies and NO WHERE on the website it says if no cancellations for the prefix dinners... 

Yeah the birthday girl had to pay for the 3 people that cancelled last min due to a family emergency. No sympathy at all.

SORRY YOU NEED TO PUT THAT ON THE WEBSITE SOME WHERE...    

Oh and there's curtains that separate each room so you can hear it all. The owner/chef/waiter/does everything guy was arguing with someone in the kitchen and then came out and smile and greeted us with a hello and showed us the way to our party. So UNPROFESSIONAL!!

To top it off.. Since they had to pay for the 3 people that didn't show... Don't you think it's reasonable to say they get their meals? That's $55 a head... And that would make it 165 bucks... The owner/chef/waiter/does everything guy told them NO they can't have their meals.. How obnoxious of him to discuss matters infront of our huge party and not take him to the side and talk about it.... Absurd! Again... UNPROFESSIONAL!!!! 

Never again... That little lady in the apron that was dressed just like the owner/chef/waiter/does everything guy was such an instigator and should have kept her opinions to herself...
author: Cel Y.

description:
Simply unbeatable value with the tasting menu! My hubby had the wine pairing too but it was just ok. The food was far better though. Every dish that we had was really good, and at the end of the evening we were completely stuffed. That's what five courses with two amuse bouche will do to ya.

Overall, a great place for a date night.
author: Elaine B.

description:
I came here for my birthday dinner last Saturday. The wait staff was very friendly and attentive. I love how the bread comes with three kinds of butter: parsley chive (my favorite), kalamatta olive, and sweet cream. 

I ordered the halibut with white wine tomato sauce and braising greens. That dish was pretty good, but it did not blow me away. I think the fish was cooked a bit too long but the white wine tomato sauce was delicious. I also tried the seared hangar steak and lamb. The hangar steak was my favorite dish. It was cooked perfectly and  melted in my mouth. It was accompanied by a brie filled "brick dough" crepe, which is a like a crispy philo-dough hot pocket filled with brie and potato. Delish!! The halibut and hangar steak were under $20 and the lamb was ~$24 - very reasonably priced for the quality. We also got crab and cream cheese filled fried wontons as an appetizer compliments of the chef! I tasted real crab meat, not the imitation stuff.

For dessert, we tried the warm chocolate & peanut butter torte (it's like a slice of heaven - takes 15 minutes to prep, but worth the wait!), fresh cream panna cotta, and coffee semifreddo. All three were really good, but the torte was my favorite (it's surprisingly not overwhelmingly sweet or rich).

Between the 7 of us, we paid about $40 each (one entree per person, 2 bottles of wine, and 3 desserts). Not bad! I will definitely be back again to try their tasting menu!
author: Jennifer C.

description:
A great casual romantic spot with affordable prices, good food, and friendly service.

The chef offered a complimentary amuse-bouche of deviled egg.  I love an additional surprise and I love deviled eggs.  Perfect!

The crab cake appetizer was packed full of crab and flavor.  The avocado puree was refreshing.  I only wish there was more than two leaves of arugula, since the dish was named crab and arugula salad.

My steak was very tender and cooked excellently medium rare, although I wished there was more of a brown sear on the meat.  The sauce was a tad bit too salty.  I enjoyed the concept of having a potato and brie hash wrapped in phyllo - however I felt the chunky hash just didn't work.  Maybe if it were a puree instead.

All in all, I had a nice time and tasty meal.  (The prix frixe menu looked really good as well!)
author: Jennifer A.

description: Loved this place. Elegant food from a family with passion to offer the best at very reasonable prices.  Unique in SF's restaurant scene. We will definitely be back!
author: Chris G.

description:
Perfect.  Great service and great food.  A nice bottle of wine and friends made a wonderful evening.
I ordered the duck and it was cooked very nicely.  Meat was tender and the skin was crispy.  It was paired with bean puree and corn and other misc vegetables.  I originally thought the puree would be weird, but eating it with the duck meat was very nice.  Our table shared the panna cotta and coffee semifreddo.  Both were delicious.  The panna cotta was smooth and paired with strawberries while the semifreddo was crunchy goodness with ice cream.
This place is a gem.
author: Karen L.

description:
We were at The Richmond this past weekend for a private event and everything was great.  We were just guests so we didn't have to plan anything but it is a great quaint spot.  I like that it wasn't a huge restaurant as it had a very neighborhood feel to it and everyone was very friendly.  

They were able to fit all of us into the main room and we were greeted by a bartender right when we walked in.  The wine was very good and the meal which consisted of a few options was delicious as well.  I had scallops as an appetizer and steak as the main meal.  The steak could have been cooked a little more otherwise it had great flavor.  My favorite was probably the dessert which was a lemon panna cotta which was a perfect and refreshing end to the meal.  

The Richmond is a little gem hidden that should definitely be tried out.
author: Blake B.

description: You have to expect to spend a long time. But if that's what you're expecting, it's relaxing and really nice. Food is really good, with generous portions. Wine pairing is very well done. Atmosphere is great, with every table sectioned of with curtains. Helps keep the noise level very low as well.
author: Jon M.

description:
Went here on a Saturday night with a large group to celebrate a friend's birthday. Everything I tried was good. The beet salad was especially delicious. For the main course I had a braised duck leg-yummy!

I tried several other things that my friends ordered including the salmon, the hangar steak and the linguine with clams-all very good.

The restaurant is small but it wasn't crowded--I think this has to do with the fact that it's a bit off of the beaten path. Food gets an A. Price was ok. I would say the average cost of the entree was $20. They did have a great sounding tasting menu for 50-60.

For a quiet, delicious dinner I recommend this place.
author: Zoey M.

description: Had the 3 course meal with wine pairing.  All the food was amazing and the wine pours were quite generous.  This is an amazing hidden gem in the city!
author: Casey M.

description: The chef / owner really cares. He came out to say hello, served us each glass of wine and made sure we were comfortable at every point in the meal. The Richmond is a personal spot for a cozy, neighborhood dinner.
author: Dan V.

description: Quite a gem in the Richmond. We had the three course menu and it was a bargain--food was excellent and the owner, John, was very engaging -- staff friendly, and nice, quiet setting. Dinner lasted over 2 hours, and was very relaxing--great night out, will be back.
author: T M.

description: I really want to try this place but every time i go, it's closed. And I live in the neighborhood, so what does that say.. The one time I was able to pop in when it was open, i saw that half of the tables were empty but they refused to seat me because they had reservations coming in for those tables in 1 hour. Meanwhile, I saw other tables on dessert and paying their bill...which would have liberated those tables, but no. And they wouldn't let me sit at their little bar and eat there either. Maybe they should get a hostess. I hear the food is great, though.
author: Louisa W.

description: This place is a GEM! The food is amazing, the service is incredibly personable, and the ambiance is so romantic. We will definitely be going back!!
author: Joan H.

description: I use Yelp consistently to choose restaurants but never review. The Richmond is amazing and I'm letting y'all know. Great experience.
author: C B.

description: Wonderful neighborhood restaurant. Everything was delicious especially the braised duck and salmon. The level of attention and service was superb.
author: Olga B.

description: The five course tasting menu was well presented and every dish was delicious and distinct. And excellent wine pairing.
author: Eve C.

description:
Excellent food with just the right size portions.  The server was knowledgeable and attentive, but the kitchen was SLOW to get the food out.  It is hard to understand that dinner took 2.5 hours on a Tues night when they were only a few other tables occupied.

The Richmond is in a residential area and it is street parking so take a cab or public transit.  We drove around for about 15 minutes at 7:30 PM and almost gave up before finding a place to park.  

We will certainly go back.
author: Steve V.

description: The night we had our dinner service was slow due to the chef was doing double duty as the host. He was gracious and the food was excellent. It's good value for the quality of food. The wine pairing was fantastic. The ambience was good and very intimate, great for date night! If I lived in the neighborhood this would be my go to place for a slightly fancier but still casual dinner.
author: Leanne L.

description:
As I showed up roughly five minutes early before their opening time of 5:30 pm, I was promptly seated anyway. I was later greeted by a very friendly waiter. He was late by about ten minutes and he sincerely apologized. 

I was started off with a ham and cheese puff pastry. It was served cold but the pastry part was still light and flakey. The cheese and ham together proved a bit too salty for my tastes. Next, the bread was served three different kinds of gourmet butters: plain, green chive, and olive flavored. I would recommend the green chive  out of the three. The bread itself was warm and fresh. Next, I received the scallops and braised short rib with polenta. The scallops were seared to perfection and the short ribs would come apart with the slice of a fork. The polenta complimented both meats perfectly. They also had a crab cake served with spinach salad, eggs, and bacon bits. The breading was crispy and the filling was tasty. Although if I had my choice I would go with the scallops any day. Next was the salmon. It was beautifully served with an orange-colored cream sauce with vegetables. The middle was left raw, which by my standards, was preferable. For other people, I'm not so sure. I got to try their braised duck which really caught my attention. It was cooked amazingly and served up with green beans and mashed potatoes. To finish up, I ordered their coffee dessert. It featured a rather strong coffee flavor with caramel brittle bits and whipped cream. But they also served a peanut butter lava cake with a scoop of vanilla ice cream which I actually ended up liking more. 

All in all, a very pleasant and memorable dining experience. Highly recommended for birthdays and dates. Yay!
author: J T.

description: I used to come here a lot, but havent been to The Richmond in a year or so. I found myself asking why did I stop coming here immediately after the chef came to our table and described some of the appetizers and his cooking process. The food here is always amazing. They support local and farmers market produce. I got the pork and it was out of this world. I sampled my friend NY steak and it was also amazing. I love the service and being able to talk to the chef.  I wont wait a year again till I come back. I need to add this to my regular rotation, but its hard in SF with so many great places to eat.
author: jeff d.

description:
This is one of the best restaurants I have eaten at in San Francisco. I mean, every single thing we were served was absolutely amazing. I wish I had taken photos so I could share them with you. 

So, we got a surprise stater of watermelon and melon that was yummy, with some bread and delicious different butters. Then, the waiter came up and apologized for our food taking so long, which I didn't even notice because my water glass was NEVER empty, which I LOVE, and then gave us another yummy free starter. Literally, one of the yummiest starter salads I have ever had, with thick sliced tomatoes lightly marinated in balsamic, with fresh corn and avocado. It was amazing. 

Then more yummy starters (harvest salad and veal sweetbread, the only ONLY thing I slightly didn't like was the richness of the veal, but I mean, it is veal) and then our main dishes, I got the steak and bf got the duck leg. Seriously, so good. And only $25, which for a steak is a really good price. 

So, two starters, two entrees = $70. Which is awesome.
author: Katie F.

description:
I'm so glad places like The Richmond and Namu are gussying up Balboa Street in the Inner Richmond, such that metered parking has become necessary.

I got an impromptu invite to celebrate my getting a job offer (recent college grad), and The Richmond was the only place I have been meaning to try since it opened.  We originally arrived sans reservations at about 8:15PM, and the hostess choked on her words and ran for assistance because I suppose nobody ever has the audacity to show up without reservations.  The place was completely empty, but the server assured us they were booked and people would be arriving soon.  The earliest spot available was 9:00PM.  We put our name down and walked around the neighborhood, passing up several opportunities to eat elsewhere.  After Yelping the place for himself and seeing that I was intent on going to this place, we came back at 9:00PM, seated, and happy as a clam.  

What a phenomenal meal.  We got the beet salad to start.  The vegetables were cooked perfectly and both of us mopped up as much sauce as we could.  The puff pastry was so light and flaky, they really have it down to a science.  The bread was warm and the butters delicious, particularly the olive and chive ones.  They also gave out complimentary crab rangoons to the patrons that night.  The dollop of filling in the center was tiny, but delicious.  I ordered the hanger steak and he the 1/2 pound burger.  Neither of us were asked how we wanted our meat cooked, but luckily our food came prepared with adequate pinkage.  

The hanger steak also came with a crepe, filled with potatoes and cheese.  I'm glad they had some greens with this entree (spinach I think), but this was no light faire.  Neither was my friend's burger, which we both concur, might be one of the best burger deals in town.  A whopping 8oz. of scrumptious burger in a bun with all the fixings, fries, and fancy condiments (Dijon mustard, spicy ketchup, garlic aioli) included for $9.95?!  Why get a burger anywhere else if you're even remotely in the area?!

The servers were very kind and attentive, always keeping our glasses full.  The head chef even came out once or twice to thank the patrons for attending and getting some people their to-go boxes.  Even though this is a "fancy" establishment for the area, any feeling of pretension is primarily brought in by the guests themselves, not so much the people who work there.

We were so full, there was no room for dessert.  Absolutely none whatsoever.  The both of us kept pestering the other to not let our glass of pinot go to waste.  Had we had the foresight to do any type of planning, we would've both stopped halfway, gotten our food to go in Chinese takeout boxes (GASP), and perhaps shared a dessert.  At least there is reason to go back, but with my budget, most likely for lunch.
author: Jenn C.

description: From the moment we entered the door, I knew this would be a special experience. We were warmly greeted and quickly escorted to our table.  This set the pace for a night of incredible food, perfect wine pairings and unparalleled service. The gentleman who served us was exquisitely knowledgeable and passionate about food and wine.  He provided us with details and descriptions of the different dishes and wines to a level of detail I have never experienced before.  Truly, the best service I've ever had.  I started with the crab cake salad, which was unbelievably good, then followed with the duck with mashed potatoes.  The duck was perfectly prepared and literally fell off the bone.  I finished with the apple crisp desert, which tasted so fresh and comforting.  I've never had anything quite like it.  I highly recommend this restaurant for the impeccable service and artfully prepared and delicious food.
author: Aaron C.

description:
Delightful and Delicious
Hope you will discover this charming gem in the Richmond District.
A friend and i had a cozy, quiet, gourmet meal from a very modest proprietor.
Charming atmosphere, excellent food and service.
Don't miss it.
(And the wine list is good and well priced - which gives it many points on my list)
author: Suzanne T.

description: Amazing!  We had the duck and the strange pastry on veggies.  I have been craving this place since.  The server was nice but seemed a bit unsure and hesitant.
author: Chelsea D.

description:
I've never been in the restaurant.. Never tried, from what I've read is amazing food. It's 6:10 on Thursday and we were turned away and told there wouldn't be a table available till 7:30 since we didn't have a reservation. I looked around the restaurant and there were only two tables with customers and about 10 empty tables. I'm not really sure when these supposed reservations were coming to fill the tables to fill the entire restaurant and then finish their meal to be able to provide us with a table at 7:30. Oh and the bar was also taken apparently. I would say it's bad practice to have your entire restaurant filled with reservations which doesn't allow for walk ins.

Ehh maybe we will try again in a few months..
author: Olive K.

description:
The food here was GOOD. Delicious! I especially like the beef carpacio and the foie gras.  BUT:
1) the ambiance here is so weird.  I suppose it's the Richmond, but what's with all the old people. In such a small space, everyone is listening in on your conversation.  And with my gutter-mouth, EVERYONE was listening in on my conversation.  
2) They seemed to be out of everything when I went.  The conversation for like 5 different items was like-- 
me: "I will have an anchor steam"
waiter: "we ran out"
me: "I will have a big daddy"
waiter: "we ran out"
me: "what do you have?"
waiter: "trumer"
me: (vomit)
3) chinese take-out boxes.. W-T-F

HOWEVER--- given that they have $3 beers--- i am willing to overlook  everything...
author: Ivy S.

description: Great food and ambiance.  This tiny place serves amazing food!  It's a great place to come with a small group, or on a date.  The place is really small but if you request ahead of time they can accommodate a large party of 10 (maybe).  The customer service is great, the servers are very friendly and helpful.  The coffee semifreddo is my favorite!
author: Cece L.

description:
These days in the dynamic SF food scene where everyone is trying to produce the next food trend, a classic menu may induce a slew of yawns and frankly, suspicion. Are you too lazy to innovate? Not creative enough to keep up?

This is why when I saw the Richmond's menu which consist of a small list of classic dishes like burger and fries, steak or salmon, I was highly suspect of the rave reviews on yelp. Not to mention, the name "the Richmond," is so nondescript that it makes you wonder if the restaurant had any imaginations at all. But this place turns out to be a very pleasant surprise, because it does the classic dishes so well.

As we have learned form Yelp, they provide 3 types of butter for the bread. I liked the olive and chive ones, but honestly the traditional one with sea salt was my favorite. It just tasted more, buttery. 

My friend loved her foie gras and our crab cakes were good. It's interesting that the cakes were perched on top of what tasted like a thin layer of clam chowder. The tangy greens on top added a nice layer of acidity to the dish.  The restaurant was kind enough to split the dish into two plates of crab cakes that are easier for sharing. 

I ordered sea bass as my entree and it looks like a hefty half-pounder. The fish was moist and the snow peas and carrots underneath were tasty.  I especially liked the green and yellow purees that had a nice subtle flavor that went well with the delicate fish.

Even though we were full, we shared the chocolate cake and pan perdu for dessert. Can't go wrong with chocolate cake and buttery toast! Again, very classic but well done.

It's not a cheap place and the ambiance isn't trendy or loud. It's quiet enough to bring your parents but also cute enough for a date.
author: Candice B.

description: I love this hidden gem and the 5 star review is long over due. The quality of the  food and the price point can't be beat. Have had a number of awesome meals here and John always  goes out of his way to help deliver a memorable experience.
author: Vince S.

description: Here's what's important: the food is amazing. One way to describe it would be "A high end restaurant that isn't presumptuous about what they do".
author: Plinio C.

description: I saddens me to give this place a 3 because I used to love going here.  However the last visit wasn't memorable at all, I frankly can't even remember most of the things we ordered.  With all of the new restaurants coming up in SF, the Richmond definitely need to step up their game!  Lack luster food, coupled with the horrendous lack of parking in that area, sadly I don't think I'll be back any time soon.
author: Christina L.

description:
I was excited to try out this place based on reviews I saw on Yelp. 

Good:

- Very attentive service
- Great seating for my wife in me in a little alcove, which was nice
- Appetizer (foie gras on pain perdue) was great

Meh:

- Main entree (bacon-wrapped steak) was chewy and bland
- Dessert (peanut-butter filled molten cake) was good, but nothing special


If I were to go back, I'd try the seafood or chicken dishes. Rookie mistake to order steak at a non steakhouse.
author: Amar R.

description: I went with a group of my friends last night and had a great time.  The first sign of how personalized the service was that I made a change to our reservation from 4 to 6 people an hour before we were scheduled to start dinner.  We were accommodated promptly and without any attitude.  Each table is surrounded by curtains, so you can't really see the other diners.  They waited for the majority of our party to show up before taking our orders and we never felt rushed.  John came out and gave us samples of wine and let us decide which bottle(s) we wanted to have to accompany our meal.  One of my friends has a long list of food allergies that John was very gracious about.  He brainstormed for a few minutes and made the appropriate changes - she was able to select from 2 appetizers or 3 entrees that would be modified.  All of the appetizers were delicious, and I was able to choose the foie gras, a tasting menu item, to be served a la carte.  Our group had pork, beef and duck - all delicious and juicy.  Portion sizes were generous.  We left very full.  Our wallets also left very full as the per person price was very reasonable!  Overall, outstanding service and food.  Ambiance feels like you're at home in your own dining room.  We will be back!
author: Mary V.

description: Perfect meal, warm hospitality, and a dedicated staff. I highly recommend it, especially since it's the only kind of restaurant like this in the area.
author: Noah D.

description:
Ya know, when we realized that we seemed to read about the closures of great, imaginative restaurants that we always intended, but never really did get around to visiting, we decided to take some responsibility.

Vowing to start actually patronizing these brave business stalwarts, we gathered a small group, made reservations, drove in circles for a very long time, then found our seats at this lovely restaurant. 

( parking was very bad, not their fault, but if you don't plan for it to be about as bad as SF can get, and you find yourself pushing up against th reservation time, you'd better be able to drop someone at the door, and let them pass plates out to the driver as they circle the restauranct in ever widening arcs.)

We eventually found a spot and hiked  thru  and then to The Richmond.

We had enough people so we were able to sample just about everything, passing plates, and exclaiming as we went.

We felt welcomed, cared about and cared for. Our group included some pretty creatIve  cooks and  knowledgeable foodies. All were impressed, and we had a lovely evening, with the food, friendship  and service perfectly balanced.

We'll come again. You should go too.
author: Skeeter S.

description:
Great place! Found it on Yelp after finding a few places closed on Mondays. We didn't have reservations and we were dressed VERY casual. We were seated in a sweet little room with simple, yet classy character.

EVERYTHING we ate was delicious. The crab cake and salad was so fresh and full of well seasoned crab meat. The squash soup was hot and tasty. Subtle and not overpowering. I had the salmon and it was wonderful. Very nice presentation and generous sides. My husband had the pan fried chicken and it was some of the best fried chicken I have ever had at a restaurant. Definitely in the top 3! The chicken was moist and flavorful. The potatoes were creamy and cheesy. And the veggies were flavorful and really pretty on the plate.

Great date place! We are going back.
author: Sarai C.

description:
Five of us had dinner at The Richmond:  great meals and a great time were had by all.  All of our appetizers and all of our dishes were put together perfectly - spices, flavors, presentation all good.  A particular hit was the crab cake with potato leak puree, and the crispy fried chicken layered on a Swedish meatball.  (Sounds a bit odd, but the flavors blended so well.)  

The restaurant itself is small, cozy, and comfortable, and the waitstaff is pleasant and knowledgeable, and just the right level of attentive without being intrusive.  For parties of 4 or smaller, they have a few tables by the windows that are surrounded by a curtain, so each one is essentially private.
author: Phil K.

description: A very cute place with amazing food!! their tasting menu is very generous and everything tastes amazing
author: Rozita N.

description:
Went there last night and had a  very every average meal.  Crispy fried chicken was not very crispy. The food was a bit late what your mother could make, if your mother was only an average cook.

Service was good and price was not out of line, but there are many other restaurants where you can get a better meal.
author: Paul W.

description:
The quality and sheer tastiness of the food gets a full five stars.  As the closest "nice" restaurant to my house, I've had several occasions to bring visitors here.  It's always good and they're always glad we went.  The service is also attentive without being overbearing.  Considering how small an area they have to work with, there is a surprising amount of privacy - some smart interior decorators put a lot of thought into the layout.  

The only drawbacks I can see: not a full bar (I can't drink wine, so it's always water for me here); the menu is limited so I've now had everything on it and sometimes twice; and it's so popular reservations are a must (probably not a drawback for the restaurant, but don't get discouraged if you have to make a few attempts).
author: Steve S.

description:
If you live in the neighborhood and are looking for a romantic date restaurant, you should absolutely try The Richmond.   I will start by saying that my boyfriend and I had a great time during our visit to the restaurant this weekend - the ambiance is quaint and interesting, the wine, recommended to us by our waiter, was reasonably priced and uniquely delicious.  The Richmond does a wonderful job of making you feel welcomed and provides special touches, such as providing a complimentary amuse-bouche before dinner, serving an entire mini-loaf of fresh bread with three kinds of butter and delivering tiny, tasty cookies to the table in an adorable little container at the end of the meal.

I ordered the Whisky Braised Oxtail with a Maine Diver Scallop and the Seared Sonoma Foie Gras.   Both were very yummy and the flavors were there, but the oxtail was slightly overly chewy.   My boyfriend ordered the House Ground Half-Pound Cheeseburger & Hand Cut French Fries which he did not enjoy and described as generally not tasty - more of a blob of flavorless meat on a bun.  We had also in the past had bad experiences with the restaurant's Hanger Steak - which was not cooked consistently, chewy and served with a  weird cheese pastry thing that just didn't add much deliciousness to the plate.

I actually feel terrible writing these bad things about the food but I hope that the chef/owner reads these and sees the trend on certain dishes.  On the Whisky Braised Oxtail with a Maine Diver Scallop - delicious, keep this one but make sure the meat portion of the dish is always tender.   The Seared Sonoma Foie Gras - nailed it.   The burger:  start over to produce a good burger and get better fries.  The hanger Steak:  create a new dish (ditch the pastry thing and make sure the meat not too chewy and is consistently cooked).  

Because I actually do want to come back.....
author: Holly L.

description:
Random little date spot which I feel Yelp did not adequately prepare us for. It is listed as a wine bar but markets itself as a restaurant. I guess I'd say the size of the restaurant is wine bar...and a very cozy restaurant....maybe 10 tables in the whole place? Also...I'm pretty sure Yelpers have rated this place as "casual dress" but upon arriving, we realized we were sadly underdressed. Despite this faux pas, the hostess and our server treated us extraordinarily well.

To begin, we thoroughly enjoyed the trio of butters but it cried out desperately for better bread to be served with it. We both had local beers because we weren't in the mood for wine. This was followed by super tasty deviled eggs....love getting free stuff at the beginning of a meal! 

Hubby had the fried chicken and although flavorful, was upset to find that it was predominantly white meat.  I had the Hangar Steak which was very tender for about half of my portion, the other part was chewy. Mashed potatoes were delicious. 

Too full for dessert.
author: Lauren G.

description:
I would always pass The Richmond while riding the 31 on my way to work and marvel at the sparkly wine glasses set up and wonder about this dining joint, after all, it's in the Inner Richmond!

Two years later, I finally had the opportunity to try this place out when I took my roommate there for his birthday.  Why did I not go sooner?!

The Food:
I had the Seared Hanger Steak on a pancetta, onion, potato & brie filled 'brick dough' crepe -- Large and thick proportion!  Cooked medium rare.  No complaints here.

The roommate had the Crispy Skin Pan Fried Chicken with scallop potatoes -- I'm not usually a fan of chicken, but the flavors and the amount of moisture and tenderness of the chicken was spot on! 

We also had a bottle of Cab from Ramsay wines, and for under 20 bucks, we didn't go wrong!

The Atmosphere:
Filled with big velvety curtains, the atmosphere was intimate and very cozy.  An awesome date spot.  NO, I was not on a date with my roommate! 

The Service:
No complaints.

Overall, The Richmond is a non-pretentious finer dining gem in the heart of the Inner Richmond.  It earns my seal of approval!
author: Matt S.

description:
I haven't been here in awhile.  This restaurant works with what it has.  The interior is a little weird; it looks like someone turned their house into a restaurant.  It's cozy.

I loved the three types of butter and made the noob mistake of eating a lot of bread.  I could eat a lot more back then, though, so no problem, full steam ahead.  

The foie gras was decent and the price was right.  The steak could've been better...in taste and presentation.
author: Erika C.

description:
came here on NYE with my boyfriend because he was treating me to our 1 year anniversary dinner :)

but we were definitely the youngest ones there. we're in our early 20s and everybody here looked as if they were in their late 30s. sheesh.

on top of that we were way overdressed. i was dressed for NYE, all blinged out and sparkly and these rich old people that were sitting around us were just in business casual, santana row, yuppie, expensive but casual clothing. meh its okay i guess.. we're young.

so to start us off the nicely dressed and professional waiters came by with some wine for the bf (because he ordered it) (some pinot noir) and some amuse bouche.

OH. MY. GOSH. THE CUP THAT THE CIDER WAS SERVED IN WAS INCREDIBLY CUTE!!! the amuse bouche was a little cute cup of warm cider with cream and something else and a loaf of french bread slices with different spreads. yum yum yum yum yummm omggg my bf and i took advantage of these and scarfed them down because at nice restaurants like these, serving sizes will be smaller.. especially if its french style.. and you know what the french say about food: its about getting full off the essence and not the food itself.

for the appetizer we ordered the foie gras. i had for the longest time wondered what foie gras tasted like since learning about it a couple years ago. the idea of eating liver was so repulsive but the way people described it, like how it was like butter, made me so curious and interested in what it might taste like. and its a french delicacy! french people dont eat weird things. so we gave it a try...

and man it really was like butter! its was deliciously smooth. the sauce was so good! the bread underneath it was delicious too! but alas, the power of the mind is quite powerful indeed and i started realizing i was eating duck liver and started feeling sick and i couldnt eat anymore and let my boyfriend have the rest. sigh if only i didnt get grossed out  by things like this so easily...

he ordered the cheeseburger because zagat reviews said it was a really good cheeseburger and my bf is an american kind of guy so that dish was perfect for him. as for me, i only eat chicken pork or beef and out of the only three chicken/pork/beef dishes that were there i thought the red wine braised short ribs sounded delicious.

bf said the hamburger was good! he said he would totally come back just to get this burger with the (free) amuse bouche that comes with it haha. they gave him fancy ketchup and mustard too. the ketchup which i tried with his fries was REALLY interesting! i couldnt get enough of the taste.

the ribs were SO tender and SO delicious. it was a bit fatty too.. which tasted DELICIOUS with the sauce. the potato puree was just mashed potatoes which was good with the meat, and the veggies.. well i only ate the french green beans. there were these beans that looked like the french green beans but white and the white translucent color kind of freaked me out so i stayed away from it.

over all the night was delicious. i really wish we could have tried the dessert menu but my bf and i were too full. its crazy that we came out of that restaurant full because i expected to still be hungry afterwards. i shall come back when their menu changes again to try some more different kinds of cuisine!
author: Rebecca K.

description: We came for a bday dinner here for table of 9 and they were very accommodating.  The chef was very nice and had introduced himself. The service we received was super. Our group opted to have the tasting menu with the wine pairing. We were given a few palate cleansers and soup as well. The brioche and butternut soup was our favorites of these small plates. The wine pairing complimented the food very well. The beet salad was refreshing and the crab salad was marvelous. The entrees were duck and short ribs. Both tasted great and the dessert was coffee ice cream. Overall we had a wonderful experience for our first time dining here. We will definitely recommend this restaurant to our friends.
author: Jennie W.

description:
Excellent restaurant.  The food, the service...everything was amazing.  

When you come here, forget about your diet and just try out whatever your heart desires and never forget to order dessert. 

This place is awesome. I am bringing my husband here for his b-day. He will love it. 

Btw, the Salmon was delicious! I loved the mushroom sauce.  YUMMY!!
author: Liza B.

description: The food and service here deserve five stars.  The lack of parking is the only down side.  We had the five course tasting menu with wine pairings.  It was very good and at a moderate price.  The portions of food and wine are generous.  The duck, in particular, was very good.  The menu sternly warns about no substitutions on the tastings menu.  However, the friendly chef who took our order and checked in on every course was very flexible for our group.  I would definitely come here again.
author: Jeffrey L.

description:
What a surprise. A hidden secret, really. Though it's not really hidden. I feel like more people should know about this place but at the same time I like how personal it feels dining here without the bustle of annoying yuppies acting like they own the city.

The laid-back chef hangs out with the diners before dinner and a cute deviled egg amuse bouche to start inspires me to pipe my own to impress guests at the next dinner party. Mint parsley and kalamata olive spreads with our bread was a great substitute for ordinary butter. Foie gras and oxtail appetizers were small but substantial in their own way. Fresh and thoughtfully prepared was the salmon with lentils and eggplant salsa. My wild mushroom puff pastry made me forget I was a beef biting, pork inhaling, chicken gobbling, carnivore. A dish so hearty it made me not miss the meat. A successful dish for any chef.  To further indulge ourselves, we ended with an apple turnover and a warm chocolate peanut torte with homemade ice cream. 

All plates clean. All bellies full. That's wassup.
author: Jen Y.

description:
I have had two wonderful experiences here.

I came to do the sampler with my gf and everything was amazing.

The meat falls of the bones

The wine pairing is very good and affordable.

Then I came back for a steak.

The steak was well worth it because it was delicious.

The ambiance is very quiet for the most part 

John has the best kept secret in our neighborhood :)
author: Daniel Y.

description:
We came to celebrate my husband's birthday on a Saturday night during the World Series. We were originally seated at a small window table, but we ended up moving to the bar to watch the rest of the game. The staff did not hesitate to accommodate us.

John was the most welcoming and generous host. He comped an appetizer because I couldnt decide between two of them, and he refilled my husband's beer multiple times free of charge.

We started with the beet salad, crab cake, and corn pudding. For mains, we had a salmon and the burger, and for dessert, we had a chocolate torte. 

We enjoyed all of our dishes and the very generous serving sizes, but John's graciousness is what made our evening memorable. We will certainly return and recommend this place to family and friends.
author: Amanda M. C.

description:
nice and cozy atmosphere, better to show up around 8pm after sunset for dinner.

fois gras was excellent.
short rib appetizer was quite good with mashed potato but scallop was superfluous for the dish. 
beef carpaccio -- should be thinner and the heavy sauce almost killed the dish. 
warm chocolate tart was too sweet for my taste - much prefer moelleux au chocolat from France. 

wine by the glass: not a great selection, and the red wine should be kept in cellar temperature rather than room temperature (which is quite warm for a warm san franciscan day).
author: Rebecca C.

description:
We came yesterday  to celebrate our one year wedding anniversary. We wanted fine, sophisticated excellent food, at reasonable prices, just because we've been spending a lot for the holidays. 

The service is excellent. I made the reservations on Open Table about a week and a half ago, and John called me the afternoon of to confirm our reservation and to ensure we were coming.  It could be because the restaurant is small, so they wanted to make sure we showed up and used the table, but I appreciated that he called. And he also congratulated us three times while I spoke with him on the phone.  We were seated immediately when we got there. 

We started off with 2 glasses of sparkling wine. While waiting for the appetizers we got to sample the amuse bouche of potato leek soup (so good and creamy!) and the warm French bread with 3 flavored spreads. We got  2 appetizers: the whisky braised oxtail with Maine diver scallop and the Seared Artisan Foie Gras with pain perdu and pear sauce. As reported by the fellow yelpers, these 2 appetizers are divine! The foie gras pairs wonderful with the pain perdu (it's almost a bread putting/french bread texture) - a great pairing of sweet and savory. The creamy polenta was heavenly, and really went together well with the was melt- in-your-mouth scallops. Those dishes only could have been my meal (the replenish the french bread when you are running low, and the appetizers are good portion size).

Our entrees: Seared Hanger Steak on a crispy "brick dough" crepe filled with pancetta, potato, onion fennel & Brie, and the wild pacific sea bass with veggies (sorry I forgot to take notes on the sea bass). On reading that some yelpers who ordered medium well, and got their steak TOO well, we got it medium rare. It was perfect. Order it medium rare. The texture and flavors are perfect. The sea bass was delicious, with a great butter wine sauce.

We ordered the Coffee Semifreddo with coffee ice cream, coffee granita & almond brittle. And they brought it out with a thoughtful little candle they gave us to celebrate our anniversary. We both made a wish before blowing it out. I had ordered a coffee and they had forgotten to bring it to me before handing us the check, so they took it back and took the coffee off the bill. 

John came over to each table to thank the customers for coming out and supporting their restaurants. He also congratulated us on our anniversary. I appreciated the time and effort he took to thank each of our tables. And we got the dessert for free too!

The Richmond is a great gem in the neighborhood. It has delicious well executed meals at reasonable prices, and a friendly and welcoming staff. We will definitely return for some fine dining and to celebrate life's other special moments.
author: Annie Y.

description:
Went there last night for the tasting menu and wine pairing. Very impressed. The Tasting Menu was delicious from beginning to end. Warm cider, butternut squash soup, beet salad, crab cake, scallop and short, rib, duck breast, coffee semifreddo dessert. The only 5-star dish was the scallop and short rib, which was heavenly. But everything was very well cooked and seasoned and deserving of at least 4 stars. I'm not a fan of butternut squash or beets, but the beet salad was delicious and I could recognize that the squash soup was well-prepared even if i wasn't diving in to it. The service was impeccable. Our waiter was very professional and knowledgeable about the foods and wine we were served.

I highly recommend the Richmond. If I could give it 4.5 stars I would.
author: Dan R.

description:
An undiscovered gem, The Richmond shines brightly on Balboa Street.

In an otherwise undistinguished space in the Inner Richmond, the eponymous restaurant belies its shabby exterior, offering a small selection of reasonably priced dishes with sophistication rarely seen in this part of The City.  Upon entering, the down-at-the-heels former store front gives way to a minuscule bar and immerses patrons in a cozy dining room with several tiny curtained alcoves that encourage romantic dining.

While the number of selections is limited, the menu reminds guests that it is not quantity, but quality, that counts.  At The Richmond, the beautiful presentation is overshadowed only by the explosion of flavors in every bite of every dish.

An amuse bouche of fried won ton stuffed with creme fraiche and crab was the perfect way to start a dining experience.  While the slices were slightly too thick, the beef carpaccio with aioli, asparagus, and fried capers was tender and delicious.  Accompanied by Laura Chenel goat cheese wrapped in phyllo, the roasted red and yellow beets were sweet and tender.  The roasted squash and celery root soup featured slight anise overtones that served as the perfect foil for the creamy sweetness of the base, prompting a guest to ask, "Is it wrong to want to pick up the bowl and lick it?"  With a tomato and white wine sauce, the sea bass with snap peas and carrots was flavorful and rich.

The friendly and attentive service showed superior attention to detail:  shared dishes were split in the kitchen and the pacing of courses was relaxed, but not slow.  At the end of the meal, the chef visited the table to ensure that everything was satisfactory.  

The wine list offers a myriad of reasonably priced "everyday" selections as well as the requisite bottles of California cult Cabernets.  With many establishments wringing every penny out of diners' wallets by jacking up margins in their beverage programs, it is nice to see a little restraint from The Richmond.

Offering a sophisticated dining experience that in other parts of The City would warrant prices close to twice as great, The Richmond is indeed a neighborhood gem.
author: CJ G.

description:
I can't believe it took us so long to try this place! 

Everything we ate....from beginning to end....was delectable. The two appetizers we had - scallops with oxtail and polenta and the foie gras - were out of this world (though I probably could've lived without my boyfriend repeating 'Jen, they gave us the entire liver. Look at that. Wow. It's like the whole liver'. In certain situations it's nice to forget what you're eating ;) ). 

The salmon with ratatouille was great but I LOVED my boyfriend's cod with chowder. We ended the night with the chocolate peanut butter cake. Perfect (though every dessert would have been up our alley). 

Equally as good as our food was our server, John. His knowledge of wine alone was impressive (we brought our own bottle and he instantly knew what it was and what it would pair best with, etc.). He was extremely personable and it was fun chit-chatting with him here and there throughout the night. Another sweet gesture was when the chef came out and visited our table. 

All in all, it was a fantastic evening enhanced by everything this restaurant has to offer. We both can't wait to go back!!!
author: Jen N.

description:
Can't believe I've never heard of this place before now. There's so much good food in the Richmond neighborhood, and The Richmond is right up there with the best of them. It's a really quiet place, and the service was pretty good (our waiter bumbled a little but he knew the menu very well). 

The food was for the most part excellent. I had the short ribs, which were tender and delicious. The crab cake appetizer was OK, a little heavy on the breading. The fish stew (heads up, it's not really a stew as much as a cod filet served on top of a clam chowder sauce) was really great, the fish was cooked perfectly. Even the beet salad was great. All in all, there was nothing that my group got that I wouldn't order again.

For a nice restaurant, the prices are also reasonable (entrees were all around $20). Definitely worth going to if you've never been, and if you have, it's worth going back another couple of times. Oh, but parking can be tricky.
author: Louis D.

description:
Came here for my last foie gras meal in California with my bf and another couple and it was very satisfying. The meal started with warm bread and a plate of parsley chive butter, kalamatta olive butter, and sweet cream butter; I loved the pastel green and purple of the first two butters, but taste wise none of us were a fan of the olive butter. Since we had a huge BBQ lunch, we ordered 4 appetizers and 1 entree to share and I wouldn't have had it any other way- the appetizers were the stars of the meal! 

The main appetizer was the Seared Artisan Foie Gras with a Foie and Chicken Mousseline Raviolo and Black Truffle Sauce! That was soooo rich and flavorful! We also had Whisky Oxtail with Maine diver scallops and crispy crabcakes! Our main dish was Pork Tenderloin  & Swedish Meatball Roti which was the most intense meat dish which reminded me of Epic Meal Time.

I would definitely come again for the appetizers, especially the foie gras; too bad California banned it :(
author: Cindy L.

description:
What a great restaurant!! Loved the setup of the place with the tables being kind of intimate. Very Romantic!

The food was delicious and tasty. We ordered the Crab cakes, the seared Sonoma Foie Gras, the wild pacific Salmon and the bone-in Pork chop. 

The waiters were very friendly and always taking care of us. On top of things!

Oh and I also loved the fact that the Chef went to check on us, that's how you can tell they actually care about the place!
author: Angelica V.

description: Perfect food and exceptional chef! We were treated with amazing hospitality and respect by the owner himself. Highly recommend!
author: Nadia H.

description:
I really think the chef at The Richmond tries hard, but he only succeeds some of the time. I'm not sure whether I'd go back.

Here are the details:

- Heirloom tomato salad with corn/avocado salsa ($11) was good, but the sweet sauce it was served with was too sweet for my taste.

- Pork Tenderloin & Swedish Meatball Roti with Potato Puree ($19) was flavorful, but I thought the meatball might have been slightly undercooked. Very good flavors though. 

- Wild Pacific Salmon with ratatouille & tomato cream sauce ($20) was perfectly cooked and quite delicious. 

- Fresh Cream Panna Cotta topped with lemon curd & streusel ($6) - OK panna cotta is one of my obsessions and it's also a great test of a chef. So I have to go into a bit of detail here:

A good panna cotta should hold it's form on the plate, but when you put it in the spoon it should start to collapse, and when it's in your mouth it should turn into thick cream: there should be no trace of rubberiness or, god forbid, chewiness. This means that the chef has to measure his gelatin perfectly -- too little and the panna cotta will not stand up -- too much and it will become rubbery. 

When I saw that this panna cotta was served in a glass I thought two things: 

1) Aha, he's cheating! No need to put in a lot of gelatin because it doesn't have to stand up on a plate. 

2) At least it will be really creamy, since he doesn't need put in a lot of gelatin to make it stand up on a plate.

Unfortunately, it still had too much gelatin and was rubbery rather than creamy. Why? I can't understand why?!

- Coffee Semifreddo ($6): OK again, what is a semifreddo? It's not ice cream, it's thicker and has a different texture, like a frozen mousse. In Italy, it's generally served as a slice about 1/2" thick on a plate. It doesn't melt quickly because it has less water content. 

This dessert is just ice cream. It's good ice cream, but why call it a 'semifreddo' if you're not going to actually make a semifreddo? 

To sum things up, I think the prices are very reasonable, the attempt is being made to produce high quality food, but it fell short too often for me to give more than 3 stars. Perhaps it's unfair because if my expectations hadn't been raised so high, I'd probably give 4 stars. It's better to underpromise and overdeliver than the reverse. 

The quality of the ingredients was impeccable, however, and it is a great value nonetheless. 

Maybe I'll be back...
author: Jacob L.

description: I'm torn between giving them 2 stars because the food was good and giving them 1 because of the terrible service. The food really was good. And reasonably priced for what we had. However, the service was HORRENDOUS. We waited nearly 45 minutes for them to clear our finished entree plates and bring our desserts. Our bill came to $56 per person with a 20$ tip. I paid on my card and my friend put down $60 cash - 3 $20s. The server came over and told us they didn't have change and that they would have to owe her the money (wait, what? how is that even possible?) We told her we only needed $4 change and the rest would be tip. The server responded that it was too busy to go get change and told us to figure it out on our own. After waiting another 15 minutes thinking she'd come back she never did and we decided our time was more important than the $4 - we had been there for almost 3 hours at this point. Sure, they were busy and it was quite easy to hear someone in the kitchen yelling at the staff nearly the entire time so I can understand why she was stressed. But forcing us to pay over 25% for a tip on bad service is outrageous. With so many good restaurants in this city, why waste time on one like this.
author: kelly G.

description:
Good food in an intimate, quiet setting that is well-priced.

We were definitely under-dressed, but the service was great and they didn't seem to notice (we were treated very kindly by everyone).

I ordered:
Crab cakes: 4 stars - tasty, sizeable portion.
Seared Salmon: 4 stars - a bit on the salty side (as other yelpers have noted) but I like salt - so I enjoyed it. The fish was cooked pretty well (although it said "seared") and the mushroom sauce was oh so tasty.

My one ding would be that the amuse bouche (this broth-like carrot / mango / lime concoction) was a not-so-good attempt at making something wholly unclassy (the carrot) seem taste-bud-tempting. Not a fan.

But all in - I would likely return (and perhaps order exactly the same order). I wouldn't necessarily recommend this place to my foodie friends, however if I had some family or friends from out of town visiting, and wanted a quiet place to talk and eat heartily, I would definitely consider The Richmond.
author: Helen D.

description: The chef personally took our order. Great little neighborhood spot with meticulously well prepared food.
author: Brett G.

description:
We chose the Richmond for a special graduation day private lunch. John Owyang, the owner, was very accommodating and made the experience work for us. We collaborated on the menu, three courses, and the pricing. John was very professional throughout and exuded a caring, hospitable attitude. He guaranteed an "artisan" presentation and delivered.

The menu included a tasty salad, a choice of entree (meatloaf or a bacon-salmon open faced sandwich), and choice of dessert (panicotta or a coffee semifreddo). Everything looked nice and filled our guests. The flavors were rich and portions about the right size. 

We filled the place with around 26 people. The prices were reasonable. The only issue was parking, but it worked out alright. Recommended!
author: Peter M.

description:
One word...AMAZE. 'Nuff said. 

No seriously though, this restaurant is an undiscovered gem.  This is a perfect date spot, which is how I recently discovered it. Quaint, intimate, great wine selection, delicious food, and wonderful service. Have a glass of wine at the small bar before you sit down for dinner, talk up the bar tender and he will not do you wrong.
 
My date and I shared the braised short rib and scallop appetizer. Yes, the best of both worlds here people...slow braised beef short rib with an amazing sauce, topped with perfectly sautéed, sweet scallops. What more could you ask for, except for a perfectly paired glass of wine. Which we had. The rest of the meal was just as fabulous, but you should go try it for yourself. Yes, it's "all the way out in the Richmond" as people say but it's worth the what, 10 minute drive at best? Go for it, you will not regret it!
author: Brenna S.

description: I absolutely love this place. It is romantic and intimate and a perfect date spot. My husband and I like to come here because the service is deliberately slow, allowing us to spend a relaxing dinner together. We like to get the carrot and beet salad, the scallop and short rib dish, and the duck leg. Everything else we've tried is also delicious. Come here with your date, order a bottle of wine, and enjoy!
author: Karen B.

description:
3.75 to be TOTALLY honest (-0.25 because the service was really slow although extremely nice).  It's a total neighborhood gem, very cozy, family-run feel with a love for good food.


+Piping hot, fresh table bread served with 3 kinds of butter (chive was my favorite, then sweet cream, olive was tasty but not my love)
+Fried chicken and mac n' cheese: crispy, juicy boneless chicken over mac n' cheese
-the gravy that was meant for the chicken (unnecessary) got onto my mac n' cheese because the plate was served as a "stack"
+Amuse bouche (i love when restos do this)
-for not checking if everyone at the table eats meat before serving said amuse bouche
+Crispy arctic char
-for having the same veggie accompaniments as my fried chicken
+for having an EXTENSIVE and AFFORDABLE wine list :)

i think i had ice cream for dessert...but nothing dynamite.
author: Priscilla T.

description:
So, I have never been to a restaurant that had $15 bottles of wine.  And not just one or two, but one or two of every varietal.  Oh, and some very nice $30 - $60, and of course several more than $200.  And there is more to The Richmond than just the wine list.

We come in, are immediately greeted with a smile.  Shown to our table.  It is already set for two.  In a private alcove separated from the rest of the restaurant by a curtain.  Very private and intimate.

And the service, that perfect balance of immediate attention and yet not intrusive.  We were attended to by three people who just worked flawlessly as a team. 

Food: Good, not phenomenal, but nobody is going to be disappointed.  Beet and carrot salad was good.  Sloppy Joes quite good, and the bread didn't get soggy.  They must have used a stick of butter for the puff pastry filled with mushrooms.  The soup was quite good, very filling.  And, when they found out that I wasn't eating meat, but didn't like mushrooms, they made me a very good vegetable crepe.  Oh, and the cinnamon ice cream, wow!

Ambiance: Much quieter than most with quiet music in the background: Steely Dan, Keb Mo, ....

More than anything, The Richmond stands out because of their attention to details: Table already set, coffee was brought in a pot that was left at the table, special vegetarian crepe prepared, chef visited the table.

Total with a $37 bottle of wine and tip: $126 for two.

I would definitely recommend, not overly romantic but appropriate.  Would also be fine for a work dinner.  But, not a huge menu selection, and so you might want to make sure that you can find something.
author: Kurt G.

description:
This place is really amazing--a true neighborhood gem. I'm not sure why they don't get more boisterously loud press, because they certainly hold their own against Rich Table, Outerlands, and other SF hotspots. 

We love their deep wine list, the creative and well-executed tasting menu, and their incredibly reasonable prices! It's a very comfortable and special place, with excellent service. We'll be back!
author: Justin L.

description:
I had the fortunate experience of being treated to a dinner at The Richmond. Our dinner hosts insisted on the 5 course with pairing and the decadence ensued. I had a very similar experience and menu to Diane B. (review below). The food was amazing, care and consideration to plating and flavor combinations. We also got treated to a few "extras" which seem less extra now that I see others got the same dishes. The whole experience was fantastic except at the very end we also got to hear the loud and obviously pissed off staff brawl.
To be honest, I didn't care much because I was 5 glasses of wine in and tend to find the humor and passion in it. My hosts were a bit taken back and apologized which I immediately felt bad for, because they had indeed taken us to one of the best meals we have had in the City...period!
I gave them 4 stars because I found the atmosphere a bit claustrophobic with the heavy red curtains and the one bathroom stall.

The food is a stand alone 5 stars and if you can overlook the lively staff relationships, then book a table and enjoy yourself.
author: Elisa S.

description:
Our group came here and decided on doing the 5 course tasting menu. see http://www.therichmondsf.com/therichmondsf.com/Tasting_Menu.html.

Everything was absolutely delicious. The restaurant has nice quiet ambiance and is worth every penny.
author: Dennis K.

description: Not much to add that other people have not said. Dinner and service was perfect and the prices are cheap for the great quality of the food.
author: Adam G.

description: if i could give 6 stars, i would! probably one of my favorite restaurants in the richmond. besides the food (the 3-course with wine pairing is perfect), i wanted to write about the amazing, amazing service here. i've been here twice (first--introducing my boyfriend to my mom, second--with my boyfriend) and both times we were greeted by the owner of the restaurant. he co-owns the restaurant with his wife and they both serve as the waitstaff. i love how the richmond is "undecidedly hip," they know what they're doing, who their customers are and operate their restaurant with a sense of conviction and passion. the last time we were there for dinner, we ended up being the last patrons of the night. we spent 30 mins talking to the owner about wine, how he selects it his vendors and how he personalizes the tasting to each person. there are so many restaurants in sf that's "cool" and "hip" but has no heart. the richmond is the opposite. i can't wait to introduce more people to it.
author: Angela H.

description:
This is one of the best restaurants I have been to in my life. It is surely the most delicious food I have had. 

My boyfriend took me here for our anniversary. It was the first time we had tried the place, so it was a bit of a risk, but it ended up being amazing. He made a reservation; we were an hour late, but they had no problem. It turns out they hold the table all night, and I don't think they even charge a fee for it!  It is pretty dressy (like, cocktail-dress level), and they have linen tableclothes and all that, which I like. But it's small, so it's still intimate. And we got to eat by the window, in a little nook.
