We started out with wine. They didn't have the wine I like by the glass, only by the bottle, but the waiter was very nice to bring me a taste of what I wanted to try, and then I ordered that. 

Then we ordered the goat cheese, beet, and cardamom salad. Literally one of the best salads I have ever had. The salad also came with a warm triangle of phyllo dough stuffed with goat cheese. AMAZING! 

Then I had the pan fried chicken, substituting mashed potatoes for the scalloped ones. The waiter was really nice about explaining all the dishes, and about substitutions. I hate when stuffy places don't allow substitutions. You just know they are pretentious and think they know more about what pleases the palate than the person eating it does. Food is subjective. It kind of makes me think they make it beforehand instead of making it to order. Anyway, the chicken was seasoned perfectly. And I am a serious chicken lover, so I've had it almost everywhere. It was so good, even the next day, when I ate my leftovers. The other awesome thing about the restaurant is that the entrees were actually big enough to fill us up, not tiny, as some higher-end restaurants' plates are. And the prices are reasonable for the quality and quantity.

Finally, I have to applaud the service. They did take a little while to fill our water glasses, but I drink water faster than most people, so I don't blame them. But they were very attentive and understanding. They were okay with explaining anything, and didn't make us feel dumb for not knowing. Also, when we started getting warm, they were quick to open up the windows for us. And even though we were the last ones out, they didn't hurry us at all. 

Their menu changes seasonally, so I would suggest you hurry on over to try what they have now. And we will most definitely be going back. They earned every one of these five stars!
author: A K.

description:
Chose this random little restaurant for my birthday dinner with my bf's family.  Having read so many great reviews and hearing so many great experiences, our expectations were well exceeded!

We were quite impressed looks alone as we first entered into the restaurant...cute little wine room with glass doors and a quaint dark dining room with about 10 tables.  The staff consists of the owners (hubby as the chef and wife as the hostess) and an extremely friendly server.    A great added touch is that the chef acts as a co-server as away to introduce himself.

The menu is limited (about 6 main entrees that gets switched up every so often) but when you still have a hard time deciding what to order because everything sounds so darn good, then it's not a problem!  The impressive little wine room was accompanied by a little but impressive wine list.

So we started off with a surprise...two complimentary candied pears and walnuts salads.  The chef personally served this to us to apologize for the lack of welcomeness when we first walked in.

For appetizer, we had  the scallops on top of oxtail & polenta and for our entrees...steak , short ribs, seabass and cod.  All of which we were very impressed with.

We also ended with a surprise...complimentary chocolate fudge with almond lace cookies and a glass of muscat just for my birthday!

A great little gem in a quiet little neighborhood with great prices (nothing over $20 except for vino of course!), great quality as well as quantity and great service.  It's the perfect place if you  are looking for something semi-fine dining.
author: Tina L.

description:
Date night with boyfriend and not only do we get to stay in our hood but we end up having a romantic, foodie dinner at a great place that is actually reasonable.  

This place is small and is the definition of a neighborhood restaurant, but in the Richmond, you don't often find sophisticated French/California inspired cuisine that is all locally grown.  This place is quiet, romantic and has a simple elegance that is really inspiring along with a very impressive wine list.

We had the oxtail and scallops, followed by short ribs and steak and of course wine.  The food was great, elegant and very well executed.  The scallops with the polenta and oxtail were great, the short ribs melted in your mouth and the steak was amazing.  The portions are also very generous and the prices are great.  

We had a nice long dinner where we never felt rushed and great food all for $70.  In the city that is great and for the quality of food, service and ambiance almost unbelievable.  Sure you're in the Richmond but if you're looking for a nice, romantic dinner that is fit for foodies, you have to give this place a try.
author: Inga W.

description: I am so happy that we found this place! My wife and I joined another couple for dinner here tonight and opted for the 3 course dinner for the table. It was amazing to say the least! The Chef took the time to come out and personally explain each dish, while checking to see if we were enjoying everything. The Chef was completely cool with me substituting my appetizer dish for the Foie Gras on brioche with apples and agave syrup dish with a generous size helping of Foie like I've never seen, and it was prepared perfectly. My steak was cooked to a beautiful medium rare, and to those that say they weren't asked how they'd like their steak prepared, just trust that Chef knows what he's doing. Everyone in our party was extremely happy that we ended up having our little reunion dinner here, and I will most certainly be back and recommending The Richmond to all of my friends in the service industry. Thank you guys for a beautiful meal in a calm, unpretentious setting, in our quaint part of this amazing city!!
author: Tom K.

description: My wife and I have dined at least ten times at The Richmond over the years.  It hasn't changed much.  Still real well prepared food for lower than expected prices.  Still the 3 kinds of butter with the bread.  Still good affordable wines.  The menu changes with what's in season.  We generally get one of the fixed price options.  Recommended.
author: John K.

description: This place was great. The salmon was probably the best I ever had. The coffee semifredo was also good.
author: Reilly D.

description: Wonderful place. We walked in as a party of 9 with no reservation (every restaurant's worst nightmare), and they very graciously put together a table and took very good care of us. The chef came out and offered to create a special tasting menu for us, and every bite was delicious. The wine selection was very good, and reasonably-priced. Great low-key restaurant that clearly takes pride in what they do. Will definitely return.
author: Bret W.

description: Neighborhood gem of fine dining.  Very good portions from the tasting menu.  Delicious & well presented.   Great place for romantic dining
author: Cindy C.

description: The Richmond is a FANTASTIC place for a date, small, quaint, cozy atmosphere. Food was delicious and it's everything you'd want from fine, private dining. Probably would get 5 stars but I remember having to wait quite a while for the food, and it's been a couple months since I went. It's a great restaurant though - definitely check it out!
author: Joshua B.

description:
I always wanted to take my girl to this place but I always hesitated 

because it looks so fancy inside. But do not let that deter you from trying 

them because you will really be missing out on a great experience. For a fancy restaurant it is very laid back.

The servers are great, the chefs are great. The atmosphere is great and everything we had was great!

You do not live in the richmond if you have not eaten in "the Richmond"

I finally brought my girl, we were both wearing less than casual clothing, 

but when we entered we were greeted like we were the king and queen of 

england!  Then mark; who was the best server ever, gave us a choice to 

to either sit in a table where other tables were around or sit in a more 

intimate table with a little privacy, I chose the privacy for a little romance.

anyway, my lady and I, had a six course meal, and no lie every single 

plate that they brought out was delicious! Both my lady's plate and my 

own left our table without a single drop of sauce or crumb left on it! 

Their wine selection was great as well! So once again do not prejudge 

this place for what ever you think it is! go in get a table and dive into 

one of the best food experiences of your life!!!!!
author: John E.

description: The waiters are friendly. The good is delicious. I wish I could meet the chef to compliment him on the meal. Our waiter Rob was excellent, very friendly and helpful. A must try in the inner Richmond. The duck leg is to die for.
author: Steve M.

description: Excellent service and cute ambiance. Went here for a special date night and we were not disappointed. We shared the beef short rib and scallop over polenta (favorite thing we had), and then the pan-fried chicken and the hangar steak. All were solid but the appetizer was the most flavorful and interesting. Wine selection is solid and reasonably priced. They also do a tasting menu for $50/person which is very good in comparison to other SF restos. The cheesecake for dessert was unfortunately not impressive. I would come back but I'm not rushing back.
author: Natasha F.

description: wonderful experience, impeccable service, impeccable presentation, not one bite went unnoticed as amazing. owner personally helped select fabulous wine. the attention and food at this restaurant are far superior to other dining experiences in the city. would go back any chance I got.  understated.
author: Christy D.

description:
Made a super late reservation to celebrate a landmark occasion here last Saturday night.  I called around 3pm that day and was psyched to hear they had one rezzie left that evening for 9:30.  Perfect for us!  I'd heard this place was exquisite from various people who had eaten here years ago, so I was pretty excited to finally try it out.  Plus, I love supporting my neighborhood restaurants.

We had a lovely table near the door, but thoughtfully arranged velvet curtains protected us from any door drafts.  We ordered a few rounds of appetizers (crab cakes, sweetbreads and the potato leek soup) and some wine.  All was well.  My tummy was ready for this. So ready! 

The food arrived in a very timely manner, but really lacked anything special.  The sweetbreads were difficult to taste under all the pepper (way too much pepper) and coating, and they weren't very crispy as their description stated.  I love sweetbreads (who doesn't love the tender thymus?!), but these were quite....meh.  The crab cakes were ok, as was the soup, but again nothing really stood out in the dishes that made them special or memorable. They just tasted like dishes I could have had at any restaurant.  And I'm not sure what all the hype is with the bread and spreads. It was just....bread. Maybe I've become a bread snob since I rarely eat bread anymore.  Just tasted like average bread.

So I was hoping for bigger things with our entrees.  I had the burger, bf had the salmon.  Maybe this is my fault for ordering a burger at a nice restaurant, I dunno.  When I ordered it, I wasn't asked how I wanted it prepared.  I let that slide since I trust a good restaurant to know how to prepare it.  But when it came out, the middle of my patty was SUPER raw.  Like, sticky-moist-ground-beef-fresh-from-the-butcher-paper raw.  I kept double checking it as I picked at it with my fork, thinking maybe the lighting was making it look redder and more raw than it actually was.  Our server saw my distress and came over to ask if everything was to our liking.  I pointed out my raw burger and she said "Yeah, our burgers are cooked to medium rare."  This looked a little more raw than medium rare, and maybe some people like challenging their intestinal fortitude with burgers this rare, but after multiple bouts with e.coli poisoning in my lifetime, I don't roll the dice on ground beef and prefer it mostly cooked.  So I asked if she could throw it back on the grill for a medium-well finish, which she happily did.  But when my burger returned for round two, I picked it apart again and found it just as raw as round one! Surely the lighting was playing tricks on me (you know how restaurants dim the lights and cast a red tint to it to make everything more appetizing? I thought that was happening here).  My bf took out his iphone and we hit the flashlight app to really get a good look.  But seriously, the meat still looked so raw that I just wanted to be done with it.  I asked the server to just box it up (at this point, I'd rather just cook it at home myself).

After returning home, I opened the box up under our revealing white kitchen lights to make sure I wasn't overreacting.  Sure enough, I wasn't. RAW. REALLY raw. 

Except for the burger incident, the food wasn't bad (I would have given it  three stars were it not for the raw patty).  It was just really underwhelming for "finer dining."   Maybe we came on an off-night or something. But I'm not inclined to return since there are tons of wonderful options in the area. .
author: Summer E.

description:
The tasting menu was fun and totally affordable at $50. I added the wine pairing for $25 and really enjoyed it. 

The Short Rib and Scallop was AMAZING!
author: Melissa D.

description: My boyfriend and I tried this restaurant last night; it came recommended as a neighborhood gem and I hadn't heard of it so I figured we'd try it out. We were so pleased with our experience there in terms of quality of food, hospitality of host, cost (!!!), and wine selection and pricing. Parking was slightly challenging so when I came running in while by boyfriend parked, the chef-owner poured me a glass of wine to 'take the edge off.' Much appreciated. They did not care that we were a few minutes late because this restaurant only seats each table once/night--not in a pretentious way, but because they don't want to rush you. I really enjoyed that courses were served slowly. I love going out for dinner and sitting a few hours without feeling rushed. We ordered asparagus with Caesar, croutons, shaved parmesan, toasted capers and prociutto; the short rib & diver scallop over polenta (YUM); corn and brioche pudding (AMAZING) and duck (perfectly cooked in a port sauce that tasted like mole). The wine was tasty and oh so reasonably priced. The chef took so much pride in his food and was gracious to every person in the restaurant, which created an overall sense of gratitude from all parties in the restaurant. I can't explain but it felt nice :) Dessert: we couldn't decide between apple crisp and panna cotta and chef brought both! Both were delicious and yet still felt light and not overburdening with cream and butter. In fact, the whole meal felt fairly healthy and without fillers. Will definitely be returning!
author: theresa v.

description: LOVED IT!  We had the 5 course tasting menu and were blown away by the service, presentation, and flavors of every bite.  The owner, chef and server was very accommodating to a couple food allergies in our party of six.  The wine pairings were also generous and reasonably priced.  We will be back!
author: Kristen A.

description: This place exceeded my expectations. It's an interesting little spot that's not in a location with a lot of foot traffic. We were there as part of a group of 6 and we all had the tasting menu with wine pairings. They were very generous with the wine pairings. The butternut squash soup was lovely with pepitas adding a nice crunch as a contrast. Soft shell crab - really good. I enjoyed all the courses. The service was good - they replaced the utensils with every course, which isn't something I would have expected for a restaurant at this price point. Everyone was really, really nice. I would definitely go back. Wine prices are also lower than average. And you can carry on a conversation.
author: Natalie T.

description: The food was excellent - and mind you, this is coming from a vegetarian. But you know what I really liked? The ambiance. It was sweet and quiet (full, but peaceful). I could actually relax and hear my conversation with my date. I really enjoyed the space.
author: Christy T.

description: Where to begin? From the moment our party of four walked in, to the goodbye after our meal, everything was just about perfect. We were seated in a small draped area, where with the help of the carpet, it was easy to talk and be heard, something very rare now a days in most trendy restaurants. Our entrees included the duck, hamburger, and hangar steak. All were prepared as we ordered, and the amount of food was just right. Prices are more than fair for the Bay Area. We can't wait to return.
author: David R.

description:
I was here for a friend's birthday dinner and it was quite nice! I got drunk off of wine! I felt like I had a grand ol' time, but I'm not sure if my friends felt the same way about my behavior..hahahha I can't believe I pretty much drank the whole bottle by myself!  I don't believe I was obnoxious, maybe a little bit too lively and happy for the occasion but not obnoxious. 

My waiter always had an amazing smile, i was tempted to ask him if he ever felt strained wearing such a huge grin for so long.  It seriously looked like he plastered a plastic smile on his face for the evening.  I'm not complaining, but i just thought that was really amusing! Perhaps I may have had a little bit too much wine. 

Getting to the crux of the matter, the food was excellent! The chef came out to ask how everything was and even introduced himself.  For shame, I never remember much while being a bit on the tipsy side.  He mentioned something about something or other...but bottom line was, i had a great cut of the freshest salmon!  I wonder if he ever felt that good food was wasted on me since I couldn't tell anyway, being in my state at that time.  
The food was excellent! the service was great! You can tell the people here take pride in their work and you can taste the quality! The ambiance was very relaxing and comfortable. They had classical music and the beatles music on...that alone gets an extra star!! =)
The prices are a bit on the higher side, but the experience was worth it in my opinion.
author: Tu L.

description:
This is one of the best meals I can remember. They started by serving a sweet little homemade potato chip with some delightful white sauce and carmelized onions- like a REAL sour cream and onion chip, on the house. We ordered a bottle of King's Ridge Pinot- it was the perfect compromise between the steak and salmon. I really appreciate their reasonable wine prices considering the high quality. 

As the appetizer, we ordered the beet, cardamom carrot, and phyllo-goat cheese pastrry. So good. For the entrees, we ordered the steak and salmon. The steak was allegedly melt in your mouth delicious and the hash and swiss chard were perfectly cooked. My salmon was so tender and flavorful, but the shining star of the dish was the mushroom sauce. It soaked into the vegetables and infiltrated the salmon and was truly the most perfect sauce I have ever tasted. Nothing was too heavy and I didn't feel sick at all, and we were both so content for the rest of the night. The chef came out and made sure everyone was happy. The waitress was very attentive but never overbearing. I will absolutely come back.
author: Natalie V.

description:
Dankalicious in all regards. Came in for an early dinner around 5 and was warmly greeted by the chef who gave us a healthy cucumber shot when we first sat down. For the appetizer snacked on a deliciously dank crab cake and sampled my first dank-a-fried oyster. Let's just say I was salivating for more. For the main dish I got the Yellow fin Tuna, which was surrounded by a swamp of danksauce and dankshrooms. A nice glass of fine wine (can't call wine dank) didn't hurt either.   

Customer Service: Danktastic

Environment: Dankaesthetic 

The Richmond comes in on the Dank Scale at a hefty 9.5/10 rating
author: Thomas D.

description: Great food, service and value. Lacks ambiance big time. Won't go again, but solid for the price.
author: Ryan and Suky L.

description:
An excellent spot for a date. This place has that intimate, romantic restaurant feel without a massive price tag. The wine selection is fantastic, and the prices for a bottle are surprisingly low. My date and I went with the Firehouse Red, which I would highly recommend. Apparently one of the house favorites.

You're started off with a complimentary amuse-bouche of deviled eggs. You are also given fresh bread with an assortment of butter-- salted, blueberry, and parsley infused butters.

I ordered the bone in pork chop with potato puree and fresh veggies. My date ordered the steak with a brie cheese crepe. We also tried the crab cake salad as an appetizer. The salad was great, with a somewhat mexican flair to it. An avocado puree with a salsa-like salad on top of a very fresh crab cake-- yum! I enjoyed my bone in pork chop, and almost thought I wasn't going to be able to finish it as it was such a large cut of meat. But I did. My date didn't so much enjoy his steak, as he said it was quite rubbery, but he enjoyed the restaurant very much and noted that he might have just ordered the steak on an off night.

The staff was extremely friendly, and personable. Our waitress was quite entertaining, and fun to talk to. Service was incredible. We never had to pour our own wine, or worry about having too many empty plates on our table. I will definitely be back!
author: Ashley D.

description:
I had dinner at The Richmond probably a couple of years ago and I still remember what was one of the best dining experiences I had since I moved to the US. What I liked was the incredible simplicity.. Something it makes is elegantly sophisticated somehow.
I remember I had a tomato salad made with 5 different varieties of tomatoes.. Sliced and served as a little tower with very little dressing. Then as my entree a simple piece of chicken cooked to perfection and served over.. Maybe asparagus? (sorry but can't remember!)
Anyway.. The chef is obviously somebody who respects food a lot and treats it accordingly. For this Richmond entirely deserves 5 stars.
Ps: I think prices were very reasonable too..
author: Sergio T.

description:
We have eaten at the Richmond three or four times but haven't reviewed it yet...each time was a 5-star worthy experience! This place is tucked away in the Richmond but still serves delicious, inventive food in a classy ambience. Perfect for date night.

Like the last time, we got the tasting menu - started off with a delightful amuse and then course after course of perfectly portioned delicious food. Everything from the bread with different spreads to the main courses to the amazing service was literally perfect. The chef/owner came out and said hello and even gave us some free wine on the house, totally unexpected and amazing.

Unlike other restaurants like Flour & Water or Gary Danko, the seating here is actually intimate and you are not elbow-to-elbow with other diners. This is something I really appreciate, especially in San Francisco. Moreover, there's usually not a big wait, also rare to find in San Francisco for the quality of the food.

This place is seriously underrated - great food, perfect service, great ambience, and all at an amazing price. Can't wait to go back again!
author: S. L.

description: I have probably driven by this place a dozen times and never noticed it.  A gem in the neighborhood.  They make their own herb butter which they serve with the bread - delicious. A nice surprise was the amuse bouche they started us off with (melon puree with diced watermelon and  basil).  Ordered the heirloom salad with avocado and corn as a starter.  The tomatoes were perfect (not meal-y) and the corn and avocado were perfect compliments. For a main course, I ordered the hanger steak with sautéed chard and potatoes. Good portions, chard was cooked perfect and was flavorful.  Steak was a little too salty for my taste but other than that good.
author: Paige D.

description:
Came here the other day and really enjoyed the meal.  It's funny, the yelp site says this place is a little pricey, and for the food it is, but it has REALLY cheap beer, for some reason.  

Got the mushroom souffle, and each part of it was very tasty, although to be honest by the end of the meal it got a little too rich for me.  I'd still come back though.
author: Phil J.

description:
This is a really solid, neighborhood-y type place with an outstanding wine list and a nice, dining in my friend's living room vibe. They really excel at MEAT - like steaks and that burger, oh man is that good.  But lots of the other stuff is quite delicious but sort of unmemorable. I've been back a number of times because I feel like I am supporting my neighbors but they might need to kick it up a notch to make it into my pantheon of favorite SF places. We went with party of 4 on a Saturday night and just with normal convivial, wine-soaked meal we felt like we were Charlie Sheens on a crack whore bender from the sort of deathly quiet in the place.  (And we are middle aged moms/dads so not exactly rock stars.)  
I do like and if you are in the area or walking distance it is a lovely choice for a chill night out - I just might not travel across the city for it.
author: Kirsten M.

description:
I really wanted to like this place, but unfortunately I didn't.... 
I didn't like my food but my co-worker's was pretty decent. 

I don't think they paid attention to the details like stains on my wine glass, staff talking loudly in chinese, pour wine in the middle of our conversation, asking how everything was while we were all chating, serving across the table.... all these little things just didn't add up to the type of dinner i had in mind. 
  
I sat next to the kitchen door and our conversations would be interupted with the staff coming in and out saying "IN!" loudly.  All in all, I wouldn't go back =( 

Sorry =(
author: hannah t.

description:
When friends visit from out of town, the first thing I ask is "What are your dietary limitations"? It's my sneaky (and very Bay Area) way of trying to narrow down the myriad options for dining out in SF. However, the response was, "we eat anything, as long as it has calories...however we would prefer someplace quiet." 

Quiet. Yet, good. That is actually a bit tricky!

20 minutes of internet searches led us to The Richmond. After lucking out with parking, which is usually quite difficult in that area, I entered the restaurant wary, because it really was very, very quiet. Almost awkward quiet. We all ordered the tasting menu (warning, if one at the table does, everyone else is required to also) which was a little more than I was expecting to spend for the evening. However it turned out to be a delight. It was great to be able to catch up and hear one another, and my gluten allergy was elegantly accommodated. The food was delicious and interesting, the service was attentive and as my companions ordered wine pairings, the fellow who introduced the wines did a very good job.

Takeaway? Good place to go when someone asks for quiet...but good.
author: Betty O.

description: While I thought that the food was pretty good, I wasn't like "Wow ... I've got to go back!".  The ambiance was drab and I thought that the portions were too large (crab cake), which didn't help the taste.  Presentation was a bit lackluster.  Not sure I would return.
author: Denise L.

description: Such a cozy place. You need to make reservation to ensure a bookng but the food is great.  My boyfriend has ths fish, I had lamb, we shared an scallop app, and brownie dessert which was all fantastic.  The server was great with the reccomendation didn't reccomend the most expensive thing on the menue but actually what she liked.  Great value for the price. I wouldn't go back all the time as the menu is limited but great for a special meal.
author: Heather S.

description: Had a great dining experience at the Richmond. Delicious food and wonderful presentation. It's a cute restaurant and worth a visit.
author: Olya S.

description:
We live around the corner and have just now tried The Richmond. The ladyfriend and I went here for dinner on New Year's Eve and were floored by how good the food and service was. We were promptly seated right at our reservation time and our waitress, Ginger, was friendly without coming off as too eager. We started with the seared Foie gras and the panko fried oysters. If there were six stars on the yelp scale they would be dedicated, and exclusive to, these appetizers. 

As per one of my resolutions for the new year, I decided to exit 2010 with a nice cut of beef and the flank steak was cooked to perfection. The ladyfriend had the braised short ribs and the two of us were literally fighting one another other for the others dish, like two snarling cartoon dogs. The wine was excellent and affordable, and without a giant mark-up, which is something I really value about restaurants that are already making a profit on booze to begin with. 

Also, get the Peanut Butter Chocolate Tort. Seriously worth the wait. And I have no idea who this person was, but there was a short guy there with blond spiky hair that was carrying a signed head shot...of himself. 

Happy New Year SF.
author: Josh B.

description:
I wasn't very impressed. The service was not good, it took a long time for us to get our bread and beverages...this place is small, people in my group shouldnt be thinking of eating sugar cubes b/c they're THAT hungry. Even with that being said, if the food was memorable, it wouldve at least warranted 3 stars...on to the food: 

i had the fried oysters for an app and the cod and seafood chowder for my entree. 

The fried oysters were just like any ol fried oysters you could get anywhere...They came with a "miso slaw" but the slaw was more like sliced up cabbage with no dressing and there was no other sauce for the oyster so it was very dry...if i had a packet of tonkatsu sauce in my pocket i wouldve broken that baby out. 

on to the chowder: it wasnt a chowder. it was a nice piece of cod (best part of the dish) with a little bit of miso soup with random sprinklings of seafood (nothing really noteworthy). 

since we were with a large party, i tried several other dishes and pretty much everything was so-so. best thing i tried was the foie gras and that seems pretty hard to mess up, for the most part. 

Would not go back...they staff seemed ok, but definitely better options in the area.
author: matt h.

description:
If you want to spend a perfect evening with someone you like -- go to the Richmond.

The ambiance is romantic and cozy with draperies throughout for privacy and style.  The food is excellent focusing on high quality California ingredients and paired with wines from the region.  The service is attentive from the staff and chef.

I hope this place thrives for years to come!
author: Lis A.

description: Cozy!  Customer oriented service (not necessarily speedy but definitely customer oriented).  Creative twists on standard meals (not quite comfort food).
author: Paul D.

description: Took my boyfriend here for his birthday after reading such great yelp reviews about this restaurant and The Richmond definitely lived up to my expectations. Great food, service, and ambiance. We came in on a Tuesday night around 8:30 and since we came a little late and they close at 9:30, our waiter was super nice and made sure to not let us feel rushed to leave. I will surely be back here!
author: Stephanie G.

description: I ate here 2 years ago and it was quite good.  I recall the food portions was small but we ordered a bottle of wine and and their tasting menu.  It was a 2 hour dinner which we enjoyed very much.  The main reason why we chose this restaurant was because of a $200 gift card that we received. Downside on gift cards is that, they did't accept tip with a gift card :(
author: Kimmy C.

description:
I love San Francisco and all the good eats, but there's nothing that gets my goat more than waiting forever to get ressies to eat at a restaurant that's over-hyped, over-loud, and over-pretentious- only to find that the food, itself, is bland, boring, and mediocre at best.  IMHO, there are way too many of these types of places in the city. 

This is not one of those places.  As someone who prides herself on having a really good palate, I'd say the food here is on par with the likes of Gary Danko and La Folie, but in a much more casual and accessible (but still elegant and private) setting.   The five-course prix fixe menu here is a steal at $49.95.   You certainly won't leave hungry- the portions are generous, and when you throw in the amuse bouches,  fuhgeddabout it.  I practically had to be pried out of my chair with the jaws of life.   I'm still dreaming about the melt-in-your-mouth braised duck and the melt-in-your-mouth short ribs.  Not only is the food delicious, the presentation is visually stunning, and the service is friendly and attentive.  The owner/chef graciously came out to check on us several times throughout the evening, refilling our wine glasses.  Loved everything about this place- food, service, ambience.  One of my favorite restaurants San Francisco now.   Will recommend to everyone I know.
author: Lisa K.

description: This is a real neighborhood gem!  And located in my very own neighborhood I can't believe I didn't try this place sooner.  The setting is cozy and intimate, great choice for date night.  The food was good and the service was excellent. The portions are generous and pricing is reasonable.  I can see this becoming one my favorite neighborhood restaurants in the Richmond district.
author: Mac S.

description:
This is one of those quaint little neighborhood restaurants buried in the middle of the block.  We haven't tried this place since when Jakarta restaurant closed and The Richmond moved in.  Upon walking in, you can see the "not in an underground cellar"  wine cellar facing you. 
There were several diners already in the restaurant when we arrived.  It's so quiet that you can actually hear the conversation of the table next to you.  At one point, there was some delay in the food for the table next to us and I was surprised the chef came out personally to apologize.
We tried the 5 course prix fixe menu for $50.  It was well worth the price. Several amuse bouche came with the meal but my favorites were the soup, lemon sorbet surrounded by orange wedges.
My bacon wrapped, new york steak medallion was tender but not the best slice of meat I've ever had. There was also fried bite-sized bits of sweetbread (better than some I've had in the past) over a large foie gras mixed ravioli which was covered by a delicious mushroom sauce with truffle oil. 
A perfect ending to the meal was the coffee dessert with chunks of coffee granita, whipped cream, covered by toffee-like shavings.  Looked like a sundae, tasted like a dream. 
Our waiter was very nice, attentive and knew exactly what ingredients were in each dish.  Definitely worth a revisit.
author: Ry T.

description:
amazing, amazing. highly recommended. go there now. intimate as it gets while still staying cool.

first time here, and my only regret is that we haven't gone sooner. It's literally down the street from where we live. such a neighborhood gem! no really--its trite and overused, but neighborhood gem. diamond in the rough.

the prices are great for who and what they are. highly appreciative of this in the neighborhood. sparkling wine for 7.50 and a malbec for about 8 i think, with a bill for two that amounted to $109.

three appetizers, one entree, one dessert and two glasses of wine. fantastic! the sparkling wine was flavorful and light, a great start to the meal.

fresh hot bread with salted butter, olive butter, and parsley butter
at this point i was happy. all they needed to do was not screw up to get to five stars. the bread was fantastic, and devoured happily.

foie gras -- scallops with short rib on polenta -- crab cake
lovely appetizers. full of flavor, a great variety of tastes, and everything done well. what more can you ask for? well, the only thing was maybe having it come out with some time in between. everything was served all at once, which is probably optimal for a table of four, but for the two of us, we had to focus on one dish at a time, so some of it might have gotten cold. either way, still amazing and delicious and happy.

pork tenderloin with swedish meatball and veggies
i was slightly full at this point so we got most of it to go. the vegetables were delicious and perfectly seasoned and cooked. the pork tenderloin was a little dry, but still tasty. i'll still be super happy eating it later, i know.

pain perdu with strawberries -- porto
a light and sweet touch to end the meal. i love strawberries, i love port. i got them both. 

the service was fantastic, and our server was nice and came when we needed him. a delightful meal, a delightful night. he listened to our comments on the pork tenderloin being a little dry, the chef came out to thank us for our comments, and i think this definitely shows the care and pride from a neighborhood joint.  definitely will be back, and bringing friends along too.
author: Jade L.

description: So yummy! We did the tasting menu and enjoyed every bite. Not 5 stars in my book just because we heard a server talking rudely about a customer and it was very unprofessional; you expect optimal service for a restaurant at this price level. Still, I would go back because our server was great.
author: Lisa E.

description:
White table cloths, non-pretentious, excellent service, EXCELLENT FOOD, and INCREDIBLE WINE SELECTION, affordable as well! You don't get a combination of those much in this city at all!

Went for an intimate birthday dinner and we were comfortable from stepping our feet in the door.

We had a crab cake starter, with main dishes of Salmon and Veggie Crepes.  Let them help you with wine, their list is hand picked...

Will return as soon as possible!
author: Elliott J.

description:
thank you ruby h. for writing a review that sold me to take my bf here for his birthday. 

don't let the reasonable prices fool you! the place really is a place you would pass by everyday and not even give it a second glance. parking is definitely hard being in the richmond.

I walked in feeling slightly overdressed, just a dress in general, but everyone else was more casual and neighborhood-y feel. oh well, better overdressed than under!

the tasting menu online is different from the one in the restaurant and i'm kind of glad it was cuz the one online wasn't too appealing. We decided on the tasting menu and to do the wine pairing! our first time! whee. very good prices, $50 for tasting and $25 for wine pairing.

Our waiter was very nice and since it was my bf's birthday, he had a "heavyhand" pour. X____X

we had:
deviled eggs- thought it was hardboiled eggs HAH, but it was creamy, simple
the complimentary bread with spreads- pesto was good, the salted butter thing is always good, and olive...eh not my favorite.
squash soup- in a tiny cup, very creamy and flavorful
beet salad- red beets, yellow beets, goat cheese in a crispy puff, it was yummy.
crab cake- very flavorful, a lil bit of spicy kick.
ravioli- it was a very good ravioli, lol. there were chicken pieces that were so tender, and there is bread? inside the ravioli?
bacon wrapped ny steak- slightly different than most steaks i usually eat, it is on the sweeter side cuz of the bacon. but without the bacon, the meat is a bit bland. cooked perfectly though.
by this time we were getting really full. the first two courses were served with white wine which complimented the dish perfectly.
the rest were red, which took some getting used to, as I am not a red wine drinker. 

who knew you'd get buzzed from a wine pairing?? sigh

then they brought out a palette cleanser, lemon lime sorbet with oranges. refreshing!
then for dessert was the coffee semifreddo, they added a lil candle for the bf.
it was very good, the toffee nuts had great texture with the coffee ice cream. 

bf was very pleased with the place i chose and i am too! we will probably be back and maybe bringing the parents to try a fancy place!
author: Christine M.

description: One star is being generous. After about 45 minutes someone stopped our table in the back and asked if we were ready to order yet. I ordered the steak, which took another 45 minutes and then came out rare because the waiter never asked how I wanted it cooked. My friend asked for ice water and after asking for it three more times she actually got it. The food was meh - the service was worse. Not recommended ever.
author: Sam R.

description: I have been going to this restaurant for many years and can state unequivocally that this restaurant is a hidden gem. John & Thu Ha provide innovative, creative, and delicious food at insanely reasonable prices. Thu Ha is extremely personable and charming and is responsible for outstanding appetizers and desserts. My favorite is the beet and carrot salad although everything I've tried has been excellent. Recently celebrated my birthday there (again) and was not disappointed. Parking is usually challenging but we've always had good luck parking in GG Park which is just 2 blocks away.
author: Faye L.

description:
So first of all, how darling is this place?  Our little table felt so cozy and romantic, it was separated from the entry by a little curtain, totally made me want to canoodle with my date..

Started off with flatbread topped off with some sloppy joe type sauce.  

I had a puff pastry "whisky barrel" filled with amazing mushrooms, served over whipped potatoes and some kind of slightly sweet orange colored sauce (can't remember what it was).

I tried my date's chicken scalloppini and ravioli, yummy.

Wonderful chocolate and peanut butter torte with vanilla ice cream.

The owner dropped by to thank us for coming, the service was beyond good,  the cost was minimal and every detail of our 2 hour meal was perfect.
author: Poppy C.

description:
I went here with my boyfriend for our anniversary and it was truly the perfect evening - partly because of the company, but largely because of The Richmond.  

Our meal was great.  Started off with complimentary crab wontons, which were yummy and crab-licious.  The bread came next - warm and plentiful with three different kinds of butter.  For our entrees, I got the hanger steak and my boyfriend got the sea bass.  Having tried both, I can say that each were excellent.  The steak was perfectly cooked and came with a more than generous portion.  The fish was light and fresh and overall perfection.  We topped off our meal with the chocolate and peanut butter torte, which really was the perfect ending.  The meal itself was very good; the fact that in total, including drinks, came to less than $70 made it fantastic.  

The food, however, was not the best part of the meal.  I would be doing a disservice to yelpers if I did not compliment the AMAZING service that we had here.  Knowing that it was our anniversary, the staff went out of their way to make the evening special.  We were seated in a private area, checked on often (but not too often), given complementary glasses of wine with our dessert, and told "happy anniversary" by everyone who served us - including the chef, who checked on us twice!  I really don't know if I've been served better in even the finest restaurants that I've dined at. 

All in all, a great experience.  I definitely won't be waiting another year to come back here.
author: Megan D.

description: Very tasty! I didn't get the pairings but I'll have to try that next time. The food was fantastic and the professional and quieting atmosphere was enjoyable. I got the steak and it was cooked to perfection with a fantastic salad. Decent prices nothing was too expensive or out of range for the quality of food.
author: Adrienne P.

description: This place is always amazing. Ive been coming here for years after discovering it when I lived in the richmond. I highly suggest it! The crabcakes and the burger the way to go
author: Erin E.

description: it's a  wonderful life if you really enjoy here, i mean  no matter how the food is good or anything else, a cup of  coffee and bring a book, just sit here, read some and  think something about the life, you will know something. that's is a good place should give you.
author: Correalew F.

description: Went here on a date with my lady. It felt like a neighborhood restaurant that was just fancy enough without being full of themselves. Better yet, these guys can cook. Decent, reasonable wine list. I will be making this a regular date night.
author: Bob R.

description:
I love everything about this little restaurant, it truly is a neighborhood gem!
For my second dining experience at The Richmond we opted for the 5 course tasting menu ($49.95pp) which was actually more like 8 courses, but with everything perfectly scaled so you don't over-eat. Well, not too much anyway!

The bread and spreads get 10/10.

Dinner by preceded by a hot apple cider to awaken the tastebuds, followed by the soup (not on the tasting menu). The soup was wonderful, rich and creamy with fantastic flavors. 

Roasted beet and cardamom carrot salad with goat cheese and filo pastry. 
This was nice, though I'm not a huge beet fan, and the pastry was a little think for my liking.

Crab cake and arugula salad with avocado puree - wonderful! A great tasting crab cake, moist with with a light and crispy coat. The avocado was tasty and had a bit of a kick to it. Perfect!

Braised seabass in a white wine tomato sauce.  My fish was melt-in-the-mouth wonderful, though the sauce was somewhat disappointing. Less white wine and more tomato than I had expected, with an unusual cheesy flavor.

Orange sorbet and segments to cleanse the palatte - very nice.

Seared fillet with wild mushrooms and potato hash.  I don't usually like my meat quite this rare, but it was so wonderfully soft and melty that I didn't mind. Perfectly paired with the mushrooms. 
I think I got lucky on this course, because my fellow diners complained that their meat was a little stringy. 

Coffee semifreddo.  Not my favorite dessert, but a very nice finish to the meal nonetheless.

The wine menu is diverse, but what I like most about it is that the wines are reasonably priced and without ridiculous mark ups. 

The service is attentive and pleasant, and I love it when the waiter is able to tell me about the wines on the menu.  
This is a small and intimate restaurant, with a very calm and cosy atmosphere - not the place for a loud party, but a wonderful place to enjoy great food and quiet conversation.

I know I'll be back!
author: Izzy A.

description:
Dinner consisted of: 

Beet salad
Oxtails and scallops
Lamb chops
Salmon
Complimentary Bread

I mention the last because it was so damn good.  They had an herbal butter, an olive butter and a salted butter.  I seriously would have been happy with the salted butter and bread for dinner.  (The herbal butter has got to go and you may as well just serve olives instead of mixing them with butter.)

The smoky, meaty oxtails were perfectly matched with the polenta, as were the salty scallops.  I didn't think the oxtails and scallops were a good combo, but treating the dish as two worked well.

The beet salad was nice, but I have to admit that I kind of like the taste of dirt and the chef seems to have stumbled upon a way to prevent the beety-tast-of-earth from presenting itself to the palate (citrus rind).  So if you love beets, you might want to think twice about ordering.  If you hate beets--you'll probaly love this salad.

Salmon:  disappointment.  First of all, the sauce-rainbow-o-colors have got to go.  Secondly, the salmon was bland bland bland.  As were the lentils.  A very boring dish that made me wish there was more salted butter for the bread.

Lamb chops:  a bit gamey.  Not overwhelming, but definitely gamey.  Veggies were very good, potatoes with chive were alright.  Did I mention that the Lamb chops were wee gamey?
author: Nobody M.

description:
My father and I are on a Richmond run of excellent. We continued it tonight at Pot De Pho (http://www.yelp.com/biz/pot-de-pho-san-francisco#hrid:Cc3XEUwfM7c8ZlyjMy9s4Q), but it started at The Richmond.

It was this yelper's Birthday Eve, and we went to celebrate. One month later I am still raving about how much I loved it. The service, the environment and the food were all exceptional.

Every single person we interacted with - the hostess, our waiter, the chef when he came out to say hello - all exuded a genuine appreciation for our patronage. And they all, rightfully so, gave off this confident, assured and prideful tone. Each knew they were working at one of the best restaurants in the city.

All this took place inside a small space that defined intimate, charming and warm. One could easily get caught up in the experience and think they had the place all to themselves.

But none of the above would have mattered had we not thoroughly enjoyed the food. Even though a few weeks have past, I vividly remember the flatbread sloppy joe, the chicken ravioli and the grilled squid. Inventive, expertly prepared and exceptional, each one confirmed what was a sneaking suspicion all night - The Richmond was one of my favorite meals of the year.
author: Jason B.

description: John was extremely accommodating. He personalized our meal and our wine. He didn't hover but was wonderfully attentive. All of the food was to die for. I cannot recommend this place enough.
author: Maggie C.

description: Came here in April for my birthday dinner and I couldn't have asked for anything better. Sometimes, with fine dining, I have to admit, I'm a little disappointed with the portion sizes but you don't have to worry about that at "The Richmond". Both of our entrees (the duck leg and the skirt steak), were amazing and our server recommended a great bottle of wine that complimented our entrees perfectly. The little restaurant is quaint and tastefully decorated and the service was top notch. We'll definitely be back.
author: Kristy R.

description: Short and sweet - The Richmond is not only a hidden gem, but serves an outstanding 5 course wine pairing at a very reasonable price - if you come here get this!  The chef is friendly and the staff extremely knowledgeable.  This is a great spot for a special occasion, is low key, and will not disappoint.
author: Matt D.

description: This is a true neighborhood gem!  My husband and I came one night for dinner after having walked by it so many times in the past.  It's a small, intimate restaurant perfect for a quiet evening out.  The service is top-notch, and the food is so well prepared.  They started our meal with an amuse bouche of melon salad, and we shared a beet salad for an appetizer.  For our main entrees, I got a really juicy and tender pan fried chicken, and hubby got the seared rib-eye steak cooked to perfection.  For dessert we had the panna cotta and coffee semifreddo both really big and super yummy!  Everything we ordered far exceeded our expectations.  We are really looking forward to coming back!  Thank you, The Richmond, for such a lovely evening!
author: Julie P.

description: I went to dinner here last night with my boy friend and I have to say.... I'm not sure what all the fuss is about? while the food i ordered was delicious (app: short rib and scallop, main course: hanger steak. BF got the salad with blue cheese and pear vinaegrette and the cheese burger) I didnt find a lot of the things that are in the pictures that other Yelpers have posted! where was the foie gras or the crepe filled with bri i thought was going to go with my steak? Maybe its because it was a wednesday night? maybe they changed their menu? i dunno, but i really wanted to try their Foie Gras!!!!!!!!!!!
author: Megan S.

description: Found this place on Yelp and couldn't believe how great it was.  Wonderful food.  Really genuine service (they took wonderful care of us, and we had decided to bring our 1 year old daughter...which can be a challenge sometimes).  And the prices were incredible.  If we lived in the Richmond, we'd eat here every week.
author: Kimberly G.

description: Great dinner.  Went here for a going away dinner and got the pre fixe menu for 4.  We brought out own wine but they have a great wine selection.  It's more of your quiet white table-cloth type restaurant but the menu was more progressive than the atmosphere.  Great place to go with parents.
author: Kyle L.

description:
I was really excited to try the Richmond for my birthday dinner, especially after reading the great reviews from others and also seeing that it was just down the street from where I live.  On our walk over, my boyfriend even said, "Hey, if we like this place, it can be our new go-to place to celebrate!"  I liked the cozy setting, but we were kept waiting for what seemed like forever to order wine and food.  Our reservation was for 8:15, and it wasn't until nearly 9 that we got our amuse bouche.  I had to ask for bread because I was so starving by that time.  It definitely seemed like the restaurant was understaffed, as any request took forever to get any follow up.  
It took a while for our appetizers to come out, and both were just luke warm when they did.  I wonder if they had been ready for a while, but sat because the staff was too busy to bring them.  At that point I was too hungry to sit any longer and wait, so I didn't send them back.  We ordered the crab cakes and the oxtail.  The crab cakes were the highlight of the evening--great texture and taste!  I wish they and the sauce it sat in had been hotter.  I was disappointed by the oxtail, as the scallop was overdone and the oxtail was underwhelming (and nearly cold).  For our entree, my boyfriend had the bacon wrapped steak.  He said it was ok, but nothing spectacular.  I got a meat dish as well (I apologize, the name escapes me!  It came highly recommended by the waiter).  I got half way through it before starting to feel sick to my stomach, so we packed everything up and left.
AS A DISCLAIMER--I really wanted to like this place, and it seems like a lot of other people had a good time.  I would hope to have a better experience another time, but honestly it was so disappointing that I can't see it being worth my time or money to try it again.  The Good:  cozy atmosphere, reasonable wine prices, friendly staff.
The Bad:  extremely long wait time, cold food, underwhelming flavors.   While I appreciate the good, I just can't reconcile it with waiting a very long time for luke-warm food that doesn't taste that great.
author: Annika M.

description:
This review is looooong overdue as I came here with my family for my father's birthday in August 2009, but I was just reminded of how wonderful it was and wanted to add my two cents....At the time I was living on Anza and Arguello Streets and my parents were driving in from Northern Marin to celebrate my wonderful father's birth. His requests: something different, new (not the same old Italian, Chinese or Mexican place) and that wouldn't break the bank, because although it was his birthday, he was taking 5 of us out for dinner. 

The Richmond was perfect! I called ahead of time and talked to the host about pre-ordering and paying for a bottle of wine to be set on the table for when we arrived. He was extremely accommodating, asking me what my dad liked in wine, food, etc. I settled on a bottle: 2007 Patricia Green Cellars from Willamette Valley (we ended up getting 2 we enjoyed it so much!)

The ambiance is great inside, its small but still functional, no one is on top of each other, and we had a nice little alcove section to ourselves. The lush red drapery and dim lights are really spectacular. Our server was excellent and we ordered: 

Caesar Salads and the Leek Soup
Seared Hanger Steak 
Rack of Lamb (2)
Wild Pacific Salmon & Eggplant Salsa
Braised Wild Pacific Seabass 

Each were excellent, with full flavors and rich tastes. For dessert I am pretty sure we ordered one of everything and shared them all. Gluttony for sure but we all had a wonderful time, were treated great by the staff and i have suggested The Richmond to numerous other friends and colleagues as well! Bravo!
author: Alissa C.

description:
We had dinner here last night for our first time.
It will be our our first of many (and we live in Noe Valley).
We are going again next Thursday.
It was that good.
 * Wine: About 10 wines are available by the glass. Nice
 * Dinner: Everything was terrific. I had the Red Wine Braised Short Ribs, with potato puree. I brought some home (to save room for dessert) and just finished a great short rib sandwich on a chabata roll.
 * Service: Spot on, attentive without looming over the table
 * Price: Very reasonable for this QUALITY. 3 starters, 3 entrees, 2 drinks, 3 desserts, tax & 20% tip = $152.20
author: Wayne S.

description:
It's hard to remember to come back here, but when we do, I kick myself for not coming more often.

I also forget what a great deal it is here: we had the amuse bouche, the amazing bread with flavored butters, salads, entrees, a glass of wine and split the dessert for under $100 with tip.

Highlight of last visit: hanger steak! So beefy-tasting. You forget that beef is supposed to have a flavor, sometimes.
author: Stacy J.

description:
Great little wine list that is CHEAPER THAN RETAIL. The staff always remembers us and gives us extra tastes. Three types of delicious butter and excellent sourdough bread. And I can't think of anything witty to say right now so just trust me and go and then get the molten chocolate cake with peanut butter filling then give them a fantastic review on here because they deserve it and they're great.
K Thx.
author: Chloe N.

description: Quiet, calm, small, great food, service could be a little better
author: Eileen B.

description:
We came here for dinner on a weekday. The restaurant is petite, but they seated us promptly; we had made reservations. I was told that the burger was the best here, so I thought . . . why not? I could use a good burger, and I was starving since my coworker had decided to finish my half-eaten lunch (I was rushing off to a meeting, at the time).

Anyhow, the burger was great. Not dry. Bun was crispy and reasonably priced for a semi-upscale restaurant. Would I come here again? Yes. Oh yeah, they give you soup and bread while you're waiting for your entree to come.
author: Jennifer H.

description:
My friend Richmond and I had ran the San Francisco Full Marathon a few days before we ate here with a group of friends. We were both 26 years-old, running 26.2 miles, on the 26th of July - weird, right? Why do I bring this up? Well, he decided to keep this triple-theme going by having his birthday dinner here. Yes, that's right: Richmond's birthday dinner at The Richmond in the Richmond District. I suppose when you turn the incredibly old age of 27, you try to come up with stuff like that to make things more exciting. I wouldn't know about that though - I'm staying 26 FOR-EH-VER. (c)Squints in The Sandlot.

We had a table for eight reserved at 7:00pm and called to let them know we'd be about 30 minutes late. They gave us no trouble and even bragged that they were saving the best table in the house for us. They must've heard that my non-Yelp-Elite ass was coming over and that I was going to write one of my craptastic reviews. Or maybe they were just an incredibly cool staff. I was delighted to see it was the latter... or possibly both.

This restaurant is tiny. Their restroom is so small, you don't have any room to walk in it: you step in, you piss, flush (please do), do a 180, wash your hands (please, please do), do a 45, open the door, and walk out - it's so convenient! It's also very clean. *thumbs up* They have these little nooks where you can be seated and (what I think were red velvet?) drapes you can shut for an extra dose of privacy. Upon entrance, we were greeted warmly and were brought to the biggest nook of the place, and it was perfect for the eight of us.

 We started by looking at the wine list, which had about 8 - 10 choices of each type of white and red. We decided to go with the Woop Woop (yes, like Bub Rub and his whistle-tips) Cabernet and the Ramsey Pinot. Both weren't pricey at all and went great with our food.

They started out by bringing us crusty bread with three types of spread: olive butter, herb butter, and some type of cheese. They all tasted fine with the bread, and the waiters were quick to bring us more bread everytime we ran out. That was followed with samples of their potato-leak soup: it was so smooth, clean, and tasty. I might have to order that to start next time. A few of us shared the Foie Gras while others had the Heirloom Tomato Salad. No complaints on the appetizers here - it was all fresh and delicious.

Most of us got the special of the night: a generous cut of Rib-Eye with a Toasted Brie Crepe with Potatoes and Onions. It was great - the crepe was a great compliment to the rib-eye. However, the only reason I can only give this place 4-stars is that my rib-eye was very rare when I ordered it medium-rare. The meat was quality nonetheless, and I enjoyed it a lot (that's what she said). During our meal, the chef greeted us and made sure everyone was satisfied.

I had the coffee and had a bite of the Apple Tarte to end our meal. Not bad!

My friend Ralph brought me a bag of durian candy straight from his stay in Singapore, and I opened it to give everyone a piece - BAD IDEA. This stuff was foul and so much like real durian that it stunk up the place. Luckily we were the last party left. The chef was all smiles and even accepted a piece since he said his wife loved durian.

This place is definitely a gem - very intimate, great staff, decent prices, and good food all tucked in a very quiet part of the Richmond District. I'll definitely be back. Maybe I'll come back for my 26th birthday this year... or maybe my 26th birthday next year.
author: Len L.

description:
Took my family and bf here for dinner the other night, since it's super close.  We had an enjoyable meal and everything was reasonably priced, but I wasn't that impressed.

Bottom Line: Good but not Great
author: Chris Y.

description:
fine dining in the Richmond, really?  the decor of this place is pretty cool.....the bar and the walls seem to be made from either real wine crates or replicas.  either way, it looks neat, and i wouldn't mind having that incorporated in my place.

my buddy and i just wanted a burger, so we asked to be seated at the bar, as the rest of the place was a bit too fancy (and/or too romantic) for us.  they started us off with an amuse bouche (this apple cider with chantilly cream...it was good).  their bread with a variety of butter/spreads was also good.  so far, so free!  i'm really not a cheap-ass, but i do like free stuff, don't you????

the half-pound burger was freaking excellent.  i probably didn't need to eat the whole thing, but it was good.  the handcut fries were amazing as well.  

okay, that's really all we ate, but the dessert menu looked really good.  i could see this spot being a nice date place, but if you don't have any love in your life, there's nothing like a good burger and fries to ease your pain.  at least that is what i tell myself.

this place is legit, and the prices are really reasonable.  the service was good, and it was nice of the chef to come out and thank us for eating there.  i could see myself wanting to try their tasting menu one day.....maybe just not after a Thanksgiving weekend filled with stuffing my face.
author: Miss P.

description:
We had an amazing meal (my dad said it was the best hanger steak he had had in his life)....good selection, great flavors, generous portions and reasonably priced wine list.  The ambience is comfortable (you can actually have a conversation without raising your voice) and intimate.
I found this place a bit randomly through open table and it was a great find.
Can't wait to go back!
author: Rochelle S.

description: The food is excellent.  John's, owner and head chef, knowledgeable tidbits concerning of the wines they serve was very informative. We had the 3-course meal with the wine paring, nice pours and portions. You are not rushed out, very comfortable cozy. They have curtains in some areas, so you can have a intimate dinner if you like or there is a room big enough for about 10 people and still have other table available, not it not too crowded. You must try!!!!
author: Adrienne L.

description:
Dear The Richmond,

You are marvelous.  I brought my parents to you when they were in town, and I have not seen them enjoy a meal so thoroughly in some time.  My steak was perfection, which I appreciate greatly as I seldom indulge in such things.  

The two males of our party were both very pleased with their hamburgers and impressed that you had such a thing on your fairly-upscale menu (though after having one slathered in fois gras in Chicago and the $16 cheeseburger at Father's Office in Brentwood, I'm no longer surprised when I find fancy hamburgers).

We all delighted in the amuse bouche, two of your luscious desserts, and a reasonably-priced Syrah.  If you weren't so (appropriately...but, still) pricey, I would treat you like a neighborhood restaurant and drop in all the time.

Love,
Erin

P.S. We came on a very rainy night, and our waiter was extremely kind and helpful about taking our dripping coats, umbrellas, and various other sundries (i.e. my floppy, soaking-wet Burberry bucket hat).  That was beyond the call of duty, and just makes me appreciate you even more.
author: Erin M.

description:
This was the perfect pick for our anniversary dinner last night.  Intimate design and definitely not pretentious.  Loved the deep red velvet curtains.  They added just enough accent and separation for privacy between parties.  We had a table right in the front window, so plenty of space, yet confined enough for my husband and me.  We ordered the 5 Course Tasting Menu.  And it was absolutely beautiful.  I caught my husband several times eating with his eyes closed to better determine flavor as well as savor each bite.  Service was also amazing.  As my husband commented, Steven was just the right amount of attentive.  He was helpful and knowledgeable and we sure did appreciate him.  We were also never left with empty dishes long at all.  The whole meal flowed beautifully.  They even added a small candle to the corner of our dessert dishes for our Anniversary.  The small things really do make a difference.  If we had one thing to suggest, it would possibly be to utilize a crumber/sweeper for the tables.  It would add that extra something (like the candles), as I have a knack for creating crumbs wherever bread is served.

Excellent, excellent, excellent experience!  Thank you!
author: Christina C.

description:
Our night had a bumpy start, but by the end of it, I was convinced that this is my new favorite restaurant. Last Saturday, my husband and I came here with another couple. We had lined up a babysitter and were psyched for an adults' night out, an all-too-rare occurrence these days. We arrived for our 7 p.m. reservation, only to find that due to a computer glitch, it had been canceled. At first, we thought all hope was lost, but the chef and staff - who were very apologetic - rallied and made it work. They sat us at the bar with a gratis bottle of champagne for our trouble. 15 - 20 minutes after our original reservation time, we were seated at a table. This set the tone for the service - our waiter was ever-present but not obtrusive, friendly without being too talkative, and well-versed about both the menu and the wine list, able to make spot-on recommendations.

The food was top-notch: think fresh, simple ingredients that work well together. The salmon was perfectly cooked, the foie gras a decadent treat, and the panna cotta for dessert was light and not overly sweet. My dining companions' food looked amazing, but I was too focused on my own to even think of tasting. The wine list is brief but selective, with lots of great values (our friend noticed a wine that retails for $30 for only $39 - not a bad mark-up).

The chef came out to check on us and apologize again for the reservation gaffe. The classy way the staff handled our situation, the top-notch food (at reasonable prices), and the seamless service all made for an excellent experience - we'll definitely return.
author: Jen R.

description: I liked it here. The food was great, and my girlfriend and I had a nice cozy spot with drapes to make it seem very private.
author: Forest S.

description:
Came here for my wife and daughters' birthdays.  The food and service was excellent.
We ordered ala carte however we wanted to try the prix fix but their policy is all members at the table have to order it...disappointed.  My wife doesn't like foie gras or duck which is why  she wouldn't order the prix fix.  However, my daughter and I would have went for 2 prix fixe.

However, the ala cart was enjoyable.  Along with the appetizers, we were served deviled eggs and baguette with 3 enjoyable butters like, kalamata olive, sea salt and I think cilantro?
The foie gras, crab cake and sea scallop was good.  The braised short rib, hangar steak and fish and seafood chowder for dinner were all good.

My only negatives were the limited menu.  We wish they had more selection and also didn't require everyone at the table to get the prix fix menu.  In addition, if we were able to do so we all would have gone for the wine pairing but it didn't seem to make sense doing it ala cart.  Also, it  would be difficult to return often if they don't change the menu as I would want to try something different....remember the menu is good but very limited.
author: g s.

description: Not that this place needs any more positive reviews, I just figured one more won't hurt. I dined here with my BF a few weeks ago and we were blown away at how wonderful the food was.  Our server was very friendly and knowledgeable of the menu. I ordered the butternut squash soup (best I've ever had) as an appetizer and then I had the crab cake app as my entree. My BF had the oxtail with Maine diver scallop and then the tenderloin - yes he was very hungry. Couldn't finish everything but it was all outstanding. We had a great bottle of Malbec with our food too.  I highly recommend this little hidden gem in the Richmond district any day of the week.
author: Theresa A.

description:
Incredible restaurant.  

But a serious warning:  Don't even THINK about driving to this place,  I thought I've seen some bad neighborhoods in SF for parking - North Beach and Polk Street are up there - but it is abso-fucking-lutely impossible to find parking around this restaurant.

Cab it - you'll be glad you did.  There is no, I repeat, no parking in this neighborhood.
author: David M.

description: Great little neighborhood gem. Very good food, very good service.  Our server "Rudy" was great.
author: Brad G.

description: Perfectly cooked food and great service. The spiced chicken and pasta was delicious and they have a good wine selection. Will definitely be back!
author: Carma Y.

description:
Between 4 and 5 stars.

Food was delicious. Though, it seemed like my wife and I had the same sauces on our dishes (both meat dishes). There aren't so many dishes on the menu so repeating a sauce seems like there is a bit of a lack of creativity. Salt level was significant, close to too much, but not quite there for us.

Service was excellent: good information and attentiveness; professional and polite.

Atmosphere is great for what it is: a wonderful neighborhood restaurant. 

Very good value for food and for wine.
author: michael b.

description:
After passing this cute little place so many times and trying to go once without reservations (FAIL), reservations were made for an 8:30 Saturday dinner.  I arrived about 10 minutes and tried to grab the attention of one of the two servers and busboy, but I couldn't. I was getting incredibly frustrated!!! No one acknowledged my huge doorway blocking presence for 17 minutes!!! WTF?!?!?!?! I was getting so cranky, I wanted to leave. But since I had wanted to try this place, I waited. Plus the reviews seemed good. 

I had a feeling once we were seated, things would improve from there. (Partly because my shoes would no longer hurt.) After being seated, service improved vastly from there. The 2 servers were no longer brisk and unresponsive. They were suddenly very attentive. 

The seared foie gras was very tasty and sizable. The apple sauce on the side was different but worked nonetheless. The seabass was cooked perfectly with delicious vegetables and a light and balanced white wine tomato sauce. The fish was able to be the star of the dish. 

Another plus is the a very affordable wine list. Towards the end of my meal, the chef came out and thanked us for our patronage. I thought that was a very nice touch. 

I got over the curt service when we first entered. Would I come back, sure! But I have other restaurants to try first!
author: P L.

description: Loved my dinner at D Richmond! Staff was very friendly, no complaints at all. Atmosphere was superb, very cozy seating with dramatic velvety curtains, great for a date night ;-) Food was simply delicious, very aromatic. This is def a fine dining gem in the heart of the city.
author: Ankita B.

description: Intimate environment. Excellent service as well as food. Appreciated the wine suggestions.  Would have expected it to more expensive. All around an extremely pleasant experience.
author: Cy L.

description: Lovely food, great atmosphere. Very accommodating to food allergies in our party and a really solid wine list.
author: Caitlin S.

description:
We've always taken our out of town guests here for dinner, excellent food.  Haven't had any complaints about any of the entrees on their menu, but I definitely lean towards the sea bass.

Parking could be challenging, but it'll be worth it.
author: Kmaintl L.

description:
Love this place! I've only been here once but enjoyed it very much! 
 
I had the Steak Rib Eye Stuffed with Mushroom Duxelle and oh my god.....

that's all I can say.

It's a good date place or just with a few close friends. Quite expensive but really worth it. 

Enjoy, eat, and share the company with your loved ones.

Service is meant to be sort of slow so you enjoy the atmosphere. Good wine too!
author: Carissa E.

description:
I hate to even write a review because I'm afraid to give away one of the secrets of the Inner Richmond, but to be fair, it's amazing and should be shared with others. 

Every time I've come here the Chef and Owner(?) has come out to greet our party and thank us for supporting the restaurant. Most of the items on the menu are out of my price range, but there is one amazing deal.... the burger, which is amazing ... and it comes with fries for $10. 

Their condiments -- the butter that comes with the bread and the ketchup and mayo are house-made, and they are amazing. 

They even have Trumer on tap. 

This place is very cozy and classy. If you want to impress parents or a date, this is a great option.
author: Angela M.

description: I got the veggie entre which was mediocre but the starters (roasted beet salad and potato leak soup) and bread/butter were so amazing that I am still giving this place 5 stars.  Very reasonably priced as well.
author: Robby W.

description:
Dinner for my hubby's birthday.  What a difference in what this neighborhood restaurant used to be.  Nice little bar, nice decor - though hubby did have a 'distance' issue with a piece of 3D art that was hanging right over our table.  Way too close to have tree branches sticking out of the canvas...

Anyway... onto the food.  Started off with a "sloppy joe" style flat bread.  Surprisingly delicious - but how can you go wrong with something topped with Italian sausage?   Hubby had a yummy salad with a vinaigrette (he's so good).  

Entrees, I had the short ribs.  Wonderfully fork tender, over a mashed potatoes and greens.  Hubby had ravioli with sauteed chicken.  Mine was better (heh, heh).

No room for dessert.  Very friendly service.  Our waiter was on it - always checking in on us.  Dishes were cleared almost immediately - but not in a rush to get you out.

A very nice evening.  We'll be back.
author: Denise M.

description:
This restaurant was recommended to us by the folks from The Plumed Horse in Saratoga as they knew we live in the City . The Richmond is more than good, it was great!  We opted for the 5 course tasting menu: Roasted Beets & Cardamom Carrot Salad, then Crispy Crab Sweetbreads, Braised Wild Pacific Seabass in a White Wine Tomato Sauce,  then a leek soup, and finally Seared Rib Eye Stuffed with Mushroom Duxelle.  The food was paired very nicely with 3 local small local wines.  Of course the chef gave us a lemon sorbetto to cleanse the palette prior to coffee semi-freddo dessert which was paired with a really smooth grappa. Everything was excellent. I told Chef John that we appreciated his food not being overly seasoned and we were just pleasantly surprised by the affordable food with wine.

So, if you want high quality, upper end dinner,  without the upper end price, go here. It's a bargain! What I mentioned above is a $74 per person without tip. That's $50 for the tasting menu, plus $24 for the wine pairing.
author: Al G.

description: I'm used to eating at Asian restaurants in the Richmond district but so glad I found this place. We had the potato leek soup and foie gras to start, they both were excellent. One of the best foie gras I've ever had (and I've eaten a lot of them.) The potato leek soup was nice and tasty too. For entrees we had the skirt steak and pork chop. I'm normally not a fan of pork chops but they've taken it to another level. It was tender and juicy in every bite, I think I would only eat pork chops here :) Our server was very friendly and courteous too, we told her we were in a hurry and she managed to serve everything in a timely manner. The chef also came out to greet the customers at the end of our meal, that was a nice touch. I would totally come back again.
author: Yan R.

description:
We had a family dinner there last night.  The food and the service were fantastic.  

I had the tomato salad and salmon.  All 4 of us really enjoyed our meals. I'll definitely go back.
author: Ben B.

description:
The boy and I loved this place.
The food was good, but the atmosphere and staff really make it. Superb wine selection and a good offering of half bottles (always nice if one of you has to drive after dinner).
the bread is out of this world as was the scallop and oxtail appetizer.
Crispy skin arctic char was also great. The hangar steak was very good, but needed a little something to give it an extra boost. We had all of the 
following (some of which they give to every diner for free) for $98 (before tip)

potato leek amuse bouche
yellow split pea soup with bacon crouton
whiskey braised oxtail and seared scallop with polenta
fresh baked baguette with three flavored butters
Crispy Skin Arctic Char with ratatouille
Hangar Steak with chard/greens
Panna Cotta with lemon curd (deeelicious)
chocolate cake-type dessert whos french name I can't rememeber
1/2 bottle of 2001 Syrah.
2 cups of coffee.

AND the chef came out and spoke to all the tables, thanking us for our patronage and making sure everything was done right.
