author: Alex K. W.

description: Roast pork with mashed potatoes! Very Good!
author: Michelle H.

description:
The person who wrote that the medium-rare hanger steak was too rare must have either ate there on the same day as me or overheard me mention it to my family. That's one big reason why this place only gets three stars. If I'm paying about $200 for a family of four for dinner, I expect my food to be cooked properly, which this wasn't. In addition, I wasn't a huge fan of the spice rub or marinade they put on it. It was tender, but it wasn't what I expected or ordered. If you want to order it, make sure you order it medium if you normally get it medium-rare and ask the waiter what the steak is seasoned with.

Another reason why this place gets three stars is because of the service. Our waiter was extremely polite and was more than willing to offer his suggestions, but the overall service was ridiculously slow. After we were seated, it took about 20 minutes to get our bread, 45 minutes to get our starters, and an hour-and-a-half to get our entrees. All in all, we were probably there for close to 3 hours.

Finally, a minor gripe about the wine -- it should have been decanted. There was quite a bit of sedament in the bottle and in our glasses ... not very good.

To be honest, this place was on the border of two stars. But with how great the Apple Cider, the bread with the compound butters, the "Sloppy Joe" starter, the Chicken Ravioli, and the Chocolate-Peanut Butter cake were, I can't justify a two-star rating. 

This place is good if you know what's good. Just beware of the above concerns.
author: Ross H.

description:
After hearing about John and the Richmond from a friend who lives in the neighborhood I decided this might be just the place for my small (30 person) wedding reception. As anyone who has planned a wedding reception can attest, if you don't have 200 people, a lot of money and a love for undercooked salmon there aren't a lot of options out there. If I could have imagined the ideal place for my wedding reception, it would have been the Richmond. When my husband and I went for our first meeting, he was totally sold and said "its perfect" and I said "I know!!!" John is really wonderful and has such passion about what he does. We and our friends are really into food and wine, and my husband and I just wanted to have an intimate "dinner party" with good food and wine where we didn't have to do the dishes.  

John was very flexible and accommodating and customized the menu and the evening just as we wanted it. We had a blast at the tasting and were very impressed with the food.  From the moment we arrived to set up the flowers in the afternoon until the moment we left in the wee hours (sorry John!) everything went smoothly. It was like being in our own home. The staff was so friendly and helpful. The pacing of the meal, wine selection and the food itself was top-notch!

This is a true hidden gem. To have a meal, let alone a private reception, of that caliber and service without spending a fortune in SAN FRANCISCO is unheard of! And frankly, even if we did spend a fortune, I doubt we would have had the service and fun that we did with John and his staff or as tasty and elegant a meal.

Our friends and family report it was the most fun they ever had at a wedding reception and the BEST FOOD they ever had a wedding reception for sure!

Braised Short Ribs, Crab Cakes and Beet Salad are standouts!

Thanks to John and his staff for making our night so very special. We'll be back!
author: E E.

description:
Quiet & cozy - perfect for catching up on the uninterrupted conversation we haven't been able to have since the lovely Boy came into being - great wine list at a reasonable price - again, perfect for catching up - 
the food was ok - not alot of choice for a vegetarian - we aren't, but if you are, you won't find much choice - the dessert was kind of disappointing, but it was the 3 hours of uninterrupted conversation we had as we sat at our quiet velvet-enclosed table sharing a very good (& did I say reasonably priced?) bottle of wine as the fog swirled outside the windows that gives this place 3 stars.
author: Robyn C.

description:
Went to this great restaurant for dinner last night and it blew us out of the water. Because of the ban on foie gras is looming we ordered 3 orders of the seared foie grad as an appetizer and they were all delicious. And at only $16.50 a pop it was beyond worth it! They served bread with 3 types of delicious butters and an amuse boush  before the appetizers. One nontr though, the crab cake was very spicy. Luckily the Man who ordered it loves spicy but had I ordered it it would have been too much. We had the cod, the salmon and the fried chicken. All were really amazingly delicious but the fried chicken was unanimously the favorite. It was done perfectly. We ended the evening with the warm chocolate and peanut butter dessert which was great. 
Now a note on the staff and atmosphere. All are very unassuming, but kind, knowledgeable and go above and beyond. 15 minutes after arriving the power went out on the whole block. They handled the situation with grace and, because of gas burners, were able to get food out still. The chef came out to assure that he was still cooking and that service wouldn't be stopped. The lights came back before the main course and it all made for a fun experience. We were also the last to leave, per usual with my family, and they didn't mind at all. It took some time to get a cab out there so they just chatted with us while we shared some drinks and waited. It was the most surprisingly pleasant experience we've had in the city. 5 stars all around!
author: Avery H.

description:
I found this restaurant on Yelp and Opentable.  We were going to the Post-impressionist exhibit at the DeYoung Museum and wanted to find a local restaurant that would be nice for dinner after the exhibit.  While I had checked reviews, the quality of the restaurant and the experience far surpassed my expectations!  WOW!

The service was outstanding and the waiter made our dining experience feel very special.  His wine selection was perfect for our meal.  The food was outstanding and I consider myself a foodie!  Everything was beautifully presented and the food was superb!  From the bread with special butter and sea salt to the amuse bouche (a small portion of their potato and leek soup)  We had the sea bass which was exquisite and the mushroom in philo pastry--also fantastic.  By the way--the roasted beet and carrot salad was out of this world. 

I highly recommend the restaurant for a special occasion, a celebration or whenever you want a  wonderful meal.  We'll be back next month and many more times to come.
author: Jackie K.

description:
I came here with my boyfriend for his birthday, and had a great experience! We had the foie gras, and they brought us two of them when the chef heard that we had never tried it before. The chef even personally checked on us for each course to see how we liked it. 

We got that, the scallop and ox tail, hanger steak, cod and oyster chowder, and two desserts, all for eighty dollars! Everything was delicious and it really had the feel of a five star dining experience. We requested a more private/romantic seating arrangement and were sat in our own curtained-off room! 

Everything delicious, service impeccable, everything was perfect. I will definitely come back here for any special occasion.
author: Perry S.

description: Very small location wen't here about 4 months ago for a double date. The chef's, and server's here are awesome. The main chef is actually the owner.  Some of the best food I have ever tried.  Only thing I didn't like is that the wine pairing was pretty weak as they use low quality wine's ( 3 out of 4 of us had headaches from the wine's).  Highly recommended for any special occasion! I would return. 4.5 stars!
author: Javier V.

description:
This neighborhood emerald should be praised by all food critiques and local patrons! The chefs amuse was a delicous apple cider and bread with assorted flavored spreads. the pear salad and oxtail/scallop starters were perfectly portioned. the seabass and hanger steak were cooked to exact juicy temperatures. with all the proper seasonings and accompanyments. the sorbet cleased my palate and pecan truffle desserts were rich and scrumptous! 

The table was intimate with curtains and Xmas decor.  we never felt rushed with our late reservation. The server was laid back and let me engage with my date. the only regret was that I was so too full to finish my brie pastry with my entree. the chef/owner was pleasant when greeted table. I encountered a similiar experience here a few years ago with my exgirlfriend.  thats consistency!
author: Alex S.

description: This place was awesome. Went there with a friend, we enjoyed 3 glasses of wine, two starters, two entrees, and a dessert for about $100! The service was impeccable, ambiance fantastic, and food perfect. They don't accept American Express (groan) but lets be honest, I can't deny them stars for that. It is one of those places that has a small menu due to the fact that instead of spreading talent/value/taste widely among multiple items and thus diluting it, the few items they have all are done to perfection. Go here for a quiet intimate dinner, you will NOT be disappointed!
author: Nadine O.

description: We had a 6:30pm dinner reservations and thought the service needed improvement. My sweedish meatball dish was phenominal but  our waiter wasn't that educated on the minimal basic menu list that the restaurant offered. The waiter wasn't educated on the ingredients in many of the dishes. I was hoping we would be educated on what we where about  to enjoy. I have to give the place a 5 star rating though as a perfect date spot to make a good impression and I would go back for that only reason.
author: Robin S.

description: We went to this restaurant last night as it was close to the Academy of Sciences, but we had a great meal. The three course menu for $35 is very reasonable and the portions are large. The duck leg was great and my boyfriend had the port chop which was equally as amazing. The wine was a steal at $32.  I would not rate this a $$$ restaurant. John, the owner and chef was very attentive. Dessert was amazing. We will definitely come back, if we can find parking. It would be five stars if they had easier parking, but the park isn't far away and has lots of parking there. Wells done The Richmond!
author: Michelle F.

description:
wow, i cant believe its been more than three yeas since ive been here. i put it on my "go here often" list, but for some reason or another, i just havent gone back.

just as good as i remember it. could not be more happier with the entire meal. bravo indeed.

amuse bouche.... well its was great and dont you love meals that start with a amuse bouche?

*little story time* 

so i can be a little kid most of the times. im young at heart, i cant help it. soooo remember late 90s bad dance music?

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5P0_v__IOrE&feature=related

this is what im hearing in my head everytime i hear amuse bouche. if you are ever eating in a nice place with me and you see a grin when theres a mention of an amuse bouche, now you know why. 

La da da dee da da da da

seared foie gras on a nice piece of toasted, yet fluffy bread with what i thought was a bit of cinnamon. wonderful.

roast pork loin with mac and cheese and some veggies. this was outstanding. 

the ladys dishes were just as good if not better. 

absolutely nothing i could even come close to complaining. 

just a note, but these small things make the difference for me these days..... 

the bread came out crusty and warm and with some great olive butter, butter with grey salt and a chives/parsely butter. add a few slices of cheese, some cured meats and a bottle of wine and this alone couldve been a great meal. 

speaking of wines, they expanded their wine list. something i remembered about my visit 3 years ago seem to have stayed the same. they have some really good, higher end wines at fairly reasonable prices. 

cant wait for another visit.
author: Euge L.

description:
I took one of my best friends here tonight for his birthday because it was close by and of the rave reviews from yelp.  I always love it when the chef/owner comes out to introduce himself/herself and to talk about his/her passion for cooking.  It really adds a great touch to the whole dining experience.

I honestly think this restaurant can be better.  They are a little slow on the service.  The seating capacity is probably around 40 and they only have one waitress and one busboy. The food is a little dated and they can definitely use a face lift on the menu. Overall, it was still good. The ambiance is very quaint.  They have a lot of draperies around the whole restaurant and they do have candlelighting on their tables.  They also have a wine room.  The bathroom is coed and is not handicap accessible. 

This is what we had.

We decided to make our own 3 course meal.  We split the burger and fried soft shell crab for appetizers.  My buddy had the pork chops with macaroni and cheese and I had the arctic char with rice a roni.

The burger.............the best 9 dollar burger I ever had.  They have their own home made ketchup. dijon mustard, aioli, and hot sauce.

The soft shell crab and salad was awesome.  I just love the freshness of everything.  A little over seasoned.  (side note...........they don't have salt and pepper shakers on their tables.  A little pretentious but all the food really didn't need any reseasoning.)

The pork tenderloin and macaroni and cheese.  The pork was very tender.  I really didn't like the macaroni.  They could've done it with mash potatoes instead.

The arctic char was cooked to perfection.  They used a medley of brocollini, carrots, and string beans.  I always love a restaurant when they use brocollinis. 

The whole dining experience will last around 1 1/2 hour.  The total cost for this meal was 66.00.  What a deal!!!  They had this one dessert on their menu that we wanted to try but it took 15 minutes to make.  I think the waitress should've told us this when we ordered our entrees.  Oh well...........there's always next time because I am a fan.  

My buddy was so impressed with the meal that he made reservations for the next day to celebrate his actual birthday with his family.

One way to best describe the food, and this is no way to disrespect the chef, but it tasted like what a restaurant on a cruise liner would serve in their high end restaurants.  You know..........the ones that you have to pay extra for.
author: jason g.

description:
Being in a relationship means finding yourself at times in situations outside your sphere of familiarity; this can be both a positive and a negative. Here is an example illustrated for you. For simplicity, My sphere of familiarity will be more of a cube. And it will be two dimensional, making it more of a parallelogram. Use your imagination.

 --Sphere of Familiarity--
 |                                         |
 |                                         |
 |                                         |
 |                                         |
 |                 Me                  |                         Wine Bars
 |                                         |
 |                                         |
 |                                         |
 |                                         |
  -------------------------------

I am out of my element in these sorts of places.

But I've been to a few, and The Richmond has everything you'd expect; Marked up wine served in expensive glassware, and plates of beautifully presented miniscule portions of fruit and cheese. Three of us shared a decent bottle of pinot, a beet salad, and a cheese plate. Honestly, the real standout among the appetizers was the complimentary bread and trio of flavored butters made in house. 

But The Richmond has my endorsement because I suspect that the owners understand people like me; There were three details that my companions may not have noticed but seemed to be there just to make non-wine-bar folks like myself feel at home. They were:

1.) Sports playing on the TV. If your companions are willing to sit at the bar up front you can watch football.

2.) Trumer and Prohibition Ale on tap.

3.) An awesome burger on the menu. Moist premium beef & cheese on a bun from Schubert's bakery, and some perfectly done shoestring fries. The ketchup is also made in house, and has notes of basil and dill; AK and I decided it was a little better than the ketchup at The Front Porch and that's saying something.

The Richmond does well as a wine bar, especially since you can eat burgers and drink beer and watch football there.
author: matthew r.

description:
I am so excited that establishments like The Richmond have been popping up in my neighborhood.  To have The Richmond, Namu, and Sushi Bistro all on one block is pretty dope.

I took my parents and brother here for a joint birthday dinner and it was pretty fun.  I liked the fact that it's what I call "California-fresh" with local ingredients cooked to perfection in a taste and texture contrast that makes me want to lick the plate.

We got the potato leek soup sample, which tasted so good I stole my dad's serving.  We also got the soup and salad which the 4 of us devoured until our entrees came.  We each got a different protein and we all tasted each other and hands down my seared chicken was the winner.  It was juicy and the skin was crispy and savory and just one of the best seared chicken I have ever had in my life.  I think they must brine it because how did they get the chicken so juicy?  HOW?  Not to worry, the duck was nice, maybe a little stringy, and the fish came with an amazing sauce while the steak was satisfying.  The bread with the 3 butters gave a nice touch to the dining experience.  I want to go back an gorge on that chicken as many times as possible.  That with a whole bowl of potato-leek soup would give me a reason to get fat....
author: Susan C.

description:
I can't get you off of my mind. The salmon was placed on top of a bed of oyster mushrooms, spinach, and sauce and came with tender broccolini and green beans. The carrot and beet salad was seasoned with cardamom as a really nice twist. The steak wrapped in bacon was perfectly done, as was the oxtail appetizer with scallops and polenta. 

We went here for our anniversary and wanted a nice, quiet romantic restaurant. Everything was terrific, reasonably priced, and spot-on for our night. We will be back.

I had to think twice about mixing the salmon leftovers with our eggs this morning to make a scramble. Part of me wanted to eat all of it on my own.
author: katt a.

description:
Small Restaurant. Big Wine List. Complimentary Food. That's The Richmond.

We came on a lazy, rainy Saturday evening after watching Zack and Miri Make a Porno (sidenote: Yes, we still had an appetite after watching the movie. Not MUCH of an appetite, but it was something. Go watch it!). The Richmond seemed a little out of place being in a residential neighborhood, but it was definitely cozy and charming. The staff was extremely nice also.

Since we weren't that hungry and we spent the night before (Halloween) binge drinking, we did not load up on the drinks and food. All we ordered was the pork with mac and cheese and one of the fish and veggie dishes. The fish was good, but definitely do not come here and not get the pork with mac and cheese! You will regret it.

That's not all. They brought over the complimentary bread and spreads and the bread was amazing!!!! The spreads were butter, an olive spread, and some other herb spread, but like I said, the bread was amazing! Light and crunchy on the outside and soft on the inside. 

They ALSO brought over this sweet fig/raspberry sauce/yogurt thing that was different and pretty yummy, but WHERE THE HELL DID IT COME FROM??? We hadn't ordered it, so we looked at each other and were like, "ok."

Then, they ALSO brought over two green salads for us. It was some sort of arugula blend with a sweet vinaigrette, but once again, where the hell did it come from??? When we finally gave the server a weird look saying "we didn't order these" she said they were all complimentary since the kitchen was a little behind on our entrees. Amazing! Why do you only get free food when you're not that hungry? (By the way, we didn't notice the kitchen was lagging.) 

The prices were reasonable too. Not expensive at all. The Richmond is definitely a small nice restaurant with decent American food that everyone should try at least once.
author: Maureen B.

description:
After barely escaping Friday Nights at the DeYoung with our sanity intact, Basi L and I were rescued by our Knight in shining Nissan and whisked away to the quiet, calm environment of The Richmond. The Richmond was exactly the double dose of civility and taste that Basi and I needed after the Mr. Toad's Wild Ride experience of Dia De Los Muertos at the De Young. 

Since I've been kind of a nightmare train wreck of a friend and significant other lately, I thought I'd treat my two favorite ho's to some cheap(ish) wine and tasty snacks. I was shocked to see many, many bottles on the wine list for less than $40. We shared a $29 bottle of Pinot and were extremely satisfied. I know my wine pretty well and this was definitely a great buy. 

On to the food. I really have a problem with itsy bitsy portions served on enormous, cave-man sized plates. This is what happens at The Richmond. The food, though high in quality, is served in painfully sparse portions. The cheese plate was no more than 4 or so paper thin slices of manchego (served with an overly salty pecan butter), another light cheese with a delicious berry compote, and a generous pile of bleu cheese (nothing special) under some lightly dressed greens and roasted apples. This was $12 and would not have been satisfying for one person, let alone three. Basi and I are cheese fiends and I would not recommend ordering the cheese plate. We also got the beet and carrot phyllo dish, which was delicious but equally sparse and probably best for one person, especially if that one person really likes beets and has a hard time sharing :) 

The real standouts were matthew capital r's burger and fries. I have never in my life enjoyed eating off of his plate more than I did last night. With every handful of fries that disappeared from his plate into my hand, I was getting closer and closer to God. The ketchup is house made and smacks of basil and dill. It is on par with Front Porch's ketchup and they were very generous with it. The housemade aiolis, mustard, and butters (parsley-chive, salted, and kalamata olive) are all divine and are clearly made with love. 

There was only a short wait to belly up to the 4 person bar but they recommend reservations for any night, as the space is teeny-tiny. The service was gracious, warm, and friendly and included some free pours when our bottle was empty and generous servings of bread and condiments while we waited for our dishes. 

Basi and I will be back for a girl date. And this time, she better put out.
author: Autumn K.

description:
A great little bistro in the middle of a quiet neighborhood, but worth at least one visit if not several. I went there with some friends after a happy hour at the De Young Museum on a Friday night, it's about three blocks away, which is pretty cool and convenient.

The Richmond is definitely redefining neighborhood cooking, and the clientele - typically in their 30-50s - tends to be a regular and appreciative crowd. The organic Californian menu changes enough to keep things interesting but you can rest assured you'll always get something delicious. An indication of the attention to ingredients comes with the bread plate, which comes with three different types of butter to taste. One item that is a consistent fixture is their half pound cheeseburger hamburger and fries, which, as with all good bistros, is done to perfection. 

The service is great, if a little casual, and on our visit the owner/chef lingered around our table to explain some of the dishes we were having. A well thought out wine list complete the overall experience.

I'd recommend The Richmond for a quiet dinner with friends, or perhaps an intimate date. In either case, any foodie in your party will be duly impressed and will surely marvel at the idea of finding such a culinary experience seemingly in the middle of nowhere.
author: Nish N.

description:
This place is very very good. Not great, but very very good.

The small space is next to a laundry mat/dry cleaner. The owner and his wife are usually on hand to share a dinner conversation with you, which is a very nice touch.  Aside from that, I was pleased with the food, but not blown away. In fact, the bad part is I can't even put my finger on something specific that I ate. I only remember that it was good.

Fun trivia: the chef/owner likes Jack in the Box.
author: Jason C.

description: Excellent place! Nice to have a simple elegant restaurant in the neighborhood. Staff was very attentive without being over bearing.. And the chef came out to see how everything was! A plus in my book. I really enjoyed my meal and wine as well! highly recommended
author: Nora S.

description:
Visting this cozy, family-run, elegant, friendly, environmentally conscious restaurant really made me think: 

When we all usually dine out or shop, how often do we actually feel like we are directly supporting the people whose efforts and dedication have wholeheartedly gone into what they have created? Sure, perhaps a visit or two to Rainbow Grocery... or those artsy shops in the Mission/Hayes Valley... but on a regular basis, dining at most places in the city is usually an anonymous experience- sometimes you get to meet the chef, sure, but the chef isn't always the owner- the owners are sometimes a group of investors with deep pockets.... here, it's an elegant family-run neighborhood restaurant that deserves a try- perfect for a romantic dinner for two, or a night out with friends. 

As the other reviewers have mentioned, the Chef John made it a point to visit and chat with the tables (and it's been 15 months since they opened..) He made sure everything went well (our dining experience was wonderful) and he even entertained our curiosity about parallels to real-life cooking and 'hell's kitchen', the tv show... (now that's a nice guy!) 

The restaurant supports sustainable organic and LOCAL farming and gets its produce from five small Californian farms- and it shows! The menu is seasonally changed based on the freshest ingredients available. 

Our table had the Halibut, Vegetarian Tofu dish (mm... not what you think, not 'flavorless' at all!), Chicken, and another Alaskan Fish that I can't remember... but it was all well-seasoned & beautifully presented!
The appetizer portions are just perfect, not too large so that you'll spoil your appetite for the main course... 

It was difficult to choose from the dessert choices- I wanted to sample each of them... but we all shared the banana dessert (sadly, my memory fails me) topped with an ice cream that was just a few notches short of that of Joe's Ice Cream on Geary! 

Their coffee is served in those wonderful french press pots, the tea in those beautiful cast iron teapots, and the china they use is simply gorgeous- Villeroy & Boch- my faay-vorite! (I was impressed as soon as I sat down, to be honest.) 

I think we even witnessed a marriage proposal.. Awwwww...... 

Check it out! You won't regret it! 
Their menu changes seasonally, so check out their website for an idea of their menu- but be aware that it might be a little different. 
Opentable.com!
author: M'ia K.

description:
I went to The Richmond last week on a whim with some buddies to let off some steam from the roaring weekend we endured. I had read many good reviews of this place and thought it would be a nice change from the norm.  Arriving to The Richmond was an adventure in its own right, and having a restaurant of such surprising caliber tucked away against the harshness of San Francisco was quite enthralling.

We were seated in a private room, the ambiance was nice, not stuffy or pretentious.  It said elegant without being ostentatious.  We had great service all night, and the food was absolutely spectacular.  The bread was awesome.I did love the three butters, I love having options, I think most people do.  I could rave about many of the courses, the cheese course of Humboldt fog and rhubarb chutney, the perfectly cooked duck breast, and of course the seared Foie Gras with pain perdue The Foie was the best dish of the night, I would highly recommended this dish to any Foie Gras fanatic.  Every dish was devoured with fervor and thoroughly enjoyed, no misses.

It was a great night, the staff was attentive and friendly, the chef gracious and humble. I would come back and would absolutely affirm that The Richmond is a terrific neighborhood gem with incredible value that you rarely see in this big city.
author: Shaun C.

description:
Summary: It's okay, nothing to rave about.

After hearing rave reviews on Yelp and from my sister, my wife made arrangements for a party of ten for my birthday. When we all arrived, we were ushered into a back area where it was more private.  Instead of one table for 10, two tables for 6 and 4 were made so that the server could get better access - however, dividing made it feel like two parties instead of one. We had to insist on joining the tables together. Insist meaning that the server would not do it, but the owner had to come out and explain to us how their service would be hindered. We thought it would be okay for the server to do a little reaching - after all, they are going to come over and reach maybe 8 times during the dinner at most, while we will be sitting as two parties for 2 hours?  [Strike 1]

Immediately, we noticed that the menus were not the same as they were on-line; slightly disappointing because we were anticipating specific items. Oh well. The other asterisk was that if one wants the tasting menu, then the entire party MUST order the tasting menu no exceptions. Needless to say, not everyone wanted to eat the same thing, so that idea was out the window. [Strike 2] 

The meal itself was good, but not spectacular nor particularly outstanding; it wasn't super expensive either.  To top it off, because they knew it was my birthday, they provided a candle, but no cake (not that we were expecting anything).  What was the candle put on? The bottom of a coffee cup.  I don't know if they had meant it to be a joke, but it sure was!  Not only that, but what is the COST of a slice of cake compared to the bill on a party of 10 (~$500), about 0.3%?  I don't get it, don't even bother - that move just screams "CHEAP". [Strike 3]
author: Alan Y.

description:
Everything you've heard about the burger is true.  

A bulbous patty of ground goodness with an above average bun and a generous complement of fries for less than a Hamilton.  They also had a great selection of salads and, for a smaller restaurant, a surprisingly good number of wines to choose from.  

When I'm out that way, I tend to end up on eating somewhere on Clement, but I will happily hotfoot it across Geary for The Richmond.
author: L W.

description:
I've eaten here once, but I've already had two positive experiences.

One Sunday night, me and my fiancee were walking by and decided to check out the restaurant.  It was closed, but we glanced through the windows and were looking at the menu.  As we were looking, the door opens and John, the aforementioned owner and chef invited us in to take a look around.  We declined, but had a nice conversation about the restaurant, the food and the wine.  John was so nice to us even though the restaurant was closed and he was there just to work on the books.

A few days later we decided to actually eat there.  Our expectations were bouyed by all of the glowing reviews here at Yelp, and we were not disappointed.

First, we made a reservation via Open Table to get the points.  But we didn't need to on this Wednesday night.  We were the last people seated that night and they were very gracious.

Shortly after we ordered, our waiter brought out an amuse bouche for us.  A little sample of one of the main entrees.  Yummy.

Then there was the bread.  Yes, there were three types of butter.  And yes, they were each unique and fantastic.  We loved the berry butter.  (Curious, you have to come and try it!)

Our appetizers were delicious.  I had the soup and she had a salad.  The waiter thoughtfully gave us two soup spoons since we were planning on sharing.

We each ordered burgers and while a little thing, both were cooked exactly to our liking.  Sometimes a place will get lazy when you order two steaks or burgers cooked differently, and they both end up coming the same way.  No, not here.  

As we were enjoying our dinner, John came out and asked us how the food was.  Delicious!

I saved room for dessert and it was probably the most pedestrian of the whole meal.  That's not to say it wasn't good becaues it was.  Compared to the rest of the meal though, it just seemed okay.

Nevertheless, the whole experience was wonderful and it's great knowing that if we want to get dinner at a nice restaurant, that there's one nearby.
author: Ben C.

description:
I really wanted to like this place because every time my cousin and I try to make reservations at a certain time they're booked! We were certain this had to be amazing so we were stoked when we could finally make a reservation that would work. 

We got in and the place is definitely small and hard to have a conversation at a normal voice without the acoustics lending it to an automatic and inadvertent eavesdrop session for everyone else. The bread was amazing, 3 types of butter and perfectly warm! We started with the foie gras which sat on some french toast. The foie gras was so rich and delicious that we both liked it better with the table bread and by itself. It needed something to counter the texture and a soppy piece of toast and syrup didn't pair as nicely as we thought. 

My cousin got the pork chop with potato puree and I got the hanger steak. The pork chop was very nicely plated with a good portion size however upon cutting into it we realized that it was so fatty that half of the chop was fat. We both know that some fat is perfectly normal and almost necessary for a fine pork hop but there were heaping piles of it on the plate by the time we were done with it and it was kind of gross. The hanger steak was ordered medium rare, however it arrived medium. Whatever was used to season the steak was entirely too salty, especially when arrived plated with a crispy brick filled with brie, potatoes and onions. It was a healthy portion that was already cut up for me which was nice however there was brine (which I was disappointed in finding) and the flavor disappointed me. We didn't order wine but we walked out of there with a $65 tab which I suppose could have been much worse.

The service was the saving grace besides the bread with a 2 person team (one handling the bar in addition to waiting tables) and their tact and attention for a small environment.

Overall, I probably will stick to the downtown FiDi, SoMa areas for that price point and food fare.
author: Kristen R.

description:
Our favorite restaurant in San Francisco.  Intimate, unpretentious, DELICIOUS and very reasonably priced.

We brought my parents here tonight to announce our engagement and had a wonderful meal as always.  My dad is a huge lamb eater but the lamb was unavailable this time - I guess someone heard us poking fun at my dad for being disappointed about the lamb (part of a longer story - the family dog ate some very expensive lamb my mom was planning to cook for him last week) and the chef actually offered to cook him the couple pieces of lamb he did have!  We were already stuffed with delicious food and so had to decline, but I thought it was just an incredibly sweet offer and I know my dad did too.  I can't imagine having celebrated our engagement anywhere else.

I'm still stuffed from this time but can't wait to get back to The Richmond again.
author: Amanda W.

description:
This is a SF gem. The quality and creativity of the food is exceptional. I've eaten here on numerous occasions and have yet to order any dish that was less than great. 

Some great dishes:
-crab cakes
-Whisky Braised Oxtail with a Maine Diver Scallop
-Fish stew
-pork chops
-even the complimentary bread with 3 flavored butters is such a treat

The service is also fantastic with a clearly professional staff. Ambiance is intimate (especially if you get one of the front tables in the window alcoves) without excluding families and non-romantic rendezvous. 

I'm almost hesitant to write this review because I want to be able to get reservations! But the staff/chef here are so great, they deserve the great review!
author: gloria y.

description:
It's nary that I give out a five. I think I have only done it once before. The Richmond is very special though.

It is on a little block tucked into the Inner Richmond. You feel so in-the-know for even knowing about it. 

But now I'll get to the point of why it is so great. My boyfriend and I had the following for under $90 bucks:

- Amazing samples of potato leek soup that I am still thinking about
- The most fabulous bread with three home-made flavored butters (I am going to try to recreate the parsley butter at home)
-A bottle of wonderful wine--a Syrah. Even more, the waitress recommended two very good inexpensive wines, and gave us samples. We really appreciated that she did not push the expensive bottles on us. 
-The braised oxtail and seared scallop, resting on polenta, appetizer. GET THIS.
-The spinach salad with fried oyster and pancetta appetizer
- Pork loin and artisanal mac and cheese
-The most amazing seared and roasted chicken with a bread stuffing and sauteed vegetables. 
-A very memorable chocolate and peanut butter brownie with vanilla ice cream. The center of the brownie was warm and oozy.

This dinner happened three nights ago and I can still remember the details of what we ate. It was phenomenal. And my boyfriend and I hung around for an hour after dinner chatting and nobody rushed us out. 

Definitely a good spot to take your parents, a third date, or a good good friend.
author: Andrea F.

description:
Celebrated my birthday dinner here with some friends and was very happy that they chose this venue.

We ordered the tasting menu with the wine pairings which I would definitely recommend. Our selection that night included Fried Sweet Breads and I just HAD to try it. If you've never had it before, this was a nice introduction - I honestly don't think I would've enjoyed it prepared any other way.

The wine pairings went quite well with each of the courses - a great deal of care went into the choices.

The service was great - the owners, John and Thu Ha, make fantastic hosts.
author: Kristi K.

description:
I'm a hearty eater but it was the 2nd time in my life where I hardly touched my dinner. The steak was bloody and had a weird taste to it.

The pork was equally gross. Under cooked.

This is the first time that I had  fois gras. It was just too rich to eat. What idiot would eat this? Even more, the way the poor animal had to suffer so that some bourgeois can satisfy his/her palate. 

Seriously, five stars for this restaurant? gimme a break.
author: maverick s.

description:
Every single thing about this meal was great. I loved the butter spreads. The wine list. The soup was fantastic. Service was really attentive. We got the table in the front by the window (like I requested on Opentable) and it was surrounded by heavy curtains which made it seem like we had our own dining room. Every thing was great... Until the entree...

It was probably my fault anyway. I ordered a skirt steak medium to medium well. It came out super rubbery and basically inedible. The crepe that accompanied the steak was GREAT and that's what I ate, but I didn't eat the steak at all. Couldn't chew it. 

Despite that, the meal was wonderful.
author: Jen D.

description:
This restaurant totally comes out of left field and is not typical of the normal place to have dinner in The Richmond. It's a bit fancier, but MAN! This place is full of little details. 

They give you hot apple cider when you sit down and are waiting for your food, have three different kinds of butter for your bread, and the chef (John) is as modest and as kind as can be. You'll catch him serving you sometimes and even waiting on you. Nice guy. 

Their scallop and whiskey-braised oxtail starter was great. I had the manicotti for dinner, and it was excellent, but I wanted to eat 10 plates of their foie gras for dinner. Yes, TEN PLATES of it. No lie.
author: G B.

description:
The Richmond is a neighborhood place that tries very successfully to be more than that.  You can tell from the greeting upon arriving, to the three types of butter that come with the good, warm bread, to the visit you will receive from the Chef.  I had thought this place was one of the Michelin Guide's Bib Gourmand restaurants.  Apparently this is not so, but the place deserves the recognition.  

I go with a five course Prix Fixe dinner that is good value at fifty dollars.  My meal begins with a very nice beet salad that comes with well spiced carrots and a warm puff pastry filled with some cheese.   Nice contrast of textures and temperatures.  Nice any way you look at it. 

Next a generous portion of crisp veal sweetbreads with braised greens and a ravioli.  They don't downsize the portions here to Tom Thumb size.  Another nice plate of food as is the well-portioned sea bass with greens and tomatoes in a wine sauce that came next. 

The only plate that I didn't care for came next.  RIbeye was a bit on the rare side for me and I would have liked the somewhat fibrous meat to have had a bit of crispy char.  The potatoes and mushrooms that came with the steak were nice. 

An intermezzo of sorbet cleared the palate for dessert of, I think, a coffee affogato.

The place filled quickly with people from the neighborhood.  The Richmond has obviously earned a following.
author: David D.

description:
Nice to have a place in the Avenues that is serving good seasonal food, and has high-standards for their service staff.  Engaging, knowledgeable waiter.
The decor (lighting & window covers or accents) could use some attention to improve the overall ambience of the place - a little effort would make a world of difference.

Food highlights:
Scallops & oxtail over soft polenta (generous appetizer!)
Persimmon salad
Hanger steak (med. rare was a bit too rare.....serving was plenty for entree plus leftovers)

Very enjoyable at reasonable prices.
author: A S.

description:
I had insanely high expectations upon visiting The Richmond for dinner last week. It's fairly normal to have a certain level of expectation for an upscale, American-style restaurant (that comes with high ratings) since there are so many to choose from in San Francisco. But due to a few key circumstances, it was going to take more than your average 4- to 5-star experience to impress me. The pressure was on.

Key circumstance #1: It was my birthday. And if there's any one day out of the year to act like a princess and expect to be treated like a princess, this is it. And it's these years that I'd like to remember the most when I'm reading 'More' magazine and attending the Vagina Monologues on my birthday in thirty years.

Key circumstance #2: The boy was taking me to dinner. Normally such high expectations would not be put upon him (clearly, I felt lucky to have such an amazing guy to take me out) although for this particular night I'd made a couple suggestions and was knocked down--twice--for his choice, so the "yeah, this better be worth it" phrase was dancing in the back of my head. If this seems bratty, please refer to the "princess" philosophy noted in key circumstance #1.

Key circumstance #3: I had unwillingly been working from 8AM-7PM and was yearning for a relaxing, comforting and delicious, wine-inclusive experience. 

The waiter sat us at a table for 2 near the window, and although we were in the "main room" (which only has about 4 or 5 small tables in total) we felt very secluded and private. The warm low-lit atmosphere was enhanced by frosted ceramic candle holders etched with scenes of Italy at each table (available at Macy's for 50 bucks each, or to steal from the tables at Aqua, according to the waiter.) Beautiful oil/mixed media scenes of Napa Valley vineyards hung from the walls. The crowd was a late 30s and 40s mix, looked like a bunch of old friends and dates catching up and enjoying food and wine on a casual Thursday evening. 

We ordered a bottle of the Morgan 'Twelve Clones' Pinot Noir from Monterey (Santa Lucia Highlands), mostly because we liked the name and it was under 40 bones ($37). Besides the funny name, it was a great wine, served at the perfect temperature and went well with both our dishes.  Later we looked up the retail value and learned they only marked it up by $7, which was amazing that it wasn't listed as a $50 or $60 bottle, like any place could easily charge.

For starters, we shared the crab crepe over greens, and the "Happy Boys Farms" organic salad.  Crab was fresh and crepe was crispy; I probably could have eaten 8 more. Salad was extremely simple, although I'm not sure I would have added anything else. Wish they sold bottles of the light herby dressing the greens were mixed with. Although in my opinion, the best starter (and accompaniment to our meal) was free. The warm, crunchy french bread and variety of butter was a surprisingly delightful treat. Among the 3 kinds of buttery goodness was an olive tapenade, euro-style with sea salt, and chive and parsley (my fav) sampling. 

Next up, I ordered the hangar steak that came with red potatoes infused with goat cheese over greens. I asked for medium rare, and I got it. It was beef-tastic, and along with the cheesy potatoes, rich and flavorful. Portion size was surprisingly substantial, I gave the boy almost half and was still quite full. The boy got the crispy cod with beans and I think it came with rice. To be honest, I was so obsessed with my dish I can't recall the full details of his--I had a couple bites but it wasn't enough to distract me enough from my dish, or ask for more.

At dessert time, it was a toss up between the panna cotta and a warm, gooey chocolate and peanut butter brownie cake thing served with creamy vanilla ice cream. We went with the latter, and it was a good choice. For my birthday, the waiter came out and melted the bottom tip of the candle and stuck to the side of the plate. I'd never seen this done before, and thanked him (not only for the candle but not sticking that piece of wax in my sweet dish, god forbid I mistake candlewax for the flavor of the chocolate).

Despite all the circumstances, and my judgmental, uncompromising attitude, this place blew me away, I would have given it 6 stars if I could, as the atmosphere, service, food, and price (I'm sure you can have a similar experience in excellence at an establishment that will cost you twice as much). On the downside, I think my meal ruined my ability to enjoy good steak anywhere else for a least a couple months.
author: Kelly R.

description:
What an absolute hidden gem this is!

If you go in early enough you don't need reservations, but the place is pretty small so you may not want to chance it later in the evenings!  It so cozy and intimate.  The servers are so friendly and attentive and if you're lucky you might even get a seat by the window that is sort of in a nook!  The breads are delicious and they are served with three different types of butters (which are so tasty and such a nice twist on butter).

I always get the burger and some wine and some sort of appetizer.  Their burger and fries are delicious, but this past week I ordered the crab crepe to start with and WOW!  I wish I could have eaten ONE MILLION of them - and yes, it was THAT serious!

If you haven't been and you live near by you must try it!  But shhhh...don't tell too many people!
author: Jennifer H.

description:
Run by hubby & wife team that know their cuisine and fine wines in addition to sporting uber personable service. Though we didn't have a rezy and arrived closer to closing, we were welcomed pleasantly and catered to well past everybody's bed time. 

The chef is a wine lover, renovating parts of the space to accommodate what must be an ever growing selection to accompany his deep knowledge.  We were drinking something I would never expect to see being poured by the glass, much less on a restaurant's wine list: Ahlgren Cabernet. The winery is a Santa Cruz Appellation mom & pop wine making duo that make robust, complex, earthy wines. The chef personally comes to each table to make sure everyone is enjoying the experience. Fun Chef Fact: At the end of the night he prefers pizza or Jack-in-the-Box. 

The head waiter has worked at practically every restaurant in San Francisco, which is reflected in his ability to lead you to a menu choice accompanying your taste or mood. All the ingredients are from local purveyors. Menu highlights: Beet & Carrot Salad; Pork Loin Mac & Cheese; bread served w/ varying flavors of butter and sea salt; and a Not to be missed Pana Cotta.

In this neighborhood restaurants tend to come and go, but with the museum nearby, delicious cuisine, The Richmond -like the city fog- is here to stay.
author: Johnny C.

description:
A well-earned, high 4 stars.  A party of 15, we ordered lots of food and 10 bottles of wine.  Everyone was very happy with everything, I think.

Rave reviews:
foie gras on pain perdu
panna cotta
pop tart
ecole 41 apogee

High marks:
hanger steak with brie/pancetta blintz

They serve great bread (I really mean it -- it's great) with three nice butters.  They keep the bread coming.  The unexpected amuse, a creamy leek soup, was way too creamy for me, but super comforting on a blustery august evening.  The chicken + ravioli with truffle sauce was very good, but I couldn't make out the truffle; it tasted more mushroomy than truffles.  The chicken itself was excellent, and the chicken ravioli filling was too much tougher chicken, I think, but the pasta had a great toughness to it.  

Portions are large.  Service is great.  The chef/owner was very accommodating and stopped by often to make sure everything was good.
author: Joe H.

description:
Confused Americano cuisine.   And I'm not saying that in a bad way.

It's almost American with a twist.  Somehow you can't really put a finger on it - the menu looks somewhat American but yet, there's not quite the commitment to what sister fusionary cuisine it integrates with.

First, minus one star for the real slow snail service.  Perhaps it was a Tuesday night and they had one server.  I'll give them the benefit of the doubt because the place was crowded.  He definitely got slammed.  But evenso, 10 minutes later while seated he finally comes with bread.  No salutation, just 'what are you having'.  Eh, again, he was probably slammed, so I'm giving them the benefit of the doubt.

Hot bread, three butters (regular salted, olive, and cilantro?)  - very unique.  So were the complementary deviled eggs.  Freebies are always nice.  Again, another 5 minutes before my wine came.  It's not hard to pour.

Ok, you gotta get the oxtail app.  That was delicious.  Small, pungent, hearty, and alive.  The Maine scallops, though small, were sweet and seared to perfection - the middle was still raw (perfect).  The oxtail was removed from the bone and it was softly stewed to tenderness.  The polenta (I think) and the wine reduction were complex.   The organic salad was nothing to write to home about.

The hangar steak looked really really good.  It came with a bread sized fried wonton / egg roll that had potatoes and other herbs in it.  Kinda like a French samosa.  It was good.  The hangar steak tasted really good.  Nice sized portion - 3 or 4 large fillets.  But one major no no.  It was cold.  I mean, like 'Clemens sitting at the same table as McNamee' cold.  I think what may have happened was that they waited for my entree to cook before bringing the steak out.  Bad news - minus one star.  I had the Arctic grilled char which was fantastic.  It was like if a cod and a salmon had a baby.  Light and flaky but not too salmony.  Even the color was a light red.   Skin on grilled with herbs lampin' on a large dob of mashed potatoes (very creamy and good) showered with those fish hat mushrooms.  The schrooms were probably first steamed/boiled then lightly blackened.  Delicious.

Not a bad touch that the owner you see on the website comes out to check on you.

The atmosphere was hazy - lots of soft and dark textures.  Had that upscale soul food joint like the old Powell's in Hayes valley - hardwood floors, dull and generic colorful paintings, and high ceilings.  Great place for good friends or a romantic date.  No loud music, patrons dined courteously, and it did seem very exclusive.  The flatware was superb, cloth napkins were nice, and eye-pleasing professional glassware were charming.  

Dessert was cheesecake with a raspberry puddle.  It was good, light, and sold as home-made.  It was good.  The coffee was fantastic.   Hot and generous as they left a handsome silver coffee pitcher on the table - YOU get to control the coffee.  NICE TOUCH.

The owners and servers were all very warm and caring.  Most patrons looked like they've been here before or are actually regulars, as they were on first named basis with the owner.  At one point, I saw the owner (in his chef attire) sit down and share a glass of wine.

This place is definitely worth another look.  If the service was more attentive and the food actually warm, it'd run a 4.5 star, hands down.  But let's keep it real.
author: Isaac L.

description:
You know what... this place deserves 5 stars. It's not fancy shmancy like downtown places, the restaurant is small, and parking is minimal. But really those are the only things to complain about. 

Their food is top notch and sophisticated. Chef/owner John Owyang does a great job of keeping it simple, while delivering high quality gourmet experiences. Their menu is diverse for carnivores and vegetarians alike. You must absolutely get the whiskey braised oxtail with seared diver scallop over polenta appetizer. You heard me correctly... all that yummy goodness was offered in an appetizer for only $9.95. That brings me to my second point... their prices are amazing. You get huge portions for VERY GOOD PRICES. Their wine selection is pretty amazing for such a small restaurant and there are a couple really good values in there (I'm not telling which ones). To top it all off, the chef personally came to our table and spoke with us for several minutes about the menu, his philosophy, and cooking techniques. 

The Richmond... what a place!!! We must continue to support this restaurant and keep awesome neighborhood places like this open.
author: Arick R.

description:
The Richmond feels like it's not sure what it wants to be.  Is it a nice neighborhood restaurant or a higher end destination place?  The food was good but not as good as the price suggests.  I had the crab crepe to start - I didn't really like it because it had potatoes in it even though it didn't say in the description.  My entree was the pork loin, my friend had fish.  The loin was solid but not amazing, same with the fish.  The wine list looked pretty good but by the glass selections were a little wanting.  The decor could use some work (FYI., the waiter said they had just finished a major remodeling and were still finishing up) and the tables were a little cramped.  

Overall, I rate this as a good but not outstanding restaurant.  If I lived in the neighborhood  I would come occasionally and give it 4 stars.
author: matt d.

description:
when i was a kid in massachusetts, the neighborhood rugrats and i would ride our bikes to friendly's.  we would order one sundae between the five or six of us and sit there for hours, ordering water after water (i didn't grow up in a very affluent neighborhood).  we would be as obnoxious as possible, yelling, snorting water out of our noses, rough housing and doing everything we could to look like the complete morons that we were.  until someone in an official collared shirt and a name tag would come over and kick us out- telling us not to come back without our parents.  

the richmond not only put up with me and my sister in law's obnoxious behavior, they seemed almost refreshed by it.  our waiter laughed at my stupid jokes, indulged my annoying questions and loud complaints about the music (i hate steely dan) and managed to ignore the dirty looks from the stuffy whities sitting around us.  i kept waiting for someone to tell me to leave and not come back unless i was with my parents.  but seeing as how i was with my in laws, i guess they decided to let me stay.  

and boy oh boy am i glad i stayed.  cause we did the chef's menu and it was fabulous.  every sauce, every veggie and every protein was perfect.  it was a great meal.  so great, in fact, that during the meal i was pretty well behaved, due to being so absorbed by the flavors.  

that's the sign of a great meal.  a meal that gets me to just shut up, stop fooling around and just enjoy.
author: Katie H.

description:
One of my girlfriend and my favorite gems in the city along with Baker and Banker. Amazingly charming decor, and one of the nicest staffs we have ever come across. All three times they were super friendly, efficient and honest about the menu (politely steered us away from one dish and to another he though was better that night). 

Food was really great all three times, and I highly recommend the oxtail. The most impressive aspect may be the insanely well priced and well selected wine list. Fairly small, but well thought out with some cult favorites like Bond and Ramey, but very affordable, as was the Paul Hobbs Pinot, which at $77 in a restaurant, is a steal. In fact, for the quality of the service and the food, the prices are incredibly fair. I will certainly be back again soon. Well Done!!
author: brant f.

description:
I have had this place on my "need to try" list since they opened years ago. Finally had the opportunity and they had availability for a last minute reservation for our party. 

It was a really cozy place with the wife managing the dining area and the husband in the kitchen. The service was attentive but the kitchen could have been a bit quicker as it took longer than expected to put something in my tummy. Thank goodness for the bread (would have preferred it warm) and flavored butters. 

Amuse Bouche: Fig w/ poached quince and yogurt 

Appies: 
- Whisky Braised Oxtail w/ Maine Diver Scallops on creamy Polenta.......great combo 
- Scallion Flat Bread Sloppy-Joe with whipped goat cheese......flavors were great and portion was great for the group 
- Fried Oysters Spinach Salad w/ bacon and Russian dressing......it was perfect and the dressing was tomato-ish but so good 

Main: 
- Seared Hanger Steak w/ a crispy crepe (filo flaky dough) filled with pancetta, potato, onion fennel & Brie.....ONLY way to order this is med-rare b/c the medium will turn out to be medium well and too tough to swallow 
- Braised Monk Fish w/ heirloom tomatoes, white wine, & oyster mushrooms....juicy and light made perfectly with the seasonal veggies 
- Roast Pork Tenderloin with Macaroni & Cheese and Veggies.......this is a hearty dish that could have been better cooked med than well done 

Dessert: 
-Creamy Panna Cotta with Raspberry sauce.....not too sweet and the tartness from the sauce was paired nicely with the panna cotta. I had to fight to get a spoonful....yes, that good. 

Overall, we were stuffed by the end of the meal and I fell in love with the restaurant. Who wants to take me there again for the 5 Course Tasting Menu?
author: Katie K.

description:
Wow, what a gem!  The food and service blew me away- all in a wonderfully intimate setting.

The Richmond was a suggestion at the Fun Committee meeting at work.  We met to begin preparation for our Staff Appreciation Luncheon for 45 people.  I called and spoke directly with the chef and owner, John Owyang.  He was very courteous and to my pleasant surprise, he offered a tasting.  What a nice change from working with restaurants that hardly give a shit about your business.  ahem:::Magic Flute:::ahem

The tasting was AMAZING.  In chronological order:

-amuse bush of creamy potato leek soup- everything you love about it.
-cesar salad- standard and always delicious.
-bread with three types of butter: chive, sea salt, olive- so warm and fresh!
-white wine (I seriously can't remember the types of wine we sampled...sorry!)
-yellow split pea with bacon crumbles- so creamy that it makes my mouth water at this very moment.
-braised oxtail and scallop on creamy polenta- Incredible!  If I had a last meal, this would be present.
-white wine
-seared yellowtail with oyster mushrooms- very fresh and perfectly seasoned.
-red wine
-seared hanger steak on phyllo dough filled with brie and pancetta- seasoned well and a huge portion.
-chocolate marquise- if you love chocolate, you will love this!
-fresh cream panna cotta- smooth and creamy with a touch of lemon tartness.

I have to mention that between each course, the staff reset all of our silverware and removed all the crumbs from the table- such great service!  On that note, The Richmond is only open for dinner but exclusively for our party, John Owyang opened for lunch.  I also have to admit that I missed some entrees from the tasting- it was a lot of food!  Let's just say that I remembered the great ones! 

I have been here about 5 times and it always impresses me.  The food is always comforting and the service is extraordinary.

P.S. Parking is a little tough, so I would suggest taking a cab or the bus.  Also, for a large party, I would say that it would only fit about 38-40 in the main dining room.  Lastly, the fried chicken is THE BEST!!!
author: Teena O.

description: It is a pretty small place, but the food and wine are excellent. Also be sure to have a reservation, due to the limited seating.
author: Kevin K.

description: Went here with my friends last month based off of the reviews from yelp. Orders crab cake salad and hanger steak with brick filled with Brie. Food was great. Nice atmosphere and good service. At the end of our meal the owner/chef came out to thank us for supporting his business.
author: Sheenie L.

description:
Went here for dinner while my mom was in town, which was nice because this place is too expensive for me normally.

The food was very good. Didn't totally blow me away, but it was still very good. It feels like your typical new american style restaurant to me. Small portions that are pretty pricey. I got the steak and it was a-mazing. It was almost buttery and basically melted in my mouth. Really good. The environment was pretty cool, they partition you off with these velvet curtains if you get one of the good tables. I would recommend eating here if you're looking for a classy place in the inner Richmond and are will to spend a little extra cash.

Oh also, not open on Sundays FYI.
author: Jonathan H.

description:
Mmm - just left here.

Pretty slow on a Friday night; I suppose the drawback of location.  But it's great that we could walk in at 9pm & get a table with no wait!

The service was Lovely, definitely on the casual side, but very friendly & knowledgable.  It's nice to see there were families there as well - added rather than detracted from the ambiance (&I hate kids).  It managed to balance friendly/neighborhood & intimate. 

I would qualify the food as very good, but not mind blowing.  highlights included the potato leek soup w/ a truffle oil garnish, the ravioli sauce (salsa?), and the panna cotta.  The wine list was great as well and they clearly take care of their bottles.

I appreciate the in house nature of the dishes.  I had the chicken & mashed potatoes, which was literally swimming in gravy - not my favorite way to eat.  The potatoes were good & mushrooms had wonderful flavor.  The chicken was tender enough to fall apart & flavor was kept in with the skin remaining.  The bacon wrapping was unfortunately soggy, probably due to the abundance of gravy/sauce.  If I have something bacon wrapped, I like the bacon to be slightly crisp.
BF had mushroom/sausage ravioli which had a suprising kick in the sauce or filling (I couldn't tell from one bite).  Nothing major, but I am glad I didn't get it as I planned; I am not a fan of heat in my food.  The ravioli filling was nice, the ravioli seemed a little too al dente for my taste.  BF finished it all off though.
Coffee was amazing!  Rich & dark - mmm.  Dessert was delectable.

Overall a very good experience & I'd return to try some of the other fare, but I would be sure to ask questions about the preparation etc.
One other nick - the online menu is not up to date & I was really looking forward to foie gras! :(  For others culinarily inclined, sweetbreads seem to be the foodie replacement on the apps.
author: laura g.

description: I thoroughly enjoyed dinner here with my fiancee the night before we moved out of San Francisco. We went late in the evening on a Wednesday and received attentive and enthusiastic service. Our waiter graciously arranged and presented wine pairing selections to match our appetizer and entree selections (even though we weren't ordering off the fixed course menu, for which the standard wine pairing accompaniment was specified). The short rib and scallops over polenta appetizer was the best part of my meal, but the duck entree that followed was also excellent. Overall a fantastic experience and the perfect way to celebrate the bittersweet moment of leaving town ...
author: Wesley M.

description:
Went here for an anniversary dinner.  The restaurant is super cute and romantic but the service and some of the food were not so great.  We made a reservation though it was completely unnecssary since the place was empty the whole time we were there.  I think this worked as a disadvantage for us because we were being eyed the whole meal by the chef.  He seated us.  Then he came by when bread was put on the table by our server to ask, "You guys have been here before, right?"  We hadn't and we told our server that when he asked us 5 minutes earlier.  The chef brought out a complimentary amuse bouche which was a little odd tasting (fig and cream cheese) but nice because it was free.  The whole time the boy and I are talking and trying to enjoy the evening, the chef was standing there, looking at us.  So uncomfortable. 

I got the seared tuna.  It was ok but nothing special and I didn't care much for the super heavy cream sauce all over it.  The chef came by to ask how everything was.  We told him it was all great and he walked away.  I ate half of my dish since I was full from the appetizers and wanted to take the rest home.  The chef came by again to ask if I was SURE I liked everything as he nodded over to my half full plate.  Seriously, there's attentive service and there's overbearing slightly creepy service.  This was creepy.  

I felt kind of bad for our server because a)  he was actually very pleasant, knowledgeable and just the right amount of attentive and b) we were his only table for at least 2 hours.  So sad that the chef made the dining experience so weird.  I might give it another try, maybe when it's busier so the chef can occupy himself with asking other diners strange questions and, oh I don't know, COOKING.
author: M M.

description:
I have to say, this cute little find in "the Richmond" district is just a gem.  We practically tried the entire menu last night and was not disappointed in a single dish.

We had...

Cheese Selection (beautifully decorated)
Foie Gras - seared with poached pear bits
Corn Beef and Hash - excellent dish with poached egg on top
Pounder Hamburger with the best ketchup ever and shoe string fries
Hanger Steak that melts in your mouth; and potatoes covered in cheese

The chef came out after-wards and greeted everyone at the table.  What can I say but this charming place has the equivalent of good food found from any expensive establishment with friendly hospitality.

I think this place is such a good try and not too expensive either! We'll be back...
author: Alice H.

description:
We were a party 11 (including a 9 month old and a 4 year old).  They didn't have a kids menu but were thoughtful to suggest serving the ravioli plain with butter.  

Dinner reservation was at 6pm and we didn't get our main course til 8pm.  The chef was kind enough to send 3-4 appetizer plates for us so we weren't starving which was perfectly fine by us. A nice leisurely meal with good friends is never a bad thing.  We had the following appetizers: whisky braised oxtail with Maine diver scallop, Sloppy Joe's, salad with pear vinegarette dressing and carpaccio.  Oh, we ate several plates of their warm crispy French bread with flavored spreads - tapenade, pesto butter and salted butter.  I had their rib eye steak special.  It was all delicious.  

They sat us in the back and had curtains to cover us partially although we accidentally kept bumping into the people on the other side of the curtains.  They had 2 other seating areas that can be fully covered by the curtains for privacy.  

One odd thing was they kept putting the food on the main table (they split us in a table of 6 and 4).  We had to keep reaching over to get the bread.  We brought in several mini cupcakes for the birthday boy which they brought out with candles.  We also ordered several of their desserts which sadly didn't have room in my belly after all the food and wine.
author: Kaye M.

description:
Love The Richmond.  Any place that starts off the meal with a warm loaf of French bread and three choices of butter (mushroom, sea salt, and olive?, that's not right but memory fails) would have to really try to mess it up after that.   The burger is perfect and they have Trumer Pils on tap.  That is often enough of a meal, but you can def. go the full three course if you want.  The soup is always outstanding.  The menu is seasonal, and only changes with the seasons, but it is almost all delicious.  Very friendly service, and the chef usually comes around to check on everything.  Wine list is nice, and nicely priced.  I've compared several of the bottles we've had there with other restaurants and The Richmond is always priced better.  
Desserts are the only somewhat weak point for me.  They are ok, but I've never felt like I had to order one again.   Great French press coffee though.
author: Kean S.

description: One of our favorites.  We found this place after going to several, in a row it seemed, loud, like decible earing burning loud, restaurants over a period of a few weeks.  My husband's birthday was coming up and all he requested was "somewhere quiet".  I found this one and what a pleasure.  You can whisper across the table at each other, the wait staff is impeccable and attentive.  Small so very intimate and the food is very well thought out as well as beautifully presented.  Great little neighborhood find and we'll go back again.
author: Linda M.

description: The food was good here but the server was incredibly rude.  He lectured us on making a reservation, but then proceeded to give us one of the free tables comprising half of the restaurant.  He didn't mention until we already tried to order that the two things we wanted were no longer available.  Acting as though we tried to walk into a 5 star restaurant on a Friday night, instead of a $18 a plate venue on a Tuesday... he practically rolled his eyes at us.  If I lived anywhere in the area I would definitely not return.
author: Meg F.

description:
I've been wanting to eat here since it opened (being so close to my house and all), and finally got a chance a couple of weeks ago on a really rainy Saturday night.  First off, parking in this neighborhood is terrible.  Since I live so close, I could walk, but luckily for Hue L. and our non-yelper friend, they didn't have to look for parking and just parked in my driveway.  Our reservations were for 8pm, but we had to wait maybe 15 minutes by the tiny bar.  Apparently, there was a birthday party that night that was taking up 3 tables and there were 2 other tables that just wouldn't leave.  The owner did offer each of us a glass of wine (on the house) to compensate though.  The place is super tiny and poor Hue L. kept getting in the way of the waiters.  

As for the food, we started with the Seared Sonoma Fois Grois, which was good, although I think we actually liked the bread with the 3 different varieties of spreads better.  I don't remember what Hue L. or or our non-yelper friend had for their entree, but I had the Whisky Braised Oxtail with Maine Diver Scallops.  The oxtail was very tender and I really love scallops so I had no complaints about that.  We all split the chocolate cake for dessert.  The menu says it needs 20 minutes to make, but I don't remember having to wait so long.

The entire dinner took a couple hours and I could see how the place can get busy, but one of the waiters told us that they're planning on expanding their space in the near future.  I guess business is doing well!
author: Kris L.

description:
My first time here, and I'll be back!

The Bread
Came with 3 different spreads, all home made and/or enhanced.

The Seared Artisan Foie Gras
Fatty liver heaven.  I imagined my own liver tasting like this.

The House Ground Half-Pound Cheeseburger & French Fries 
This was the best $9.95 medium-rare Cheeseburger I've ever had.  The Schubert's Bakery bun held up nicely as the fat from the burger McCadam Cheddar cheese came through it.  Again, the condiments came home made - the fries were fresh cut from the potato.  My OWN preference - I prefer the greasy, crinkle cut Ore-Ida type...

Roast Pork Tenderloin with Macaroni & Cheese
Again, wonderfully done.  Each slice of pork was tender.  Slightly pinkish inside.  The slices that weren't pinkish were STILL tender.

The Flourless Chocolate Peanut Butter Torte
The Torte was injected with a "teaser" of peanut butter, presented at a highly heated temperature, with a scoop of vanilla ice cream by its side.  Most chocolate + peanut butter desserts have been either too sweet, or had too much PB in it.  Having that teaser of PB is something I'll have to try when cooking myself.

+ The chef came out to the tables to make sure everything was okay.
+ A great tiny bathroom with nice modern fixtures.
+ A friendly small staff.
+ Decent presentation for each course.

- I do enjoy eclectic mellow music, but some of it was too off the wall and at times, a little irritating.  Try slowing down the tempo and turn the volume down a notch or two lower.  If you want to keep it strange though,you might be able to get away with the sad stuff... http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iuUYZJuzie0
-  The Richmond has too many surrounding businesses that makes it a bit more difficult to find parking.  How about moving to the Outer Richmond?
- The prices for the culinary orgasm are decent, yet the portion sizes were "proportionally" lower.  Minimalist sizes for each course.

Regardless of the complaints, I am definitely returning.  Everything was fantastic with attention to flavor.
author: D. A.

description:
My favorite restaurant in my neighborhood, Richmond. (Maybe alittle biased, but hey, you can get $$$ meal for less pricing. Why not five stars??)

The inside is very cozy. I took my food snob friend here before I leave San Francisco. (I had to tell him that I was in a restaurant whose hamburger is very famous when I got a phone call from him at McDonald's.) And he was happy with the dishes. 

It's very quiet and cozy ambience. Their bread, butter, and starter soup were all delicious and delightful. 

I ordered diver's sea scallop for appetizer followed by roasted chicken with Mac & Cheese. They were both excellent. 

Overall, I had very nice experience with my friend at The Richmond before I left San Francisco, so that I give five stars with thankfulness. I'll miss this place as I miss this neighborhood.
author: Masa O.

description:
I went here with my room mate to celebrate and was so impressed with this place.  You look at the Richmond and it appears very unassuming and cozy.  You walk into a smallish doorway are seated by the most walk on air fabulous waiter | host ever-ever who takes care of the entire place as though it were his orphanage of finely tuned hunger to appease.

We sit down and order a cheese plate and some wine.  The waiter not only makes suggestions and actually describes the palette of the wine accurately.  We get a 747 sized plate of delicious bread with various butters to go with it.  The bread, I believe is homemade and gorgeous.  If my memory has not yet been peppered with Alzheimer's I believe we had truffle butter, parsley butter and some orange butter that was not citrus, but orange in color.  We are told that if we look at everything like we were in coach, that the plates and everything will fit miraculously on the table.

I got grilled, marinated duck atop polenta and roasted autumn vegetables.  The wine pairing was so perfect, I feel the pretention oozing from my pores as I write about it AND I don't give a flaming hint , undertone or note about it.  :)  

With severe arm twisting I was convinced to share a raspberry panna cotta with a lovely girl and before I left the chef came out to make sure everything was okay.  

Wow!  Did you hear what I just said?  

The chef came out to see if the duck was cooked to my liking, how was my meal?

I am so taking a date back there.
That was great.
author: Gwen P.

description:
Four solid stars for value and service.

You're almost surprised by the price.  The food is comfortable and satisfying, like mom's finest cooking.  Only in this case, mom went to culinary school and somehow made Sloppy Joe's seem like a delicatessen.

We celebrated K's birthday here last night and had to write an entry fast.

For appetizers, we had the Sloppy Joe's on flat bread.  The scallion is an interesting twist on this old favorite.  We'd come back just for this one dish.

For entrees, K had the pork loin with mac 'n cheese (Gruyere).  A had the chicken roti (fried chicken a la cuisine).  Both very tasty dishes.  The pork loin was very tender.  Chef Owyoung really made the taste stay in the meat-- you don't even need a complementary sauce.  The chicken was also very good.  A little salty, but it was perfect for A.

Parking is a bit difficult around this area, but the price is incredible.  Value like this is VERY hard to find in the city and we are value-snobs.  

Weekdays are a bit light at this semi-new place, so if you have free time, we recommend spending $30/person on a very satisfying meal.  It's still a hidden gem so stop by before this place gets hot.
author: Kel S.
