description: My favorite neighborhood restaurant, although people come from all over to eat here - the food is that good. I always leave stuffed and have to be rolled home. The oxtail is my favorite, but everything here is delicious. Which reminds me, I really need to make reservations...
author: Eric H.

description:
Cute little place, great food. Extensive wine list. Went for my birthday, and the chef himself came out and gave me a dessert on the house. Unfortunately, I was so stuffed from the meal I could only finish half of it! Will return for sure! 

The price for food wasn't bad, we just had a bunch of wine which is why I gave it 3 $ signs....
author: Michelle L.

description:
The Fiancee went for her makeup and hair test run and came home all made-up so we couldn't waste it on french dip sandwiches and whatever we had on Tivo, so we decided to go to Sushi Bistro.  I called and the guy said no reservation necessary but then when we arrived the waiting area was full, people were outside waiting and the line was 3 deep to talk to the host.

So we decided to head to The Richmond.  Incidentally, we had reservations for The Richmond on Saturday (our Valentines - because F going out on real Valentines).  So we just did Valentines a few days early.

We both did the tasting menu with the wine pairing and were blown away.  Every single course and wine was excellent.  Mid-way through dinner I said, "Well you have your neighborhood Gary Denkos now."  Reply was, "Yeah, no joke".  Of course that was in jest but only partially...The Richmond can really hold its own as one of the better restaurants in the city.  I could only imagine if it were in Soma or Downtown, it would be slammed all the time.  Thank God it is where it is... ;-)

We will definitely be back...often!
author: Aberdo G.

description:
I had a fabulous meal here the other night. Three fabulous people (who I'm lucky to call friends) and I were tucked away into one of the front rooms for a very intimate setting. The chef spoke to us a couple of times, and was very polite. Mostly we had a nice setting with delicious meals. Everything from the wine to chef's tasting starter sip of soup to the apps and the mains... I had a good size piece of sea bass that was perfectly cooked! And don't get me started on the manicotta. oh yum.
The only suggestions I would make for the owners would be: more veggie-friendly food, updated menus online (add the wine and dessert menus!) and advertise. 
Seriously! This place is a gem in my beloved neighborhood, and worth the drive from other spots. Very good. And worth a try,... or several=)
author: Tiffany M.

description:
The menu and reviews made this spot look very interesting.  Tuesday night we got there are 6:00 and were seated promptly.  The presentation and timing was perfect.  I loved the beet salad and had the pork chop for the main.
Yes, we tried the wonderful desserts and everyone was happy.  It is a must if you are in the area and want a treat.
author: GREG C.

description:
What a neighborhood treasure! Intimate ambiance, simple decor, and great food.

Despite making the rounds from Geary to Balboa in search of a walkable parking spot, the Richmond is the perfect  place for a quiet, weekday dinner. Went with a couple girlfriends for a birthday and had the following:

Braised Short Ribs with Potato and Celery Root Puree- good size portion(slightly on the fatty side for me) but still slipped right of the bone

Hangar Steak with Crepe- Seasoned well, not so sure about the crepe though. Seemed more like a glorified, french inspired eggroll

Chocolate Torte- Everyone does a chocolate souffle/cake/tart dessert served with ice cream/gelato/whipped cream. What make the Richmond's exceptional is that salty peanut butter surprise inside. Who knew a little Jif could do the trick?

Overall, attentive service, clean flavors, and local ingredients. Great place to take your parents or a second date. Make sure to turn the Parking Karma or better yet cab it.
author: Rachelli M.

description:
My girlfriend and I made an inaugural stopover recently and were generally impressed. The service was a little slow and uneven, but the food was very good to excellent. We had the seared foie gras (a moderate portion at $16, should have come with more toast), a salad, and two portions of arctic char. Arctic char is a rarely seen salmon-like freshwater trout and I was excited to find it in SF. It was prepared with a seared crust and soft, juicy flesh - not overcooked. Based on this one sample I'd tentatively say the chef knows how to cook fish, which is a rarity.

The wine list is large for such a small place (30-40 seats) and there is a wide selection of inexpensive under $30 bottles.

The bread came out slowly (at least 10 minutes) although the salad and foie gras followed relatively quickly thereafter.

The presentation of the foie gras and our entrees was awkward - the foie gras came on a large clear plate that was actually a little hard to see (where do I put my fork?). Not sure what the idea there is. The fish was served with no veg or starch and was a little difficult to eat - it was moist and slippery and kind of hard to get a fork on at times. It would have been nice to have pilaf or a higher rim on a smaller plate to push the meat against.

Gordon Ramsay would appreciate the small menu - roughly a half dozen starters and a half dozen entrees. I suspect that the restaurant may be regularly understaffed. However, with relatively simple dishes it might be slow on a busy night but shouldn't become a complete meltdown.

A final note - I understand that some people think it's nice to hear personally from the chef, but I don't. He served our appetizer and appeared a couple of other times in the dining area. I think that during service hours, the chef's time is usually best spent in the kitchen.

Anyway - food, excellent. Service, good. Glitches to work out. We will go back and perhaps it could become a regular stop.
author: Joseph H.

description:
A little gem of a restaurant. I've always passed by this place on walks in my neighborhood and was curious about it. Finally my boyfriend's mother took us and his brother. 

The ambiance is quite nice, with deep red curtains draping the doorways. The servers were very attentive and knowledgeable about the food. I had the arctic char. The bf and his brother had the roast pork tenderloin with and their mother had the hangar steak with the "brick-dough" crepe filled with pancetta, potato, onion fennel & Brie. The bread came with three different types of homemade butters!

We were pretty satisfied with our food. It was very good and was obviously prepared from fresh and quality ingredients. The chef even came out to see if everything was alright. The attentive service, good food and lovely atmosphere make this place worth going to. My only qualm is that I wish they would expand on their small menu.
author: Helena H.

description: What a Gem!  I just moved in around the corner and did a quick yelp search for good restaurants in the area.  This place seemed to be getting a lot of reviews for a random inner richmond spot, so we decided to check it out.  I would highly recommend this place, even if you don't live nearby.  It is definitely worth the trek.  The food was amazing, but more than that the service is what is makes this place unique.  Our waitress was great, and although we basically only waited 1 minute for our table, they apologized and gave us some extra wine and appetizers "complements of the chef."  The chef even came out later to check on everyone!   I had the steak and my guy had the lamb.  They were both amazing.  I will be coming back here... as often as I can justify.
author: Erin D.

description:
It was a dark and stormy night...which is to say, a regular evening in an El Nino year winter in San Francisco. Windy, wet, musty - the perfect evening for a savory squash soup. 
But I was grumpy and had nothing in the kitchen, and I didn't want to cook.  So what did I do?  I called every restaurant I could think that might have some kind of squash soup.  Firefly - nope potato chedder. Zazie - nope, tomato eggplant. Q Cafe - bluh - italian sausage.
Then lo & behold, in a blind search on Yelp for what Firefly was labeled as - "American (New)" - what the hell does THAT mean? - I found a hit - The Richmond.  And they had a pumpkin puree soup with toasted pumpkin seeds. DING DING DING DING!!
And it was perfect - rich, savory, sweet, hot, with crunchy texture contrast from the seeds.  The other menu offerings looked very promising too, though not super extensive - maybe 5-6 options for apps or entrees. American (New) looked a lot like old French, with a sprinkling of other influences.   
'Course I had to be persnickety and decide the one thing I wanted to try was off their 5-course tasting menu. Not having worn stretchy pants, or wanting to spend $55 - I bugged the waiter to see if they'd let me order the sweetbread course a la carte.  Being a quiet night with the rain dropping outside - they were chill about it and served me up some perfectly seared pieces basted in a rich gravy & accompanied by wilted greens and a ravioli.  It. Was. Excellent.
Funny how a good meal can just make a crappy evening totally disappear from mind. And the quiet neighborhood is so much more accessible than other heavier dine-out areas.  It's shaping up to be a looong winter, too, so I'm going to enjoy being a regular here.
author: CINDY K.

description:
Love this place! Hardly get a chance to eat out here just because there's sooooooo many good restaurants in the city that I still haven't been to. So going back here a couple times that means something!! It's always nice of them to leave a couple spots open for walk-ins like dummies like us. We just took a chance and we were able to be seated. The first time I went here was about 2 years ago when it was FRESH on the list! I still remember that the chef came out and chatted with everyone checking on the food, it's nice when they do that, not saying they weren't busy, but they took the time to get to know their patrons. Great find for Richmond, the food..well whatever you order you will ot regret it. I think we've ordered everything off the menu and there were only 6 of us! hahaha

Intimate and savy! Try them!
author: Judi K.

description:
Pleasantly pleased after selecting this place based on Yelp reviews. I met my cousin here for dinner. We had a party of five (woot! Matthew Fox!) and not a disappointed one in the bunch. Sang (did I spell that correctly?) is a great guy! Fantastic wine, food and space...really good music, too!!

I like a menu that's not overwhelming. The choices were right on. Props for a menu *sans* chicken!
author: Jenna H.

description:
Second birthday dinner of the week with my sister, found it on OpenTable.com and decided to give it a try.  Upon entering, we were seated promptly, even though we were late for our reservation.  The area we were seated in was very cozy so it'd be nice for a date or a group of four.  Service was great, waiter was very attentive and paid attention to when we needed more time/privacy.

My sister and I shared the soft shell crab salad, which I really liked.  I had the halibut and my sister had the artic char.  My halibut was okay, I wished the outside was seared more for crispier texture and wished the inside wasn't cooked as much.  It wasn't moist/juicy enough.  The flavoring was also lacking, nothing stood out.  It was served with a 'rice-o-roni' type side and that was only ok, it really tasted like the rice-o-roni from the box.  Make this a risotto and we'd be in good business.  The arctic char was better, the sear on the outside was crispy and flavorful.  The mushrooms served with it was also tasty, although some were really salty.  We didn't order desert, so the verdict's still out on that.  We both ordered coke and it came in the glass bottle (old-fashioned kind).  It was cold and fizzy, just the way I like it.

Overally, the food wasn't that impressive but the service and restaurant was very nice but I'm not sure if I'd recommend it or go back.
author: Winnie L.

description: Delicious!  One of our favorite places for a great dining experience.  The atmosphere is quiet and classy, the owners, chef & waiters are warm and friendly and the food is fresh & simple, yet complex.  I would recommend the Richmond to my closest family & friends.
author: SFgal Z.

description:
The Richmond is a simple but refined white tablecloth restaurant.  It has a casual, comfortable vibe and is relatively quiet, even when filled to capacity.

This is the sort of neighborhood restaurant you'd expect to find in Pacific Heights or maybe the grown-up end of the Marina.  The food is natural Franco-California/San Francisco cuisine:  starters typically include duck confit, blue cheese salad, foie gras, a soup and a few others; for the mains, a few fishes, several meats and the famous 1/2 pound burger.

Dinner started with an amuse bouche--a tiny salmon sandwich cookie.  I ordered an appetizer but my wife did not, so the restaurant split my "Pan Seared Diver Sea Scallop & Whiskey Braised Ox Tail (on a bed of creamy polenta)."  Splitting the dish seemed presumptuous but I believe the kitchen doubled it's size too--so certainly no complaints.  And it was sweet, delicious scallop.

My main was a tasty lamb stew with a lamb loin wrapped in crispy pastry, like a spring roll.  My wife enjoyed the burger, which was served with small crispy fries and included two types of ketchup--one made by the restaurant, one not.

For dessert, we split a cinnamon ice cream with a stick chewy date truffle.   Our dinner, with a glass of wine, was about $55.

We'll be back soon..

Or so I've been told.  Due to San Francisco's unfair and discriminatory health code, I am not actually allowed to enter this restaurant.
author: spot d.

description:
To get to the point...overall, it was ok...I'm not impressed easily and this place is pretty typical of most restaurants that are trying to make a name for themselves...Although, they did treat my 3 year old son very well by giving him a bowl of soup (potato leek, pretty good)  without being asked to do so...Props!!...I am always wary of the portion size at places like this however they did not dissapoint...I ordered a steak, rare, and was given a pretty large portion...so much that I could not finish it...Props again!! However, the steak was noticeably salty...The other entrees seemed to follow suit in terms of portion size as well...For the kind of money you spend, I expect to walk out of the place feeling full...

The most interesting part of The Richmond is the literally, 2 foot by 3 foot bathroom...very clean and well arranged with the space available...No kidding, you could take an ATOMIC dump and wash your hands without having to stand up...now thats efficiency!!  Props 3 times!!!
author: Doug E.

description:
Three stars for food 
four and half star for service

I came here with my family to celebrate my brother's birthday.   I was not really impress with the food but the service was great.   I thought it was a really nice gestured when our waitress presented my brother with a free dessert for his birthday.  


We ordered the following food
Organic Heirloom Tomato Salad - too much dressing and the tomatoes were too riped

Wild Soft Shell Blue Crab - too much dressing on the spinach.  the soft crab was deep fried and it was just ok

Potato Leek Soup with Crab Dumpling -  the soup was too rich.  I can only finish half of it.  they served the soup with two deep fried crab dumpling. I shared the crab dumpling with my husband and we both only took a bite of it and we hated it.

Seared Hanger Steak -this is the worst most foul tasting steak!  the meat was dried, chewy, and had a strong meat foul taste to it.  my husband who LOVES steak could not stomach it.  this was the first time he ever left 70% of his food untouched.  It was so awful that he refused to finish it.

Roast Pork Tenderloin with Macaroni & Cheese - we asked them to give us rice instead of macaroni and cheese.  this was the best dish of the night


House Ground Half-Pound Cheeseburger & French Fries - this was a pretty good burger.  We liked it but we didn't love it


The arctic char - my brother liked it but husband thought it was just ok
author: L C.

description: The Richmond Restaurant is a hidden gem.  Tucked away on Balboa Street in a residential area, this is an amazing place to experience creative, beautifully presented cuisine.  Great food!
author: David S.

description:
I wasn't as happy as I thought I would be.  Everything had the possibility of being five stars but they couldn't follow through.  

Service - really warm and nice waiters but they forgot my wine. It wasn't that busy and the place doesn't hold many tables.  I think there are only about 8 tables in the place, and with three waiters, a front door lady/owner there really isn't an excuse for lost orders.  

Food - the foie was nicely cooked but had an overall sweet taste.  The oysters were a little tougher than I thought they should be.  Grass-fed beef, i think, didn't have as much flavor as it could.  Very tender but when it's near purple/raw, what's not tender?  I asked for medium rare - no biggie.  I like raw things.  But I think it should have more pink than purple.  The yellow-tail had a wonderful flavor.  Possibly overly firm/about to be dry. It was close to being not good.  The panna cotta was flavorless on its own but went well with the lemon curd on top. I swear, I 've had panna cotta with flavor before.  

It's a little on the pricey side for this level of service and near misses.  They never forget my order at Outback.  But it is warm and intimate in there.  A few of the tables have their own private curtains...which is a nice touch.
author: Bruce B.

description: Good food service menu atmosphere. It's a local gem. Order anything because it's really delicious.  Also large portion.  The chef comes out to greet u. Good wine list.
author: Ingrid Y.

description:
I rarely give out 5 stars, but this place is a gem. I have now been here 3 times and all 3 were extraordinary experiences.

The first time I came I tried to get a bottle of wine that was on the cheaper side, and our waiter (who was the owner) recommended a much more expensive bottle. When I said that I had to watch my spending, he offered to give me the more expensive bottle at the price of the cheaper bottle just so that I could try it. Wow.

The second time, they screwed up my reservation and I had to wait all of ten minutes for my table. In return, I got free salad and wine with my meal. For waiting ten minutes.

Each time, the food has been extraordinary. I recommend the steak, which in itself is amazing but comes with a potato and brie stuffed filo-dough crepe and a side of sauteed spinach. And it's $20. It doesn't get much better than that.
author: D S.

description: No idea whether or not the food is any good... but I DO know they are too snooty to do take out. I live in the area and  I dine out a LOT. I wanted a really good quality meal, but I just wanted to be able to eat it at home. Not from the Richmond. They refused to do take out.  I won't be calling them again, nor will I bother to go in. I really can't support snobbery.
author: Chris B.

description:
Decor- cute, cozy place. Has two(?) tables that could be isolated with curtains for a nice dating experience. 
Prices- good for the quality of food. 
Service- Marc (Mark?) was an excellent server. We went on a Wed night, place wasn't packed so he and other servers (Chef's wifey?) were very unobtrusive. Chef came out to thank us for joining them for dinner. Nice touch.

FOOD - We had:
1) Scallops and Braised Ox Tail - YUM. Cooked perfectly. Too bad only one scallop. Was delish tho. The creamy polenta was a nice companion.

2) Seared Foie Gras - It's my fave food so had to try! Ranks up there with the rest. Pain perdue was lovely. I gotta google what the diff btwn pp is w/ brioche!

3) Flat Bread Sloppy Joe - Kind of didn't go w/ the scallops or fg, but we wanted to try. Strong goat cheese presence. Homey and would probably go well if we got the cheeseburger.

4) Sea Bass w/ Tomato and Wine Sauce - I want to say great things about this dish, but it was only okay. I do love me some brocollini tho!

5) Duck - cooked well, but for some reason tasted sorta like it was smoked (had a strong resemblance to ham). Very tender without looking too rare, which was interesting.

6) Oh man, did I forget to mention THE BREAD!!?! It was friggin SO GOOD. I ended up asking where it was from and buying a big 'ol loaf the next day!

7) Apple Tart - didn't sound all that interesting alone, but rosemary and pepper ice cream got us. Turned out the ice cream is homemade in the resto (YUM) and the tart was more like a lil flaky crust turnover. The boy liked it a lot since he's a super pastry fan. 

Overall, the place is cute, staff/owners are super nice, and our overall experience was one to go back for. Is this my first good yelp? LOL. I tend to not want to share my good finds, but I would love to see this place weather the storm.
author: dianne l.

description:
This little restaurant has been in the area for a while after the previous Malaysia/Singaporean restaurant closed down.  It's a nice little place and the atmosphere is warm inside the restaurant.  I went there with my hubby and another couple.  We ordered 4 burgers (yes, we ordered the same thing, just noticed that it was all we want after reading the menu).

The appetizer came and all 4 of us looked at it for half a minute but still could not have a clue what it was.  It's all kinds of little dices of "something" in the center of a big round plate.  After trying, we still could not tell what these dices were.  We asked the waiter and he explained it's some kinds of melons, fruits.... whatever... we did not really care, if it's tasty.  But, honestly, it was kind of plain in taste and small in portion.

Then, the burgers came and they looked delicious.  Yes, it was, juicy and tasty, just a little small in portion, especially for the men.  Overall, the place is very nice and the waiters are nice.  But, with the price charged, I would consider the portion too small.  I would come back but it's not a place that I would eat often.

It'd be an ideal place for a private party and you can occupy the whole restaurant for that.  I have once seen a kid's birthday party being held in there during the weekend.  I believe that it's for the fun of the adults rather than the kids.

BTW, the parking in the area is hard.  You may want to park a little bit away from the restaurant and walk a few blocks instead of taking a risk to block someone's driveway which can make your visit to Richmond very costly.
author: Roserrele W.

description:
What a great little french bistro! I love the feeling of a family owned restaurant. Chef Owyang was kind enough to go around all the tables to ask how everyone's night was going. However, I have to admit that a couple of the servers (not the women who work there) are a bit strange and probably not the most personable. 

The food was excellent for the price that was paid. I LOVE the oxtail and scallops dish. It is out of this world!! And the Foie Gras was so so YUM. It's a spot that I would definitely go back to very soon! But keep in mind that parking is a pain in the butt. We had to circle around and around for more than 20 minutes to find a space!!
author: Angela T.

description:
I was surprised by how fancy this place was... and how affordable, too.

Beware... if you're looking for even a reasonably casual date spot (let's say 1st through 4th date) and haven't been here before, you may be overwhelmed by the fanciness. It's pretty quiet and intimate, too. I don't mind it at all, but some people do. It's probably great for a date with your girlfriend, though.

Two of us had an appetizer, two sizeable entrees, a half bottle of sparkling wine, and dessert for $80 (not including tip).

The duck confit was outstanding, and I am not a big duck guy by any stretch. The strawberry tart dessert was also a highlight. In general, everything was great. My only food-related critique would be that my seared yellowtail was a little more than seared.

The service was fine... reliable if somewhat absent, but it's never hard to flag someone down in such a quiet and cozy place.
author: Angelo B.

description:
The service here is excellent. Really stellar.

I am easy to seduce with amuse bouche. Also, bread with three kinds of butter. That also seduces.

The food, generally, is high-quality. The menu is small, but everything on it is carefully prepared from fresh ingredients.  I like some things better than others, but I am fairly certain that is a matter of personal taste. The attention to detail is obvious.

Great wine. I wish there was a little more wine from Europe, but still, terrific selections for a neighborhood place.

The only reason I won't go the full 5 star lovefest for the Richmond is the menu. I think keeping their menu small and focusing on making the menu items very good is the right choice. However, if that's the route you're going to take, you have to change the menu to reflect seasonal availability. The Richmond does this - but only incrementally, and only about 4 times a year. I think a monthly total menu change would make them totally over-the-top awesome.

Also, sometimes, when they get very busy, which is not that often, the food is not as consistent as on, say, a Thursday night. I don't know what restaurant that isn't true of, but in case you were wondering...
author: H G.

description: My husband & I had dinner here for the first time on Friday night and were very impressed (with the burger especially)! I'm so happy we discovered this great spot - friendly service, nice ambiance & delicious food that is not at all overpriced! We will definitely be back again!
author: Andrea N.

description:
Once upon a time, this was a hidden gem - but given the 129 reviews before mine, I'm gonna go ahead and say the secret is out...

My favorite thing about this restaurant is that it feels more like a meal by your personal chef (who does come out to talk to all of the tables at some point).  It's a small and quiet place with tables in tight, but comfortable little nooks - and you truly get the feeling that when you place your order, they start cooking it from scratch - right then and there.  The drawback of this is that, at least on the most recent visit, service felt very slow - not unattentive at all - just slow. But as usual, it was all worth it when it came. 

The one staple on the menu I'm aware of - burger and fries - is a must. And the wine list features some great bottles from vineyards large and tiny.

Allow plenty of time for parking, which can be frustrating in this neighborhood of short curbs and driveways...
author: Kiesha R.

description:
This is a terrific neighborhood restaurant. If I lived nearby, I would be a regular. I live on the other side of Golden Gate Park, so I'd come here if it were convenient. It is almost good enough to make a special trip for.

The reason it's good are fresh ingredients, attentive service, and a reasonably priced wine list.

I had the hanger steak (not perfect: a little tough, as happens with this cut) and the beet salad. My wife had the yellowtail and the potato and leek soup. It was all at a quality level higher than you'd expect for a place next to a laundromat.

Highly recommended.
author: Frank W.

description:
I back this place, cute and tiny with a good wine list. We went there pretty late so it wasn't too claustrophobic. I always wonder who buys the $350 bottle of wine at the local spot, does anyone?
The only issue I have is that my dish said there were going to be mushrooms in it and there was not a one, but again we were there late so they may have run out.
author: Roxane S.

description:
The wide spectrum of prior reviews left me both intrigued and a bit apprehensive about dining here, but throwing caution to the wind, my wife and I ventured to The Richmond last night for a quiet rainy evening dinner.  Our experience couldn't have been better, as the food was terrific, the service friendly and attentive, and the atmosphere cozy and intimate.  Nevertheless, I think I can see how on a busy night things could get overwhelming for the kitchen and staff, and perhaps that's the source of some of the problems that have led to The Richmond's mixed reviews to date.

We started by splitting an appetizer of fried oysters with frisee and miso vinaigrette.  One of the standout features of this place is the way in which dishes present strong, distinctive flavors of individual ingredients that balance against one another quite harmoniously.  My wife's entree of petrale sole (apparently a substitute for the standard menu's yellow tail), oyster mushrooms, sunchokes, and watercress and celeriac puree was fantastic, particularly for the interplay of tastes between the mushrooms, fish, and celeriac puree.  My duck breast was served with a duck confit hash that was simultaneously down home and sublime,  and worked great in combination with the duck breast and a winter squash puree. 

I wasn't too impressed by the wine list, but did think the selections offered were very good, and the prices quite reasonable.  In fact, overall the prices at The Richmond are quite reasonable for the quality of both food and service.

We were well taken care of by the service here, which was very low key and very personable, although not as highly polished as in some larger establishments.  I can see how this could get disjointed under busier circumstances, and for that reason you may want to be careful about dining here at traditional peak hours.  Another factor to keep in mind is parking, and this area has the double curse of too many cars for too little street parking along with virtually no paid lots available nearby.  We lucked out by being offered by the proprietor to park in front of the driveway next to the restaurant, a very welcome and appreciated gesture, but not one that more than one or two diners could ever count on for any evening.

The Richmond is a winner, but be careful about choosing a day and time where you can really appreciate the best it has to offer.  The warm, small space, outstanding food, and individual service helped make the evening romantic and truly enjoyable.  We'll definitely be back.
author: Hugh B.

description:
Yummo! Great food and a great price...walking distance from my apartment. I've been here twice and both times both the food and the service were excellent (I just used the same word twice in one sentence...oh well). For apps, I've tried the sweetbreads, fried oysters, and salmon carpaccio. Sweetbreads were my favorite as it came with an amazing risotto, although the others were also very good. For entrees, I've tried the steak (it was ok, but the crepe is amazing), ravioli w/shortrib meatball, burger (really good!), and the scallops w/oxtail & polenta. Desserts are great and the wine list is very reasonable. Can't wait to come back!  

Ooh, and you have to order the burger...with the fries! the fries are great.
author: L N.

description:
I needed a Western experience and was walking from Clement to the Safeway for my fix and walked past The Richmond. I saw white table clothes and stemware on the tables and thought - what is this place?! Finally got to try it out and really enjoyed the food. It wasn't outstanding but it was good and I liked the comfortable atmosphere and affordable wine list. And I can wear jeans. There was someone even in there with a t-shirt and jeans. I love it.

Started with the beet salad and oxtail and scallops for appetizers. The salad was very good and the oxtail and scallops was good but the scallops a wee bit overcooked.

Entrees were the hangar steak and petrole sole and beef cheeks. Yeah, I had a surf and turf for both of my dishes. The sole was awesome. A little oversalted as was the oxtail but very good.

Dessert was the panna cotta. This is a lot - I finished it because I am a pig and stopped eating my entree to have room. There was a raspberry sauce (I think it was raspberry) and there was lots of it. Maybe too much, I would have liked to have the sauce on the side or just dribbled over the panna cotta but I still ate it all.

The service was spotty but there was only one person on that night and he was doing all he could. Our bill came out to close to $100. In addition to the food we had three glasses on wine and should have just had ordered a bottle but I wanted white and my husband wanted red. What are you gonna do.

I think this is a great neighborhood restaurant. Cozy, good food and before I forget the bread! I love bread and finished almost a whole loaf on my own. The three spreads were all good. Can't wait to go back for more and the $9.95 hamburger. For a couple of bucks more than the Hamburger Haven I can get a hamburger in style with some wine.
author: Wendy B.

description:
The longer I was here, the better I liked it. But it took some time! For a party of five, we arrived right on schedule after trying for a long time to find a parking space!

It's a small venue, so there isn't a host stand waiting for you. We stood for a few minutes before a waiter appeared to take us to our table. Matt was friendly. Water service never ended...I was a bit water logged by evening's end. The Bordeaux blend ($9) glass of wine was tasty, and the bread with three butters (olive, sea salt and chive) was delicious. The butter should have been thawed a bit more, but overall was quite good. 

The potato leek soup with crab dumplings was superb, and my main entree of pork tenderloin was excellent, if a bit salty, and had to be sent back to be cooked a bit more, as it was too pink for my taste. The accompanying Gruyere mac-n-cheese and veggies were out of this world. Coffee after dinner was strong, and the service throughout the meal was quite good. They were nice about satisfying dietary needs, too.
author: David G.

description:
The Richmond is a restaurant that offers downtown cuisine at neighborhood prices.

The husband and I ventured out here for an anniversary dinner and had a wonderful experience. It wasn't too crowded, as I suspect most people were home watching the Biden-Palin debate (they did televise it at the wine bar).

The food was fabulous. We were offered an amuse bouche featuring two types of melons. My starter, the heirloom tomato salad, was perfect with the sweetest tomatoes one has ever had. The braised monkfish was tasty as was the wine sauce that accompanied it. And for dessert, the panna cotta with raspberry sauce was excellent - perfect to share as they serve it in a large bowl!

Would love to come back here for date night or an intimate dinner with close friends.
author: Kelly R.

description: A real find. Our party was seated within red velvet curtains for a cosy, intimate, and very quiet nook. Everything we ordered was delicious and nicely presented. Service was prompt, unobtrusive, friendly, and obliging. One lady asked for tastes of three different wines before she found what she wanted and the waiter willingly offered advise and the three tastes. We had salmon, beet and carrot salad, squash soup, and the most unusual, cod atop a sort of thick stew, which was described as chowder. After we ordered, a waiter brought deviled eggs and then delicious warm bread with three kinds of herb butter. We finished with two delicious desserts and coffee. The chef came by twice to be sure we were warm enough on that cold and rainy night and that everything was to our liking. We felt unusually well taken care of and we will be returning often.
author: Anne L.

description: It's kind of a cozy exclusive restaurant. We tried the beet salad for appetizer. It was really good. The sauces were just perfect. For entree,  we got the seared hanger steak and the wild mushroom pastry. The steak was little under done, raw and tasteless. The mushroom pastry was spot on. The dessert was ok - warm chocolate and peanut butter corte. It was nothing special. The restaurant can feel a little cramped -  but then, that's pretty normal here in SF I guess! The service was fantastic though - very attentive waiters. Their wines are very reasonably priced. But overall, it can get pricey ;)
author: K C.

description: This is a gem located in the inner-richmond district.  The service is super friendly and the food is delicious.  They give you a bread with three types of butter to start off with, and all were delicious.  The fried chicken is amazing, and the coffee semifreddo for dessert is worth coming back for
author: abby q.

description: Great food and the owner is very personable. I've been there ten times and the guy has come out of the kitchen every time to ask patrons if everything is to their satisfaction.
author: Mitchell L.

description: I was at The Richmond on Saturday night and had a chace to speak with the owner John.  He's a really nice and harding working guy.  We've been a customer for years and it's really exciting that John is venturing out.  The Richmond will have catering service for wedding and parties!  Congrats John and we'll be by soon again.
author: Audrey C.

description:
I live in the neighborhood, in fact, I grew up just half a block away on 7th  Avenue, so this nice, quiet and sophisticated little restaurant is within my walk and watch.  Being one who likes to support local and neighborhood businesses, this is one of my favorite restaurants.  

But there's one simple simple dish everyone seemed to overlook: hamburger.  It's even in the dinner menu.  Fresh ground beef almost 1 1/2" thick cooked slowly to order and perfection and served with hand cut French fries seasoned just right.  The condiments are something else, ketchup is really homemade tomato sauce, and mayonnaise and mustard are deliciously flavored.  It was simply the juiciest and tenderest and the most honest hamburger in town for a pittance.
author: Tiger L.

description: a small restaurant. But don't let the size of this place fool you. The food is amazing. Service is great and decor is eloquent.
author: Braden L.

description: Food was good here.  I questioned their wine pricing gimmick.  After dessert, the owner/chef came out and showed me their invoicing.  Integrity!  Outstanding!
author: Louis A.

description:
Absolutely A+ in every way!      The food was creative and delicious.    We had the heirloom tomato salad, pork chop, crispy vegetables, and ice cream dessert, all preceded by a lovely amuse bouche to start.     We love small, neighborhood restaurants and this is one of the best, for sure.     We brought our own wine ($20 corkage), but the wine list has lots of options at reasonable prices.     The service was perfect.

Do try The Richmond.    You will love it also.
author: Barbara R.

description:
I had read the reviews, and the menu, so when my husband and I made reservations, we had pretty high expectations.  We decided to go for the tasting menu and the accompanying wine selections.  

We had a great time, left stuffed and satisfied and slightly buzzed from the wine.  The service was great, all the staffers were friendly and helpful and the food was presented like little jewels. 

 At first we were a little horrified at the tiny portions, but they just kept coming, in succession, and before we knew it, we were starting to feel full.  The wine pairings were fantastic, dry where they needed to be dry, and fruity at all the right places.  It ended with a tawny port, and the oak undertones perfectly complimented the sweet cinnamon ice cream.  At the end of the meal, the chef came out and asked us if we enjoyed the meal.

The colors, the textures, the flavors were crafted with an artists eye and care.  The abalone egg benedict (not the official menu name, I can't remember the real name) was particularly stand out.  The abalone was melt-in-your-mouth tender.  The pumpkin soup was rich and flavorful.
author: Carmen D.

description: My sister and my boyfriend came here for dinner back in March.  The food came out with perfect portion sizes, and was beyond delicious.  My entree, sea bass with vegetables, was dripping in butter.  I would go back in a heartbeat.
author: Codarus C.

description:
Two words: "Under Rated"!!! OpenTable gives it a 14/20 - I say more like an 18/20. 

Some friends took me to dinner here one night and I kept thinking how it was possible that I lived so close to this place, but had never been in before!

We stopped in on a Thurs night without a reservation and had no problem getting a table. I loved the pictures of the Richmond District scattered about the place from years past, many of which I had not ever seen before. It was a semi-special occasion and we had brought our own wine, a decent bottle at that. The server noticed, and asked us about it. The chef also came out, asked us about the wine, and talked to us about the menu and his wine list.

Appetizers and Entrees were wonderful, and the wine list was reasonable and well thought out. I had the pork tenderloin, which was superb. We ordered the "Prisoner" wine at the chef's recommendation, and it was delicious and reasonable. The conversation with the chef, who obviously has passion for his work, just added to the positive experience. In the end, they did not even charge us for corkage.

I can't wait to go back and have been trying to rally up a dinner party. It's worth at LEAST one visit, if not repeat visits.
author: Craig G.

description: i love this place! i've been to this restaurants three times now, and every time i've gotten great customer service and delicious food! i lived in sf for 21 years and never knew this restaurant existed. i don't know how to describe this type of french restaurant, but i love it! the portions are big and the price is super reasonable. love love love!
author: K E.

description:
I really disliked this restaurant.  I walked in on a Friday night with my boyfriend at like 9:30 pm and the girl behind the bar immediately said "if you don't have a reservation we can't take you" in a way that made me feel we were trying to crash a private party.  We looked around and saw a few open tables and she sort of backtracked as we were walking out and said oh, we can seat you. 

So we sat down and each ordered the three course prix fix menu, which I think was about $50. It wasn't that good, at all.  And the first course was miniscule (my boyfriend laughed when he saw it because he knows how I feel about tall food), although the main course was decent size.  Niether dish was very tasty or good.  

And, it really, really bothered me that our server and the owner/manager were wearing t-shirts, like old scroungy t-shirts. It was Friday night and they certainly charge like a nice restaurant and they didn't have the food to back it up, it was just too much for me. 

I won't go back. And I don't get why everyone else loves it. There are a thousand better restuarants for half the cost with just as good atmosphere, including nearby Sushi Bistro and Burma Superstar .
author: Sara A.

description: The most delicious food is here at the Richmond. They always serve a free deviled egg and bread with amazing spreads, plus the food can be pretty reasonable - $10 burgers, $7 dollar starters. For fancy or less than fancy, the food here never fails. It's incredible. Great service, too.
author: Sophie K.

description: I'll keep it simple. Glad to have the Richmond in the Richmond. Simple as we are out here in the outside lands. Great food is not great unless it carries Great Service. A great lesson. Thanks guys. can't wait to get back!
author: David G.

description: The Richmond is a delightful small restaurant in an otherwise banal neighborhood. I had the Wild Pacific Salmon with oyster mushroom Florentine. The dish was delicious, perfectly seasoned and beautifully presented. My friend had the crispy fried chicken, but because she didn't eat the crispy part and declined the potatoes, I have no idea how the whole dish, as intended, tasted. She was happy with the chicken part. Three flavors of butter with the bread, olive and chive I think ... a charming touch. The amuse bouche was also very nice. The restaurant was exceedingly welcoming and the host staff did their best to accommodate requests for changes in some of the dishes. I'll return for sure.
author: Eileen A.

description:
An intimate, cozy restaurant - perfect place to bring a date. The Richmond offers all the perks of fine dining at an affordable price! Dishes were creative, generous, and flavorful. Service was exceptional. Everyone was professional, friendly, and down-to-earth.

I loved the dessert, Coffee Semifreddo! It was not too sweet and the almond brittle was crumbled into bite-sized pieces, a perfect finish to a wonderful meal.
author: Dee L.

description:
What a great little neighborhood bistro!!!  The boyfriend and I were hanging out  at the De Young on Friday night, and I thought we'd try to grab some food nearby since we were in the area.  The Richmond was totally unexpected and surprising in a good way!  The food was tasty and service was excellent.  The soft-spoken owner/chef came by each table during the evening to thank diners for their patronage.  Nice touch!  I had the artichoke soup and braised shortribs.  Both were delicious!  Boyfriend had a caprese salad and hangar steak.  He didn't share, but I'm told he enjoyed both.  They also bring out delicious bread with three different types of butter.  YUM!  They have a fairly extensive wine list, and I thought the prices were very reasonable.

The artwork on the walls was a little weird, and the TV on the wall when you first walk in seemed a little out of place.

Overall, great experience, and perfect way to finish an evening at the De Young!  Looking forward to returning!
author: Chibi Q.

description:
Updated Review:
Came here again last night and my experience was soooo much better than the first.  And it was definitely bc of our waiter.  He was awesome, so attentive and very polite!! Our food was great, they're portions are pretty big, and the cost is reasonable...I really think our waitress last time pretty much sucked, and ruined our view of the restaurant!  I would definitely recommend coming here if you have the tall, male waiter as your server to get the best experience of this place.  They definitely bring in the mature crowd, but whatever, i was having a  nice time with the bf. 

Original Review:
Ate here last night really excited actually bc i hear lots of great things bout this place.  We live in the outer richmond so the thought of having a place like this in the area sounded great.  Their foie gras was pretty good and the oxtail w/ scallops was to die for...our entrees were not as impressive,  however,  and neither was our server, hence the three stars.  The place was practically empty and she just didnt deliver, maybe she was having a bad day, i dunno. The decor/ambiance was stale (pale canary yellow walls with maroon curtains, yuck!!!) and when the restaurant filled up a little bit more, it was all old people! 65 and up! i felt like i was dining at a retirement home.  But i'll give it another try for the food.
author: Steph S.

description:
Awesome restaurant.  Just moved to SF a month ago and this is the first restaurant that got me motivated enough to begin my Yelping career.  

Just finished up eating there - stuffed to the brim.  Kitchen was pretty busy but they brought out a few extras to keep us busy while they worked.  Meal took two hours but it was not a long two hours - staff constantly checked in.  Nice date night restaurant.  They brought my fiancee (sorry ladies) a salad to eat while I had the tater soup (with crab wontons).   Had dessert and coffee - both awesome.  Wine is a pretty good deal here - great selection for pretty reasonable prices.  Sorry Ryann's mom but the pork tenderloin here took pork to a new level for me - wow.  

Fantastic food and I will be visiting again.  Soon.
author: Patrick W.

description:
Talk about charming, this place has class, elegance, and fabulous prices. It is tucked about among the fog in the Richmond, but it is well worth the drive if you live in a different neighborhood. 

I had the Foie Gras, which may be politically incorrect, but it sure was tasty. I have had it at some great restaurants and this compares to the best places in town. One thing that's nice is everything is under $20.00 and for the Foie, they can certainly charge a lot more.

The second course, I had the Pork Chop with Macaroni and Cheese. It was so rich, but so delicious. I didn't even care about the calories, as I enjoyed every bite. 

They have a nice wine list as well, which impressed me, as it is such a small restaurant. I

 would certainly discover this gem before everyone else does. Don't wait, just go as soon as possible.
author: Christopher W.

description: This place would be a wonderful date place...if I was 80 years old and dating a 90 year old!  Holy crap the clientele is old!!!  Despite the super old crowd and the fact that it was so quiet this place has great food.  Don't come here if you are on a low carb diet - the warm french bread with the olive butter, chive butter and sweet butter with sea salt is to die for.  I only stopped eating it to enjoy my scallops with braised oxtail app.  Loved the pork and mac and cheese entree and the ribeye was good but the cut of meat was a little odd.  Definitely have the peach crisp dessert - super rich vanilla ice cream with really fresh peaches.  This is a super cute tucked away restaurant.
author: Jen C.

description:
Really solid restaurant and much needed in this neighborhood. One BIG minus for me is the bathroom is not wheelchair accessible, which means 
I cannot go back. A restaurant should not be listed as accessible if the bathroom is not. Kind of a big deal when one is in a wheelchair.
author: cynthia N.

description: This is one of my local favorites- the food is always impeccable, fresh and local and the chef creates just perfect compositions. What really sets The Richmond apart though is the service. It's just stellar- it's like there are little ninjas floating around you, nearly unseen, helping make your experience thoroughly enjoyable. This is my go-to place for special nights out. Thanks for creating such a hidden little gem in the neighborhood!
author: Corrie C.

description:
This is a great restaurant!  The menu has a good number of choices, but not too many.  The food is great and the service rocks.  I tried the foie gras appetizer and the atlantic char with rosti.  MMMM!  The panna cotta with raspberry sauce is delicious and not to be missed.  The chef even comes out to thank you for coming.  What a nice treat.

The only downside is that this neighborhood can be a hard place to find parking.  But once you do, you'll be enjoying a wonderful dinner at the Richmond.
author: Bruges L.

description: Fantastic food at a great price point. Good service. Small and quaint with amazing food.
author: Erika P.

description: We went here for our anniversary!  The food was DELICIOUS!!  Service was AWESOME!  Would highly recommend this restaurant and will be going back!  My husband had the soup which was very good and I had the beet salad, super good.  He loved his hanger steak and I really enjoyed my yellow fin tuna.  Both desserts were great!
author: Donna R.

description:
Had dinner here with friends recently.. on a Sat night; I think the kitchen is much better then the wait staff, but for the quality of the food and wine, I'll forgive a few minor things (like our server was in the 'mood', wasn't crazy about our questions, etc). 
Food: I would highly recommend the tasting menu with wine paring.   The dishes were fabulous (although the portions were so generous that we barely got to desert). My favorite was the seared foie gras, and the beet salad. They also use a lot of wild mushrooms in some dishes - great flavor and presentation. 
Wine: wine paring, not only is worth it (not pricey at all), but is chosen well, down to the port with desert.  They do bring the wine ahead of food, so that was one of those server things we had to overlook.  

I think it's a great neighborhood place, the owner (the chef) works very hard to make sure you have a pleasant experience (he walks around during the meal too), it's well-decorated, and a perfect place for a nice quiet dinner with a small group. Parking was relatively easy, considering this is in the middle of Richmond, just circle a few blocks, you'd be ok.
author: Laura K.

description:
This place is fairly close, so after living near it for 3 years I finally decided to try it. 

We sat at the bar & got very attentive service. The chef was talking quite a bit with us, offered us a taste of his favorite wine & even had a delicious soup sent out to us!

The lasagne was very tasty & vegetarian, and the bread & choice of 3 homemade spreads was great too. I love carbs more than anything!!!

I need to go back here!
author: Danielle G.

description:
The irony of this 5-star review is that I had originally tried to make reservations at another fancyish place in the neighborhood, Chapeau!, but they didn't have a time available that worked for us. I'm sure that's a great place too, and I'll try it one of these days, but this really turned out perfectly for us, so I have no regrets.
First, this place is great for a romantic meal-- quiet and cozy/tiny and pleasantly atmospheric, curtained alcoves and candles on the table.
We decided to splurge and go for the five-course tasting menu, although the a la carte stuff looked great too-- small menu, heavy on the meat, just one vegetarian entree. The entrees seemed to hover just under the $20 mark, which I would say is pretty good for the quality of the place. My husband was sort of tickled to note they had a cheeseburger on the menu for $9.95, alongside the pricier options.

We got: 
*FANTASTIC bread. Crusty outside, moist tender yeasty sourdough inside, with three different types of butter. Hard to stop eating it.
*An amuse bouche of potato-leek soup, with a distinct fennel or anise taste to it. Milky and mild, nice but maybe a little bland.
*Beet salad with goat cheese sauce and cardamom carrots, and a cheese-filled puff pastry. Well presented, simple and tasty. 
*Sweetbreads, nicely browned, with spinach and gravy and a sort of ravioli/dumpling at the bottom that was probably unnecessary to the dish. Very rich and flavorful. I was starting to worry by this point if I was going to be able to get through all the courses.
*Seabass with greens and a creamy orange colored sauce that we couldn't quite identify- tomato? Pumpkin? (can't recall what the menu said) But it was good, rich and a little tangy, and the fish was moist and well cooked. 
*Ribeye steak with potatoes cooked with onions. Rare and tender and wonderful, if I go back I might very well just eat nothing but this.
*Coffee semifreddo for dessert with a nice toffee crunch and whipped cream topping.
Miraculously, the portion sizes turned out to be just about perfect-- I was very full at the end of all that, but not in pain.
Service was very attentive-- they seemed to switch off, so that all four people working in the restaurant at some point stopped by our table. But it worked out just fine, aside from one minor glitch when a server tried to give us wine (I'm pregnant and not drinking right now- my husband just doesn't drink much). 
Definitely recommend, and it's nice to have something like this in the neighborhood.
author: Sara G.

description:
I ate here recently and I have to say... I was blown away. It was amazing and one of the best culinary experiences I've had since Rubicon in January without the huge prices. It's a very intimate place with wonderful food and service. It lacks the noise and bustle of a large restaurant and I felt very relaxed there. It's a great place to go with a significant other or with someone you need to catch up with.

The Hangar Steaks was superb as was the Pork Loin. I like the simple preparation. The bread was great and the three different flavors of butter they served were superb. Wine list was reasonable and very affordable. I really enjoyed the beet and carrot salad as well. For dessert, the chocolate and peanut butter torte is not to be missed.

Highly recommended.
author: Andy S.

description:
I was suprised by the good reviews of this place in such a quiet neighborhood with few restaraunts in the area and heard about this place through some friends.
 
The Richmond is small, quiet, and can be romantic. The curtains used to create rooms and privacy from the outside seems amatuerish and the muted TV at the bar seems out of place. The paintings/photos on the wall don't seem to connect to each other or any theme. There is mini wine cellar in the back with a good choice of wines. The dinner menu is very limited with almost every entree in the $19.95 range.
 
If you go, you should get a reservation. My girlfriend and I were lucky to be able to squeeze into the schedule without a reservation. Other people were turned away as we waited for our table.
 
The meal started off with this complimentary tiny cream cheese thing with nuts and a fig on top. Not bad. Their complimentary bread was warm and comes with 3 kinds of butters ... olive, regular with sea salt, and cucumber. The cucumber one is pretty good. 
 
For an appetizer, we had the salad with cranberries, walnut, bleu cheese, and pears with pear vinegarrette. That actually was pretty good and for sharing they gave pretty big portions.
 
For the main course, we had their burger which is well worth the 9.95 price tag. The bread is a Schubert roll. I'm not sure what that is but it has these nice crunchy textures at the top of it. It comes with a tomatoe and this white cheddar cheeze melted on it. I had the patty cooked medium rare and it was very soft and juicy for the most part...one end of the patty (10% of the burger) seemed a little dry. 
The burger is accompanied by shoe string fries, dijon mustard and their own homemade ketchup and aioli. The ketchup tasted a lot like a light tomato sauce to me though.
 
Overall a pretty good burger but it doesn't beat the ones in NYC, IMO. The service is pretty friendly at the Richmond and the chef does like to come by and ask you how the food is and apologize for any wait times. They get an "A" for effort and service.
author: Daniel L.

description:
I love this place. Not one bad thing I would say about this place. First, I decided to have our "supper club" dinner here. They accomdated all of us nicely in the cosy restaurant. The chef/owner was so nice. He made us feel like he knew us. Every one of us enjoyed what we got. Not one person complained. I got the fau gras for appetizer...it was on a plush piece of french-toast like bread...it was melt in your mouth. THen I got the Duck for entree. YUM. The man got short ribs. He loved iit. My man knows food and he knew he liked this.

The next time we went was a rainy Saturday night that we just didn't feel like waiting a long time for a table. We called Richmond and they got us right in. Not only that but the chef owner let us park in a spot right in front of the restaurant that was blocking a driveway...nice. 

Anyway, this time, the man got the duck and I got the arctic char. YUM. for dessert we got a Molten Lava cake....wow! It was chocolate woth peanut butter in the middle. I went for a nice long bike ride to work that off...but it was WORTH it! 

Go here. Good Service, good food, good ambiance.
author: Sue S.

description:
__
              ___( o)7
              \ *_. )
               `---' Oh my gooolosh. You will not find goolosh here.
          
If you haven't tried this place, it is a MUST. First and foremost, every single thing we had here was GOOD, DAMN GOOD. I would even go as far as to say excellent. Yes, the food was excellent and was reasonably priced.

I was utterly impressed by the fact the owner checks on just about every table and is VERY accommodating. He knows how to pair the wines he has with the food you intend on ordering and will help you find a bottle of wine within your price range. I had two great glasses of wine for good measure.

Now on to the food.

They start you off with a deviled egg. Interesting, but good.

Then they give you bread with flavored butters. I wish I knew what kind of bread this was, because ohhh mama it was good.

To start I shared with my boyfriend the Harvest Salad (spicy pecans, candied cranberries & Forme D'Ambert with an apple cider vinaigrette) and the Whisky Braised Oxtail with a Maine Diver Scallop. Both were divine. The salad had just enough dressing and the polenta with the scallop was immensely scrumptious. We were almost fighting over the last morsels of the scallop dish.

On to the main dishes.

The boyfriend had the hanger steak. He was highly impressed when they served it they way he wanted it, medium rare. It wasn't bloody and it wasn't overcooked-at all. His comment was "this is the best steak I've had in a long time." It also came with a crepe filled with pancetta, potato, onion fennel & Brie, which was so good. Thank goodness we share our meals.

I had the Rack of Lamb with bacon, onion, cabbage, pave potatoes & yogurt sauce. The potion was good and the taste was heaven. I'm very picky about my lamb and when bit into the juicy meat, I was utterly impressed. The vegis were cooked but not overcooked and the potatoes with bacon...oh my. 

Did I mention dessert?
We had the panacotta with raspberry sauce. The sauce was perfect (not too sweet) and was the perfect ending to a fantastic dinner.
author: Zoeboe D.

description:
My friends and I came to this restaurant to celebrate an occasion.  The food was excellent, the service was superb, and the details were not missed.  The waiters and waitresses were very nice and attentive to your needs.  

Here is what I had:

Oxtail with Scallops - the oxtail meat was very yummy
Pork Loin with Mac and Cheese - not your average mac and cheese, it was gourmet mac and cheese.  The pork loin was very tender and juicy.
Panna Cotta with Raspberry - YUMMY!

I would definitely go back there again :-)
author: Annie S.

description:
This is one of my favorite bay area restaurants.  The owner, John has put together a great wine list.  The prices are very reasonable.  I love the cheeseburger over there.  The skirt steak is fantastic as well.  

One of my favorite things is the variety of butters and sauces that comes with the bread.  

Other yelpers have commented on the mac and cheese.  The pork loin comes with mac and cheese.  If I don't order the pork loin, I always order the mac and cheese on the side.
author: Robert I.

description: I ate here with three girlfriends this week and had a lovely time.  The server was also the owner and he was the NICEST person.  They really accommodated two pregnant ladies, one breast-feeding vegetarian who brought her newborn baby, and one other Mom.  The server gave us an out of the way table that he told us they used to use when his baby was just born and that they are very family friendly being a family member himself.  Well we found this unusual but were thankful!  I guess the Richmond also prides themselves on being a neighborhood restaurant even though they seem very upscale.  I mean it isn't Applebee's.  None of us ladies could have alcoholic beverages so I had hot decaf tea and everyone else stuck with water.  The Richmond had some tasting menus that we all decided to try, and the server said since it was slow he could accommodate us if we wanted to switch anything out.  I started with the polenta and scallop, and I also ordered an extra salad of pear, blue cheese and greens because I could not choose!  The other option was the crab cake and I don't know how I didn't order that as well.  I was very impressed with both my appetizers!  My main course was duck in a port wine sauce I think with some vegetables and mashed potatoes.  By now I was very full but I wanted to eat so much of this!  The duck literally fell off the bone as soon as I touched it slightly with my fork.  I am not kidding the duck just fell apart at the slightest nudge.  I had my entrée wrapped up for me as I wanted to save room for the dessert of chocolate cake with peanut butter.  I of course really liked this but was still full.  I was really doing pregnant women everywhere a disservice with how full I became so quickly.  The server/owner later brought down his daughter who is now 10, and she shyly said "hi" to us.  What a cute and nice little girl!  I absolutely loved this place and it's a shame I don't live nearby.  If I lived close I would frequent this place a lot.  Service and food were equally amazing.  Parking in this area is tough but you make do.
author: Beep B.

description: I really don't want to share my neighborhood secret, but this restaurant is simply outstanding. They won me over yet again last night with a delicious meal. Who would imagine you could make cod fantastic, but chef John Owyang wowed me yet again with a savory cod dish over grilled squid and red cabbage that outshined any other cod I've ever eaten. I was quickly reminded of a monkfish dish I enjoyed a couple years ago - the first and only monkfish I've ever eaten that was absolutely scrumptious, sweet and surprisingly light and refreshing - completely unlike the rubbery, gooey monkfish I've had at other restaurants. And how can one tie together a dinner for two consisting of cod and braised short ribs? ...with the perfect Oregon Pinot suggested by our amazing server. A fantastic meal.
author: Jen O.

description: I took my girlfriend out for our 5 year anniversary and the experience was delightful. The staff was very attentive and knowledgeable about the food and wine choices. We ended up ordering the prefix menu which was 4 courses and I had a Pinot Noir with the meal that came out to around $120 or so. The portions are huge for being prefix and the only hiccup we came across during our meal was the steak. We usually have our steaks medium-rare but it felt like it came out medium-well as our jaws were getting tired after chewing on a couple pieces of meat. Overall, the price was very reasonable and not too outrageous for a restaurant of this caliber. If you ask me if the experience is worth it, I'd answer yes because we got to try some unique dishes and it didn't break the bank.
author: Yoth K.

description:
I've been here twice, the last time this last Friday. Arrived at 9:30 (had a reservation) and the restaurant had just a few other people in it (it was close to closing time after all). For starters we ordered the blue soft shell crab, which was delicious. Our entrees were pork loin with macaroni and cheese and a spring vegetable lasagna. Both entrees were delicious. The lasagna used many different types of vegetables, including broccoli, squash, and mushrooms, so it had a great variety of textures. My girlfriend really liked her pork and mac & cheese. From my taste the pork was tender and sweet.

For desert we had a raspberry custard of some kind, which was wonderful. Tart raspberry sensation washed cooled down by the cool custard. Yum.

The service is also very good. The ambiance is pretty low-key, quiet, and intimate. The space is very small, but they use curtains to separate some of the tables in a way that makes the space feel even more intimate. Overall this is a great neighborhood restaurant.
author: Jose L.

description: Small, cute place.  I used the Open Table feature on Yelp to make reservations and it worked out beautifully.  The big winner was the squash and celery root soup and the duck confit.  Get those!
author: beck l.

description:
This is the best restaurant in the Richmond district, hands down. The cheeseburger is one of the best in the city and should win the San Francisco Magazine award. All the main dishes are fantastic and flavorful. The wine selection is great, and very well priced. Also, the staff and chef/owner are very friendly. 

Overall great scene and great prices = a must go!
author: Ryan B.

description: Wow what a place! Each time I come here I am blown away. First, the bread comes with three different butters...an olive tapenade butter, a sea salted butter, and an herb butter. I ordered the oxtail and scallops for an appetizer. Wow...the richness of the oxtail was perfect with the scallops. I also ordered the hangar steak which came with spinach and puff pastery wrapped Brie. Mmmmmm absolutely delish! And for dessert, I ordered the poptart which was filled with strawberries. It's not your mom's poptart. It was bigger, flakier, and 20 times better. Staff was friendly, decor was nice. Its an upscale ace, so no loud parties. But its perfect for a romantic dinner. Parking can be difficult and since the place is kinda small, I highly recommend making a reservation. Check it out if you can.
author: Jan Z.

description:
This is a 3.5 not a 3. The food is good and the service very helpful...the chef walks around to see if you have any questions and if everything is ok. I thought this was a nice touch and easily done in this very intimate small setting! 
With respect to the physical building, they have not put much into the decorations, though they do have some nice unique touches such as floor length drapes to shut off certain areas for privacy.
The menu however leaves a bit to be desired. The choice of starters is great, but the entrees are a bit unusual and the choice not plentiful. However as I said above, the food is good, so I would recommend checking this place out.
author: Michelle C.

description: What a find!   This place blew our socks off.   Fantastic food, incredible wine selection (at prices that can't be beat), and attentive, knowledgeable servers.  Don't be shy asking for their recommendations, especially off the wine list.  The ambience is very quaint, with a neighborhood feel.  This is a small establishment which seats maybe 45 people tops.  The chef came out and spoke with us for a few minutes, and our server John was most polite and very well versed in his wine recommendations.  The biggest surprise to me was the value - for the level of culinary delight, presentation and service, we left feeling that The Richmond was truly a bargain!  Can't wait to go back again.  One last note - you must try the apple turnover with cinnamon ice cream for dessert...   it's to die for.
author: Dennis F.

description:
I ordered an appetizer and an entree and was a confirmed member of the clean plate club.  I'm usually a small eater, but I couldn't help but finish everything in front of me.  I ordered the flat-bread with goat cheese, spinach, and italian sausage as an appetizer (might be a wee bit salty for some, but perfect for me), and the chicken roti with bread stuffing and fall vegetables as the entree.  Perfection.  The chicken was juicy and flavorful and while some might find the skin a little fatty, again it was perfect for me.  The stuffing was deliciously buttery and I even ate all my veggies!
We ordered a bottle of Pinot Noir from Oregon that was nice and mellow and went well with both of my dishes as well as my dad's oysters and hanger steak.
The service was terrific as well.  Genuinely nice and friendly and perfectly on time.
A wonderful gem.
author: Caitlin P.

description:
Environmentally friendly?  I think not.  An environmentally friendly restaurant should, almost by definition, have a vegetarian entree option.  This one does not (or at least did not when I visited last weekend).  Fortunately, I am not actually a vegetarian, but I am very fussy about my meat, and when I inquired about the producer of the restaurant's meat, I was told-- *gasp*-- that some of their beef comes from Harris Ranch.  Now, like I said, I eat meat.  But I don't eat tortured-cow, feed-lot-produced, water-polluting, smell-it-for-miles-around beef.   With Niman Ranch producing beef in the Bay Area and Prather Ranch distributing in the Bay Area, there is really no excuse for Harris Ranch.  Yikes.  

As far as the other food was concerned, I thought it was OK.  Service was a little snarky (but I guess the server could have been offended by my reaction to the Harris Ranch news).  Decent wine list.  On the whole, I won't go back.
author: Chris P.

description:
Okay, I can't stop raving about The Richmond. On a random Wednesday evening, I dropped in here, sweatpants and baseball hat clad with a friend to grab a bite to eat. I didn't know what a scrumptious meal I had waiting for me. The hanger steak with goat cheese fondue potatoes is to die for, and at $19.95 a steal since it is a ton of food! The wine list is amazing -- tasty and reasonable, and the atmosphere is a small, neighborhood bistro somewhere. The chef comes out after the meal to see how it was, and my friend, who's been there a few times, totally was treated as the most regular customer. I was impressed!! 

 The fact that this wonderful spot is in the Richmond, and not the Marina or Pac Heights makes it all the better -- like your own little secret jewel. The Richmond is a great place to grab a wonderful meal, without breaking the bank, but still feel like you are having a night out.
author: Misha G.

description:
want to give 4 and a half stars but am rounding down.  Food is good but portions are smaller than expected for the price.  

good decor for the neighborhood.  cozy, if you want privacy, there are tables tucked away, so ask the waiter
author: Ariel W.

description:
My boyfriend and I were looking for a place that was new to the both of us so I went onto Yelp for a recommendation.  The reviews were really good so we gave it a try.  Opentable rez was a bonus.  Decent location.  

Let's cut to the chase.  The food was fantastic.  Soft shell crab on lettuce was great as was the seasonal tomato/avocado salad.  Regarding entrees, we both finished our plates clean.  He got the monk fish (which was excellent) and I got the chicken roti (yum! it had croutons soaked in this great sauce).  To top off the meal, we ordered the peach crumble w/ cinnamon ice cream - again, not a drop of food left.   I second the statements about the butter - olive, chive, and sea salt.  I don't want to hype this place up too much but it was yummy.
author: L M.

description: Our neighborhood go to place. Among the best burgers in San Francisco. And some of the finest elegant dishes you'll treat yourself to in a totally simple neighborhood location. We walk down to The Richmond on a weekend evening. John, the owner and Chef, visits tables to check in and explain preparation. Wine list is terrific. When you visit a City any city, you want the hotel concierge to refer you to a neighborhood place just like The Richmond. It's a story you'll tell when you go home. Just as we do, and we're around the corner.
author: Walter C.

description: Nice and intimate.  Maybe not so great for a group spot, but definitely a place for some getting away.  The food was good I thought and one of the only disadvantages is parking on the street.  Looking forward to the chance when I can come back here again.
author: Brian Y.

description:
what a really neat spot!  this spot continues to fan the flame of my frustration with my "new" neighborhood - the inner sunset.  not so new anymore - 1.5 years ago i bought a house in the inner sunset after renting in the inner richmond for 3 years. the positives of the sunset is that they have more quality all around with their restaurants.  the "neighborhood" places are just better, i think.  fireside is a better bar than the bitter end.  park chow and bistro 9 and pacific catch are better than ... well, i don't even know a spot to compare them to.  actually Q and georgio's are both good but it's too little too late. anyway.  on the other hand, the richmond has FINE dining that is just totally absent from my hood.  Clementine (under-rated), Chapeau (good food but you feel like you're in someone's bathroom), and now The Richmond.  

getting their ingredients from local, sustainable, organic farms. decorating their walls with interesting art.  and at the same time giving that neighborhood feel.  when i couldn't find a parking spot (usually not a problem in that area) they told us to just park in the driveway of their building.  cool.  

their oxtail and scallop appetizer was amazing.  a must, i'd say - but huge!  it's like ordering another entree.   the fish and steak dishes we ordered were stellar but since they seem to change their menu every so often, i don't think they are on the menu anymore.  obviously, these are very good restaurant owners and it's only a matter of time before they get an investor and relocate this gem to a more commercially viable location (like downtown or soma) and raise the prices.  so enjoy the place while they still have a lease and while they are still here.
author: dan h.

description:
What a surprise, as I don't find myself meandering the inner streets of balboa or anza or anything south of Geary Blvd. actually. 
A friend and I got together for dinner after a short walk through the park as she lives around Fulton and 9th., so nice to stroll down through the park on a beautiful night and to my surprise walk to dinner? I'm thinking what could possibly be around here! Well I will tell you, an incredible find which I can't wait to make my 2nd home away from home. They start with a small seafood offering (on the house) puff pastry holding the succulent creamy mixture and for my friend who is not eating wheat or seafood for that matter, creamy potato, leek soup (cold) now this little delight has no cream and you would never know it, I say it has to have butter it is so good. ??? Don't know. I'd been cravin a burger and usually won't give in when the menu is so enticing, but every one says they are really great, so I give in to my desire... our waiter asks med rare? I say oh yeah. J orders the chicken without the wheat breading but it has already been preped (they did is special for before NICE) so she inquired about the Red Wine Braised short ribs.
Now if you are squemish about rare meat, you will want to order yours med as this was rare, which is ok with me when it is really good meat which it was. The buns were really buttery like a dinner roll piled high with all the fixins and fries to die for. As my girlfriend is french, I was thinking ohhh she is gonna love these. A 5 star burger for sure.
Now the short ribs, so tender with the most delicious wine sauce a nice prortion as well sittin atop taters that have been whiped into submission with a health portion of cream and butter, (from the looks of them) accompanied by steamed baby veges.
The venue is intimate, has a bar(which is really inviting and you can eat there when their packed) and the staff feels like family.
This is a hidden gem which all should experience, repeatedly.
Congrats, Richmond on a job well done!
author: dana s.

description:
Awesome! We've been meaning to try this place for awhile being somewhat new to the 'hood and REALLY enjoyed our meal - we will be regulars in no time. I feel like we can splurge there without breaking the bank. John, the chef and owner I believe checked in on us to see how we were doing. Ian, our waiter, was awesome - and the bread and soup they bring out to whet your taste buds were great as well!

A lot of places in the city are a scene without a lot of substance - this place is the opposite.
