They offer quality food, a VERY diverse and reasonable wine list, fabulous, friendly and attentive waitstaff for very reasonable places - all in all - a place we look forward to enjoying over and over!
author: Kimberley Y.

description:
This is my new favourite neighbourhood restaurant, and I don't even live in the neighbourhood. My wife lost the gift certificate to my first choice restaurant for my birthday dinner, so I searched yelp for a place close to our baby sitter's house, and The Richmond sounded promising. 

When we dropped our baby off, the sitter waxed enthusiastic about the place, so we went in with high expectations. We weren't disappointed. The amuse-bouche -  a crab won ton -  was excellent, and the bread and flavoured butters were delicious as well. I had the oxtail and scallop appetizer. I was a little worried that the oxtail would overpower the scallops, but the dish was well balanced, melt-in-your-mouth rich, and delicious. My wife had the beet salad, and she said it was good, but I'll never know 'cause she wouldn't share.

We both had the hanger steak - one thing I have learned is always order the steak. Since I began following this rule, I have never suffered from entree envy. The meat was perfecty cooked, rich and full of flavour; the kind of dish where the first bite makes me a little sad because I know it has to end soon. The wine selection was decent and reasonably priced. My only regret was that we didn't have the appetite for the full tasting menu, but we will be back.

Service and food were great, prices were quite reasonable for San Francisco - I mean, La Folie and the Dining Room were good, but not four times as good. I can't wait to come back.
author: Bill F.

description: Came here on 9/13 for dinner. Very Cosy restaurant. I thought it would be an upscale place but it's more like a hole in the  wall fine dining restaurant. Looks kind of run down as though no one has fixed it. Maybe part of the theme? We ordered the 5 and 3 course fix prix meal. The butternut squash soup was good. Tasted sweet but paired well with pine nuts. The beet salad was refreshing. Next, we got Corn & Brioche Custard with Sweet Corn Sauce. Too sweet. Not the greatest. I had Meatball Roti with a Potato Purée. I couldn't  finish it as it was too tough to eat.  My husband got the braise oxtail with scallop. Was good but I felt the food was nothing special. it's  been 2 days yet I still cant recall all the food I had. Would probably not come here again and would not recommend to anyone else. This place is family own business with the owner's wife, nice, mother all working there. All though service was very good, I felt that it was intense as showed by the owner being the bartender, waitress and server. Same goes for the wife as she was the server, cook and waitress. For the price we paid, I would rather have a restaurant be more organize.
author: Amy L.

description: I had the best experience at this restaurant it reminded me of the cartoon Ratatouille in a way. It's everything you want in an intimate setting, the service was superb and the food was mouthwatering.  We started with the best glass of Riesling wine by Dr. Loosen the king of Riesling's.  The palate cleanser was refreshing. I got to try the starters Leek Soup and Seared Scallops over Oxtail and Polenta, I would have been satisfied with just that, but oh there is more; for the entree I had the steak with a delicious crepe. It was very satisfying and the deserts were also good the chocolate torte is well worth the wait. I highly recommend this place it is a hidden gem. Loved it!
author: Sara J.

description:
very intimate dining.  red-maroon drapes, quiet conversation all around, even the waiter was very soft spoken.

delicious mac n cheese with pork tenderloin... but the best dish was the appetizer:  scallop over ox-tail, mmm...
author: Ethan L.

description: This place is AWESOME. A perfect place to have a special date night. To start the night, they have some great collection of wines. The chef let us try some wines before we decided to pick one. The chef prepared some complimentary salad for us, when he realized that the servers were not prompt in taking our order. And then he personally brought the main course and came by to make sure that everything was going well. Best of all, the food was sooooo fresh and yummy.
author: Kanwal A.

description: What a wonderful restaurant!  My coworkers and I were looking for a delicious place close to UCSF to have wine after work, and guided by such positive Yelp reviews, we decided to try out The Richmond.  The staff were sophisticated, attentive, and friendly.  We weren't hungry for dinner and only had a (delicious and affordable) bottle of wine with salads, but they treated us as they did all of their customers.  Their wine list is diverse and accessible, the food creative and inviting, and the service is as good as it gets.  Go ahead and take the bus/bike/car ride to this awesome, underrated spot!  Oh, did I mention the chef himself came out to see how we were enjoying our meal? The Richmond really knows how to make you want to come back for seconds.
author: Nora S.

description: Wonderful.  I can't think of any thing else to say.  I lived near by for 10 years and never went there. Lucky my old roommate thought of this place on my visit home.
author: Randy K.

description: Went here for a birthday dinner. My friend and I decided to try the 50.00 tasting menu, which consisted of a beet salad, an heirloom tomato salad, beef short ribs, and lamb, and then ended with a dessert. We started of with some amazing bread with olive butter and chive butter, and it was so delicious! Such a nice touch. In between courses they brought out teeny tiny "palate cleansers," which all were very tasty. The food was delicious, and the server was excellent. The chef came out to thank us for our patronage. There are only two complaints, both rather significant but not enough to make me not like the place. While the food was delicious, the portions were TINY. I am not sure of the tasting menu is the only thing that comes with small, I mean SMALL, portions, but for 50.00 I feel like it was kind of a rip off. I am not for huge portions, but I think this was a bit ridiculous... it was almost funny when they brought them out. The other thing is that we got there at 8pm, and left at 10:30pm, because the courses were taking forever to come out. When the chef came out he thanked us for our patience, so maybe this isn't a normal thing. If we were on a schedule it would have been annoying. BUT- I am sticking with 4 stars because the food was delicious, and the service was wonderful. Lastly, the wine by the glass that I had was decently priced and very, very good. I would probably go back to try the regular menu items just to see if the size is any different. Cheers!
author: Thea G.

description: This cozy little restaurant was a pleasant surprise.  Nestled away on Balboa between 6th and 7th aves this well hidden gem packs a punch!  The appetizers that you've gotta try is the foie gra and scallops served with braised oxtail.  They also serve a pretty mean burger, as well as fried chicken dish.  Service was good, nothing spectacular but had a pretty good overall experience.
author: Phil Y.

description: The prix fixe menu with wine pairings on Jan. 9 was worth every penny. I was focused more on enjoying the food rather than remembering details for this review, so I just have to give the whole meal and service a blanket thumbs up. I do remember a delicious pumpkin soup somewhere in the mix.
author: Keith K.

description:
Here's the deal -- John Owyang runs a great place (I've heard whispers of expansion). He's always available to chat with diners in the cozy dining room. The food is, in short, absolutely stunning. I'm more of a fish guy these days (although I had the burger tonight -- more info below), and I had the arctic char there 3 weeks ago.  I always remember char as a nasty bony oily fish while growing up; here, it was perfect. Their own tagline of 'euro-influenced organic California cuisine' hits it on the head; all is fresh and un-drowned in heavy sauces. In the past, I've also had the chicken and a beef dish (not what's currently on the menu), and both were superlative. The potato and leek soup was about as creamy as you could imagine, and all of their salads rock, too. Desserts are not an after-thought, though not the main reason to go here. The wine list covers the cheaper end well (the Benton Lane oregon pinot is a great deal) and though I'm not a wine snob, I'm told the selection they have at the higehr end is to die for. Can't see dropping $300 on a sauternes for dessert anytime soon, but if I do get a yen to do that, I'm coming here first. 

They always have a great amuse-bouche too -- nothing where you're cracking up laughing at the logistics you think you need to eat it, and nothing as 'ok, i guess we gotta do this' as Nopa's radish and butter --- it's always been a perfect curtain-raiser.

Finally, the burger. That's what I just had tonight. For less than $10, you get a perFECT half-pound burger, with a great sharp cheddar on a perfect brioche bun. You get a 'large' order of julienned fries (REAL fries are friggin' cut-up potatoes in hot oil -- whatever motherf***er decided we couldn't handle that and figured they needed a coating to be 'special' should be forced to eat hot-dog-and-curly-fries smoothies forever and ever, amen) . You get three small dishes of condiments, all house-made -- a great aoli, a spicy ketchup and a dijon mustard. THIS IS THE BEST DEAL IN TOWN. It's my lock of the week...

A perfect reasonably priced Friday night date? Go to the DeYoung Museum (now $5 on Fridays), watch the sun set from the observation tower, then head over 2 blocks to The Richmond. Split a salad, have 2 burgers, a glass of wine each and split a dessert. If this doesn't make low-cost magic for you, then you, my friend, may already be dead and stiff.

I ate here when they first opened up, and I was worried -- there were a lot of empty seats. But it's now tough to get a reservation. Don't say I didn't tell you.
author: T C.

description:
We had eaten there several times and been more than satisfied.  Last weekend, we were disappointed.  The place continues to be a little gem in our neighborhood with wonderful owners and a most pleasant staff.  The pace of service is just right.

This time however, the food wasn't very good.  Two of us had the "Shake and Bake Chicken with Richmond Rice A Roni."  It was boring, almost flavorless.  The other dishes were a step down from what we had expected.  We won't give up on The Richmond, but hope that their performance next time is better.

Note : The wine list continues to be excellent with prices lower than any place I know in town.
author: Larry H.

description: Most of the reviews of the Richmond refer to it as a neighborhood gem and I couldn't agree more.  I had dinner here last week and it was outstanding-the meal started with an amuse bouche of hot apple cider topped with whipped cream (perfect on a cold evening)  My main course was scallops served with braised ox tail over polenta-so yummy!   So why only four stars?  There was some serious gaps in our service...once seated we sat for a good 10-15 minutes before our waiter approached us.  And we also sat with our meals finished for another 10-15 minutes with dirty plates in front of us.  That being said, I would return to The Richmond without hesitation and if I lived in the neighborhood I have a feeling I'd be a regular.
author: phil h.

description: My husband took me here for dinner and we shared 1 appetizer, 2 entrees, and a half-bottle of wine for $65 (pre-tip)!  It was such a nice meal and the service was excellent.  We, too, loved the amuse bouche and the fact that the chef comes around and even serves some of the food.  I had the vegetable pie which was fantastic and my husband had the fried chicken.  Highly recommend this little spot!
author: Sara B.

description: Excellent food- the pan fried chicken was divine. a really great restaurant to catch up with friends I hadn't seen in a long time
author: Tricia R.

description:
This is a find

We found this listing in Zagat. Everything they said was true. You get a fantastic meal for the price of many other places around serving up 1/2 the effort. Great concentrated flavors, great attention to detail without being fussy. Friendly staff. Highly recommended
author: Peter G.

description:
I had been trying to get into this place for weeks without success, and finally took a late reservation for 9pm because it is all that ever seems to be available. Of course, I am the guy who calls the night of and hopes to sneak a reserve in at 7 or 8pm. 

The space itself is really intimate and cozy, perfect spot for myself and my lovely lady to get all romantical. Anyone looking to wow a date with a neat and cozy restaurant off the beaten path this place is a real jewel that will surely impress the pants off...well, lets not get ahead of ourselves here.

I am late again on this review so specific items are not coming to me but the food here was really well done. I do remember for main course I had the Bavette Steak and it was VERY well prepared. I remembered thinking what a prefectly prepared piece of beef it was. We tasted a few of the appetizer choices and each were delectable. The one thing that I really liked was the wine list offers a full spectrum of choices from affordable to break the bank which I think shows some serious depth. Not all places have a varied selection like this and I really think that is nice. 

Service was decent yet not overly special but the atmosphere itself well but made up for it. Overall I say this place is a definite must for date night, give it a whirl and if you don't get lucky, well, don't blame The Richmond because it did all it could!
author: The M.

description: This place is delicious, romantic, and really reasonably priced. I have been here three times, it's been great for a romantic dinner or a double date.  The atmosphere is classy, warm and cozy, which is comforting when the Inner Richmond gets to be chilly. Also, every time I have come here, the chef has come out and said hello.
author: Masha B.

description: So I wasn't expecting much when we ventured to The Richmond (no offense to the Richmond in general). It's in my girlfriend's old hood so I though maybe she was just feeling a little nostalgic and wanted to relive some of the glory that her time there brought. To say the least I was happily surprised. The chef came by a few times to check in on us and the waitstaff did a great job making sure that we were happy. Food was solid and the atmosphere was good. We grabbed an early dinner and the place really started to pick up so apparently word is getting around.
author: Russ T.

description: This place is terrible. The waiter was extremely rude and the food was average at best. I emailed the owner twice to voice my complaint but did not even get a reply.  Stay away.
author: Brian H.

description:
I know my experience in the Bay Area is improving more and more each day, because every review I write lately is 4 stars!  The Richmond definately has contributed to my growing love for my neighborhood, The Richmond District, as well as with the city overall.

This is a very intimate and cozy little place on Balboa, and they always take your coat and hang it for you when you come in (its the small things that count).  It is pretty quiet inside usually, which may have been a problem when my friends and I were here, because we are kind of loud.  Especially after a bottle of wine.  But nobody said anything or made us feel less than welcome.

The food was great!  I had a salad with mixed greens, blue cheese, and cranberries (I think), which was off the HOOK.  For the main course, I had the steak, which in itself was great, but also it comes over a brie and spinich filled flakey pastry thing...wow.  Not to mention their BREAD and butters...

This paired with great wine and good company, you cannot go wrong.
author: Jessi C.

description:
Incredible service + great food + multiple visits by the chef/owner = a perfect date night dining experience. This place is definitely a hidden gem. Parking can be tricky in this neighborhood, but it is definitely worth it. We opted for the sweet breads, potato leek soup, and the bleu cheese salad to start off. Plus two entrees (I got the burger....a serious Zuni competitor for less $), and a dessert (we shared their chocolate ice cream sandwich), a beer, a drink and a coffee (french press...the good stuff)...and the grand total was somewhere in the $63 range. An incredible deal for the quality of food and the impeccable service we received. While the space is small, the way it's set up (two dining rooms joined together), you could definitely rent one room out for a group dinner. On a side note, one of the most unique beer lists I've ever seen. This place is all about quality over quantity...
We had an early dinner, but by the time we left, the place started picking up, and diners were waiting to be seated. So be sure to make your reservations in advance. Thankfully, they're on Open Table.
author: Marie M.

description: I'm so happy that I finally tried this place after months of curiosity. My boyfriend and I made an 8:15 reservation for a Saturday night, and when we arrived a little early they were able to seat us right away. We even got to sit at the private, curtained-off table by the window. I brought my own bottle of wine (for sentimental reasons) and our waiter was happy to decant it. We shared two appetizers: crab cakes, and oxtail with scallops and polenta. Both were delicious! The crab cakes were very flavorful, crunchy on the outside and flaky on the inside. But the braised oxtail was amazing! The combination of the tender meat with the chewy scallops, fused together with a delicious sauce over a creamy polenta was heavenly. Onto the entrees, he had the bacon wrapped steak and I had the spinach and mushroom stuffed quail with potato hash. The quail was juicy and tender, and very filling for such a small bird. I had a bite of the steak and it was also delicious. We were too full for dessert (though, the options were mouth-watering) but our waiter brought us cookies anyway. A nice touch! We will definitely be back for more!
author: Kelsey M.

description: My boyfriend and I were merely walking by this place, poked our heads in, and the owner practically forced us to sit down for a beer. (and yes, I loved every second of it) Great location for a casual, yet upscale, foodie restaurant...can't think of anything like it west of Geary. Free beer and chocolate yumminess  at 10:45 pm will definitely get me back in the door. They've been open for 7 weeks now, seat 37, and John (the owner) said they've been full nearly every night. Everything is produced "in house" and all food is bought from local farmers. I'm a fan already.
author: jodes l.

description: Went here for NYE after we've been wanting to try it for a while.  The meal was everything we'd hoped for and more.  We ordered the crab & arugula salad, braised oxtail and scallops, foie gras, the rack of lamb, and the hanger steak.  Each was absolutely delicious - we enjoyed every bite and had a hard time deciding our favorites.  The service was impeccable, and the atmosphere was beautiful, inviting, and comfortable.  The wine list was extensive and impressive and not overly marked up like most are.  To top it all off, the prices can't be beat.  $100 for 5 courses and two glasses of wine.  We can't wait to go back.
author: Mary C.

description: Romantic setting, fantastic service, great food. It'll impress your date on this hole-in-the-wall gem. Wish the menu would be more extensive and parking would be easier!
author: P S.

description: What a great find!  My boyfriend got a $100 gift certificate to The Richmond for his birthday.  We decided to check it out last Friday and it blew away my expectations.  First, the food is absolutely delightful and gourmet in every aspect.  We had a perfectly flash fried soft shell crab over a bed of season greens and a foie gras dish that was sinfully good.  For entree, the lamb chop and halibut continued to impress.  We finished off with equally amazing dessert.  All of this plus a glass of exceptional pinot noir for $100 (before tip).  Bottomline, the entire experience is on par with 5 star restaurants like Quince, Boulevard etc.. but 1/2 the cost.  An affordable weekend treat!
author: Judy C.

description:
great food and pretty dam good service. i only knock one star due long wait even after our reservation.

well worth the trip out to the sticks (just kidding, it aint that far, suck it up) but leave some time to look for parking.
author: Mattew W.

description: Soooo good!  The Richmond is a great neighborhood place to take a date or visiting parents.  It's small, so make a reservation and don't show up too early cause there is not really any entryway to wait!  Their wine list is great and the staff is very knowledgable about the wines.  The owner/chef even comes to everyone's table to checkin and is genuinely concerned that you enjoy your dining experience.  I recommend the flat iron steak - cooked perfectly!
author: Bridget G.

description: This is a great place for the Richmond District! Finally something yummy and fun where so many people live.  They're food is pretty good, especially if you're into seafood.  Very fresh fish and they were getting pretty creative with their sauces.  Not overaly priced but I'm sure the "wine bar" title allows a little bump in the dishes.  The wine they had were different than what you usually see out there.  I'm nots sure if they're special or :"good wines" but they were different and I apprecited trying some thing different.  Had a New Zealand Pinot and it was rather crisp and savory.  Check it out if you're around the Richmond.
author: Grace K.

description: Excellent neighborhood restaurant.  Great feel and service.  The food was very good.  We had the tomato appetizers and I had the steak and my wife had fish.  Everything was great and they have a very nice wine list.  The owner/chef came to our table to check in with us and was very concerned that everyone was happy.  Definitely give this place a try if you are in the neighborhood.
author: C M.

description: Wonderful!  My fiance and I went after finding it on Citysearch (before I found out about Yelp) and we absolutely loved it!  the interior is nicely appointed with artwork and big silk drapes, yet it is far from stuffy.  As some others have mentioned, the manager welcomed us when we arrived and stopped by to offer us a free appetizer (a deviled egg with caviar-Delicious).  Our main courses were wonderful, it's been a few months since we went, so I don't remember what we had, but they were both stunning.  The waiter was very helpful with our wine pairing, and the manager even poured us some lovely port (complimentary) to go with our desert.  All in all, we felt truly pampered and had a lovely night!  I would recommend it to anyone except I don't want it to get crowded!
author: Nica W.

description: This is a great, off-the-beaten path restaurant suitable for a date. The food is always excellent, as is the wine list.  The service is also quite good.  I recommend the dumpling soup, especially, which is a won-ton like substance in a warm broth with rice.
author: Greg T.

description:
1. Service is nice/friendly/fast and food is fresh. Started out  with high hopes.
2. Suprisingly large portion on my entree.
3. The food is trying to be really good but it feels a bit clumsy.  My cream of artichoke soup was too rich for the delicate flavor of the artichoke; the pork loin was a little tough, the beans were underdone.  
4. But some items were outstanding, the amuse bouche that we were given was delightful, the selection of butters for the bread was a nice touch, the beet salad was a favorite.
5.  Wine by glass selection could have been more interesting.
6. I was going to give four stars out of benefit of a doubt, since I assumed they were a little newer than they really were, but now I see from other reviews they'd been there a couple years.  I'm not really feeling it for the prices. It's nice to have another bistro alternatve, but they really  need to bring their game up a notch if they're going to compete with the Clementines of the world.  
7. To sum up, you'll get a decent meal, but to me it's not  special occasion worthy or anything like that.  Get a burger and beer and some dessert, you'll be happy.
author: jette s.

description:
excellent spot. the food and service were both very good. we had the cheese plate, steak and halibut. then we went for the chocolate peanut butter thing and the raspberry cream thing.  everything was delicious. this place really packed up quick, so make a reservation. we had all this and a bottle of the bubbly and our total bill was $94.00  not too bad at all.  In case you didn't know, i'm more of a taqueria/vietnamese sandwich/thai/indian  type o dude. usually my total bill for two is $12-$40 but we wanted to try something nice and this was well worth it. plus they named it "the richmond" after one of my favorite neighborhoods in the city.
  update: the burger is super delicious too ($9.95).. comes with cheese and the house made ketchup and aeoli..
author: Pflip W.

description:
The Lumberjack, being a few years older than me and therefore *really* feeling the friends getting married/having kids pressure, doesn't hold back telling me things even if they may be inappropriate for her brother or random strangers sitting in a restaurant.  To wit: we went to The Richmond for dinner last night, and while sipping our second bottle of wine and just having finished our amuse bouche of brie with apple on a little biscuity thing, she launches into a story about the bachelorette party she hosted last weekend.  Now, keep in mind that The Richmond is *small* and it being a Wednesday night was not very crowded.  Even a whisper can be heard by those sitting around you.  Suffice it to say that the last thing I needed to hear going into the appetizers was about a bunch of 30-something women (Lumberjack included) playing pin the cock on the hunk and a guessing game involving the penis sizes of their significant others.  Suffice it to say that what I needed to hear even less (now going into main entrees) was an argument that broke out amongst the girls as to what defines a small, average, or large penis size and then being asked how I would define it.  This is my sister.  She's asking me about penis size.  Can we say uncomfortable? 
Luckily for me, two bottles of great wine, great apps and entrees, not to mention some *really* great desserts, will always help ease the awkwardness that the Lumberjack sometimes puts me in.  And luckily for me, two bottles of wine (plus some drink when I got home) helped me go right to sleep instead of tossing and turning with an image of pin the cock on the hunk burning a hole in my brain.
author: Zev K.

description:
This place exemplifies what it means to take care of your customers.  I should probably have come here a couple more times before writing this, but in the interest of saving money and jotting down as much of the details as possible before my memory begins to fade, I'm going to have to base this review on the lone spectacular visit I had here.

I arrived just in time for my reserved time, but our table was not ready yet.  We were invited to sit down at the bar.  My girlfriend and I each had a glass of wine.  The wait was maybe 20 minutes, but we hardly noticed because we were really enjoying our wine.  Once we were seated, it occurred to me that I hadn't tipped the person at the bar.  I went up to do so, and he said it was no problem, that they all get a share.  

The food was succulent.  The presentation and texture of the dishes we ordered was great.  The portions were the right amount.  The bread was fresh.  We were attended to with impeccable detail, with someone who looked like he was from the kitchen walking by to ask us how things were going and personally thanking us for coming.  We were given free dessert afterward as an expression of thanks for our patience waiting for our table.  To our surprise, they even threw in the wines for free.

I had to leave them a huge tip for that.  Never has my glass of water been kept so full other than at Harris' Restaurant.  That's how impressive their service was.  That really made our evening.
author: Stephen N.

description: I recently ate here after visiting the De Young Museum and an investment relations seminar/discussion. The menu I chose from was fixed but still regular items served seasonally..... To start I had the braised ox tail over pollenta with 2 scallops on top. WOW!! I could have just eaten this all day, the polenta was creamy, the ox tail was juicy and the scallops were perfectly cooked. For my main course I got the pain fried chicken which was lackluster and a little too oily for my taste. The veggies were good but the stuffing was a little soggy in my opinion. Dessert was a cup of Coffee Semifreddo which was very good but quite small and the presentation could have been MUCH better. I also tried the homemade cheesecake that left me wanting to take one home! creamy and sweet but with a touch of tartness and strawberries on the side...MMmmmMMM. Over all a good experience, if I was near the park and wanted a nice cozy dinner I'd drop by. Ooo the ambiance was seriously lacking though. The restaurant is smart car tiny, painted all creme with red velvet curtains/wall coverings....I think they could have don a lil more to spruce it up.
author: Sebastien M.

description: We were recommended here by a friend. A little amusee bouche, which was delectable; crab cakes - lovely, foie gras - impeccable; short ribs were OMG good.  After that I couldn't eat any more, so settled for coffee.  Wine selection is short but nice and not too overpriced.  We loved how the little alcoves are set up.  Excellent evening.
author: Cate H.

description: Fabulous hidden gem in the Richmond.  Many of the previous reviews have pretty much said it all.  In general, parking in the area is a "pain," but we had an early dinner and parking wasn't a problem.  I would definitely go back.
author: Uimuim B.

description: We were delighted with our meal at The Richmond. Everything that we tried was delicious. I started with the beet salad and my husband had the split pea soup. They serve warm bread to the table with 3 different kinds of butter. It was really good and we had a hard time stopping to wait for our entrees. We were also really happy with the wine list. It has a huge range in prices, something for everyone. The least expensive bottle was $15 and it went all the way up to $750 a bottle. We chose an inexpensive bottle and were very happy with the results. We decided to share the apple tart for dessert. We are super picky about pie after being raised in a superb pie makers household. It was really delicious. We were impressed that the waiter served 9 tables with the help of one bus person and he was super nice! We plan on returning with friends soon!
author: Rachel M.

description: Gosh, we drank so much I can't remember the food very specifically, but I do remember everything was terrific. The entire party of 12 of us was pleased. The ambiance was nice. Service was outstanding. We had a good time. Worth the money and I would go back.
author: p v.

description:
A great restaurant in the Richmond area.  Quaint spot with nice atmosphere.  

The food is excellent, nice balanced menu, and very reasonably priced.  It has become one of my new favorites.  The bread is great - with 3 types of butter.  We shared 3 very good aps - Sloppy Joes (much better than Mom ever made), Beets/carrot salad, carpaccio.  Try the scallops & short ribs dish (unlikely combo but very good).  We loved the skirt steak as well.

Thoughtful wine list and well priced.  Excellent service and friendly staff.  The chef greeted us and checked in on us later in the meal.

We will be back.  A nice find!
author: Dan L.

description: This place is a diamond in the rough. My wife and I decided to try this place out with a couple of our friends and the whole experience was awesome. Despite the fact the restaurant is small, the ambiance was warm and they did a great job creating private spaces in the restaurant. The husband and wife team provide incredible fare and service at what I would say are award winning prices. Any food lover in the Bay area should check this place out.
author: Mike F.

description: The Richmond was wonderful!  We started with the foie gras appetizer then I had the pork tenderloin with macaroni and cheese and my fiancee had the halibut in a tomato sauce.  Everything was cooked perfectly and the service was impeccable.  I can't wait to go again!
author: D'Arcy C.

description:
recommendo!

great food from start to finish.  we got our dessert wines for free even after we pointed out to them that they weren't included on the bill.  way to get on our good side, by accident or not.
author: brian r.

description:
We had dinner here and we randomly picked this restaurant to try.  We were a little concerned at first at the lack of staff, but ultimately we were seated and ordered.  

The food was fantastic!  If I had several stomachs, I would have tried everything on the menu.   We didn't have enough room for dessert so we will have to to come back another time to try the rest.

The only negative about this place is the lack of parking or valet and the selection.  However, here I would say that quality far outweighs the quantity of items on the menu.
author: Danny S.

description:
Food is really good and the service is perfect. The chef is really nice and offered us a drink and an appetizer while we were waiting for our table. The atmosphere is interesting, it feels that you are in someone's appartment that have weird paintings.
I strongly recommend this restaurant.
author: Romain G.

description: This is a great little spot. We did have a reservation but were seated a little late. Besides that, the experience was excellent! The server was so incredibly kind and helpful, offering much knowledge and suggestions from the wine list. They offered us complimentary melon and mint oil dish. The bread is served warm with 3 varieties of butter. The hierloom tomato salad and cheese dish were deelish. I had the burger (but I like em well done, this was too raw for me). Excellent and kind service. Upscale with out the prices or attitude, great for a comfortable date too.
author: Alyssa C.

description: I was here on a date recently. Came in on a Tuesday and was immediately greeted by a super friendly host and seated at a quiet table near a window. The chef popped out and put a little heater near our table. I ordered the steak which was cooked perfectly. I was tempted by the $9 1/2 lb burger because I heard someone else raving about it. I came back on Saturday to get it to go and enjoyed it immensely along with the thin but mushy frys. This place is right around the corner from me so I'll definitely be coming back.
author: Colin S.

description:
A friendly little neighborhood restaurant.  That part of the Richmond District's quite the same anymore with the addition of this and other new restaurants.
Since they opened in '05 or so, it has became one of my favorite restaurants.  Their menu is not very large, but everything I've tried I enjoyed.
For a restaurant this size, their wine selection is excellent.  The prices on them are very good too.  The chef/owner seem to really know a lot about wine and will chat with you and give you all kinds of suggestions based on what you normally like.
Finally - the food.  The one item that has never left their menu is their half pound cheeseburger.  It's always done the way I like it (medium rare).  I don't know what kind of potatos they use, but I swear, they're the most flavorful fries I've had.  I love that they are presented with homemade ketchup and mayo.
The homemade bread, as a lot of other people have talked about, are heavenly ... made all the more special with the three kinds of butter that they're served with.  I believe they are plain with gray seasalt, parsley butter and olive butter.
John usually comes up with inventive and upscale version of food that I'd never thought to serve together.  His surf & turf (not what he calls it, but my own interpretation) included braised rib (a little boneless ball of the most succulent meat) and perfectly pan seared scallops on creamy polenta.  I'm drolling just thinking about it.
And his dessert ... if you'd never had their homemade ice cream.  You must!
The wait-staff is always knowledgeable and patient.  Roger is probably one of my all time favorite.
author: Winnie C.

description: This is my third time here, which shows that I am a fan.  However, this was my least favorite visit of all of my visits.  I will admit that this was to a quicker meal, so we avoided starters and just ordered the main course.  We also ordered wine and have to say that they really have tweaked their wine list for the current economy.  You can get very reasonable wines but can also splurge if you want.  However, after ordering we sat there for at least 30 minutes.  We received little attention from the waiter and were never given the bread and three option butter that they provide all the tables until we asked right before the meal was brought out.  I went with the flank steak, chefs choice.  Though tasty, it was way to chewy.  This was a 5 star on prior visits.  This time a 3 star, so now I have to settle for 4.
author: Markus S.

description: Our first meal here was exceptional.  My guest and I were personally seated and served by Chef John, and he paired each (delicious) course with a great wine.  The staff here is so friendly and accommodating, and they keep your wine glass full with a good wine selection.  The food, the decor, and the atmosphere could all be described in the same way:  simple, yet elegant, and presented without pretense.  And all at a fairly reasonable price.  I'm looking forward to making another reservation soon.
author: Andrea U.

description: The staff was extremely friendly and gave our group a free dessert. All the desserts are lovely and very flavorful!
author: S O.

description: I really liked the food here, the staff was very attentive, and I like it when the chefs come out to meet their guests.  The chef used to work at the Ritz Carlton and opened up his own restaurant.  It was a real labor of love--you can ask and they'll show you an album of before and after.
author: Kit E.

description:
cute place.  host was rude to me until my friend showed up.  she's an attractive gal, and then all of a sudden, we became the most important people in the room.  fu dude.

amuse bouche: cold, oily lumpia atop a silver dollar sized red leaf lettuce, accompanied with a smear of sweet chilli sauce.  

who the f would want to start off their meal with a cold oily piece-o-shit lumpia that they probably got in bulk from costco.  i guess the microwave was busted too, because it was nasty cold.

sorry, although the main was quite good, you sealed your fate from the start.
author: Curtis Y.

description:
If you're looking for a quiet, intimate place to dine...make your reservation here at the Richmond. After landing a new job, my boyfriend took me here to celebrate. We originally wanted a Sunday night reservation but they were all booked, but had a last minute cancellation that Friday nite, so we took it. This is not your known franchise of fine dinning restaurant, more like a gem in the quiet Richmond neighborhood of San Francisco, owned by John Owyang and his wife. 

Everything from the butter to the dessert was incredible. They serve the typical bread that most restaurants serve, but what's amazing is that they serve the bread with 3 different kinds of butter. Now, I normally try not to eat too much bread before my meal, but the butter was so good...I couldn't help it. Then we got my typical appetizer, Foie Gras. I pretty much try Foie Gras at every single restaurant that I've been to...and this one is up there...definitely leaves you wanting more. We also had the Crab crepe appetizer, another tasty dish. For our main course, we had the pork chop and braised chicken. Normally, I'd go for steak rather than pork, but my boyfriend had recommended it...so I tried it. It was the most tender, mouth watering pork chop I've ever had. It was soo juicy! Now, that's a talented chef. Most pork chops are a little on the dry side...but not this one. I recommend it if you happen to go on the week that they serve it...as their menu change weekly.  Their wine list is amazing. We had a bottle of the 1996  Silver Oak, and it was the perfect choice for our meal. And my favorite part... DESSERT! Try the Chocolate Souffl. So moist. So good! : )   And I love restaurants with chefs that cares about what their customers think....John came out after our meal to see how it was.  The waiter was also very nice, we were the last couple there... it was near 11pm but he was very nice about it. He chatted with us and didn't rush us out of there at all.

Food, Service, Staff, Atmosphere, and last but not least company = 5 star! 

Definitely will come back.
author: Kim D.

description: WONDERFUL little SanFran spot...full blown app/dinner for three (albeit, only 2 glasses of wine,  a tea and one HUGE Panna Cotta for desert...crunchy soft bread and three butters: olive, pesto,salt....a little freebee deviled egg each,  too boot....not bad at all!! ) for $105  TOTAL!!...Decent cave too, but if you want to BYOB I think I saw $20...been to some of the *better* places in town and they really would hard-pressed to give as much quality for the price  as the RIchmond dishes up...
author: Fran M.

description: This little neighborhood restaurant exceeded all my expectations. They brought us an amuse bouche of a deviled egg which was both unexpected and perfect. The warm bread included a beautiful presentation of chive and olive butters. The entree was a perfectly executed hangar steak with delicious sauce and spinach, and the dessert was an inspired combo of warm chocolate cake with a peanut butter center and a scoop of vanilla ice cream. My friend and I stayed there for four hours!! to chat, and no one ever made us fee unwelcome or tried to rush us out. I can't recommend them enough.
author: katherine S.

description: 3 and a half stars.  Very good food overall.  Parking was very hard the night I went.  The steak could have been better but everything else was good (the sides and the appetizers).
author: S. C.

description: Love this place...Feels like home.  The food is exceptional, the wine list is extensive, and they even have a few great beers. Most of all the service is great.  It is always nice to have the owners come out greet their customers.  Can't wait to go back.
author: Michael W.

description:
I've been trying to get a reservation at this place off and on for over a year.
I read in some news article that it was worth the effort.  I finally snagged one at 6:30 this evening.  We got a great table, very private, and the service was great, although I got a feeling they might be spread a tad thin.
The food was sort of French/Nuevo/Americano something...Californiaish.
Very good food, though I would have used less salt, maybe there was an accident on the main dish I ordered.  Not bad, but more salt than I'm inclined to use.  Mostly I just like the place in general.  The owner was very friendly, and the servers were tolerant of our use of the cell phones... and NO we weren't getting calls and making noise, we just texted a lot and were doing what we do which business and family and playing games, etc.  We were in an enclosed area and could feel free to be ourselves and say what we say and make faces and have fun.  It was our 36th Wedding anniversary, and we had a very expensive bottle of wine, and nice food and left a 30% tip, so it was worth it to them to let us be our immature selves.
author: Sarah H.

description: I came here with a couple of friends for a birthday party. The place is nice with an intimate setting. The owner/chief came and talk to us and was very friendly. We had chicken, steak, pork lion, and a hamburger. The pork lion was very good. I had the steak and it was okay, a bit chewy and a little tough. I didn't get to try the other things my friends had, but look very good. The dessert were good. We had a peppery type of ice cream. Service was very attentive and friendly. I highly recommend this place.
author: Leon C.

description: The heirloom tomato salad was sooooo good!  I know not everyone likes tomatoes, but this shit was the bomb!  I have never been so satisfied with a salad before.  The pork tenderloin was just OK. It was missing something, the texture was a bit off.   I did not like how it was served over the mac and cheese too, which I think should have been served on the side by itself.  But  I was, however, impressed by their extensive wine list, the cinnamon ice cream and the romantic ambiance.  The location is close to where I live so its convenient, but I have to warn everyone...parking is the shits!
author: Micaela M.

description:
Passed this place on the way to work and thought "Hey, what a quaint neighborhood place...we should try it out."  So we Yelp!ed it, Opentabled it and we DID IT!
The Richmond was a great experience.  For a local neighborhood place with only 36 seats, extremely well placed curtains, tables and a wine box bar The Richmond was more than a pleasant experience...it was memorable.
We shared an heirloom tomato salad (delicious) and my partner had the potato & leek soup (over the top delicious) while I had the foie gras (I can't even explain how delicious).  The starters were only complimented by my partner's pork loin over Mac n Cheese (gotta love the upscale comfort food aspect of this dish) and my hanger steak with a savory cheese, bacon and potato filled crepe (again a nice play on a classic steak and potatoes comfort food dish).
The poached peaches with cinnamon ice cream was a really nice finish to a wonderful meal.  We felt like amateurs ordering the screw top Ramsay Pinot Noir when we first arrived as it was the cheapest bottle on the menu, but we knew it was a good wine for the price so we couldn't help ourselves.  In the end, it complimented our meal very nicely and we didn't have any regrets!
author: Sean M.

description:
Had the 5-course tasting menu, and I must say, the food and service left a bit to be desired.  First the highlights:
-an excellent wine selection
-a very friendly and knowledgeable waiter
the butternut squash soup and foie gras dish were both excellent
The drawbacks:
-a server who took my wine away with a few sips left.  The same server after the third course, stopped informing us what the plates and wines were.  With dessert I asked: "Is this port?" and she said "yeah".  That's it!
-salty potato leek soup
-overcooked yellowtail sitting on a couple of green beans and a puddle of lame vegetable puree
-the ugliest (3D) paintings I have seen in a restaurant in a long time
-the short ribs (4th course) were tasty, but way too big of a portion for a 4th course

Maybe if the chef wasn't so busy chatting with his buddies at the same table for the whole 2-3 hours we were there, everything would have been better.  I don't mind an ambitious place, but if you can't pull off fine dining 100%, don't do it.  I'd rather have a really good burger or stew.  That being said, I'll have to go back and try the a la carte menu.
author: Matt S.

description: Stopped in without reservations around 8:30 as a warm-up to our 10pm deYoung show. We let them know we weren't there for dinner and asked if they could seat us just for wine and appetizers. They offered us a great table, a few little tasting morsels, bread and flavored butter too.  I had the harvest salad w/ blue cheese and poached pears, yummy. Great staff, very pleasant place to hang out.
author: Sarah S.

description:
Amazing!  This is a hidden gem that you should definitely check out.  They have a large wine selection and the owner and staff are very knowledgeable of their wines and what they pair well with.  The food is ridiculously good.  The potato leek soup is the best soup I have ever had.  I highly recommend this restaurant.
The food and wine is great but the atmosphere and friendliness of the staff is what sets The Richmond apart from other restaurants in the city.
author: phillip l.

description: The atmosphere is calm and quiet (maybe too quiet for my liking). However, the food is incredible. Truly some of the best I've had in SF. The foie gras was one of my favorite tasting experiences of my life. The butter poached lobster from French Laundry was another :-).  The Richmond is great for dates and excellent if you want a top-notch "foody-type" dining experience.
author: jason l.

description:
Great food.
Relaxed atmosphere.
Incredibly intimate.
The best neighborhood restaurant in San Francisco.
author: Ben R.

description: I thought this was a great little find! I have to admit I had some hesitation considering its location and unrecognized popularity (with my peers) but I was very pleasantly surprised with the superb food that was delivered. I do wish the portion was slightly smaller so I wouldn't be so tempted to over indulge! Staff seemed to be short that night but it did not seem to really influence our service. The ambiance was quiet and may be considered a tad dull if you were not in good company.
author: Heather P.

description: What happened? I've been telling everyone for the last few years about this wonderful restaurant in my neighborhood. Brought several friends to it and I almost decided to do a review of it for "Check Please" on KQED.  We went with friends this weekend and it was so disappointing, I feel like I've seen my lover in a whole new light- like realizing your suave debonaire lover is really just trailer trash. The "muse bouche" was deviled eggs... so based on past experience I thought, "these won't be like deviled eggs from the Joy of Cooking/ a la 1950s Americana, these will be some take-off on deviled eggs that really wows me." Nope- they were Americana and boring. Then I had the cod with fish chowder- a good match for the deviled eggs- it was mushy, flavorless, and drenched in boring chowder. My husband had the steak wrapped in bacon. Usually he would not choose such a heavy dish, but he thought, because it was the Richmond, it would be amazing. Wrong again. It was fatty and heavy, and nothing special. What happened, Richmond? We LOVED you- and you've broken our hearts.
author: Miriam G.

description: Granted, we haven't been back to this place since it first opened. I can only hope they have learned how to use salt. Who puts sea salt on a green salad? And then they skipped the salt altogether in our entrees. Odd.
author: A H.

description: I've been here twice now and think it is absolutely fantastic!  Ambiance, service, and food are all superb, and I can't say that about many restaurants.  I will certainly eat here again soon.
author: Sebastian G.

description: I love the Richmond.  It was the first Yelp-recommend restaurant I visited after moving to SF about two years ago and I've been regularly visiting since.  The food is always great, the starter is a nice little extra, and the owner never fails to come out to greet you.  Though, he regularly mistakes me for someone else, which provides a certain level of amusement on each visit.  When I need a mid-week pick me up, the Richmond is where I go.
author: S R.

description: This restaurant over-delivers with well crafted, perfectly seasoned dishes, and a wine list that gives you mega bang for your buck. They clearly don't use the typical restaurant mark up, and they have some true gems on the list! It have had a romantic dinner here with my boyfriend, a glass of wine before heading home, and a comfy meal at the bar; and all three experiences were terrific. Great service, amazing food...I am so grateful to have such a superb restaurant in The Richmond!
author: Liz C.

description: A-OK. Good ambiance. The hostess was very kind. The amuse bouche was nice. Our food was above average. At the end of dinner we were caught up in a conversation and the waiter was throwing out vibes that we might be keeping him from something, like going home maybe. Chef was extremely gracious.
author: Sarah B.

description:
Hands down the best fancy dinner i've ever had. A friend had her wedding reception here, had closed down the restaurant and had a set menu. i looked at the menu right before dinner and was a little worried when i saw things like "fried oysters", "braised monkfish" and "oxtail". Needless to say, these are things i wouldn't have ever ordered if i had been given a choice.

That being said, i am so very very glad the groom is a chef who can appreciate fine food, as he chose the menu. And the chef of the Richmond is one who can pull these things off and create an impressively fantastic dinner.

Combined with amazing wine pairings and exemplary service (including personal service from a very charming chef!) and you have one memorable dining experience.

i would recommend this restaurant to anyone, and would go back there in a heartbeat.
author: M A.

description: My boyfriend and I dined at The Richmond for New Year's Eve.  Divine and well-priced.  The sea bass with tomato sauce was recommended by Ginger and was delicious.  His rack of lamb was plentiful and perfectly prepared.  Our Oregon Pinot Noir was $33 a bottle.  After a lovely dinner, we were invited to bring in the new year with the staff.  Owner and chef John Oywang (Ritz Carlton, Four Seasons)  has a winner here.  Take a date. . . they'll be impressed and you won't break the bank.   It is intimate and very special.
author: Debbie M.

description: This is a very over rated restaurant. I ordered the hanger steak seemed great on the menu however it had no taste at all. My daughter ordered a hamburger..how can you go wrong... it came out very rare to raw again no taste.  Maybe just a bad night...but we wont be back. When you pay big money for a meal I would expect it to  taste very good. sorry folks.
author: ken h.

description: small place, but really cozy! the food is so good! u get bread with 3 different spreads. i can just eat that all day. the scallop, oxtail was super flavorful. the mushroom pastry beef is excellent, and just about everything else on the menu. only the fish wasn't good. i def wanna come back here, but parking just sucks out here.
author: Karen H.

description: Nice restaurant where the chef actually presents his own dishes personally?  You've found it!  Nestled in the cozy confines of domestic Richmond domiciles this delictable and comfy eating establishment scored high marks when my girlfirend and visited on Friday, June 22.  Tina had the foi groie and I had the crab crepe.  Both were simply prepared with excellent garnishes.  For entrees I had the hanger steak and Tina the tuna.  Again, the main courses were served simply but with  delicious garnishes.  Highly recommended.
author: Adriel L.

description: A true treat.   The food was wonderful, and yes, we had the burger.  Wow - it redefined what a burger can be for me, unbelievable.  Everything else was just as good.  Even my four year old son ate everything (he even said thank you to the chef, which is a first).  All in all, a wonderful place and we'll definitely be back!
author: Evan D.

description:
i had a fabulous experience at this classy, yet comfy, and delicious restaurant!  the waitstaff was very friendly and professional.  we scored a front table with the curtain divider.  great wine, good size servings, incredible food.  we had the cheese platter, hanger steak (with a baked brie potato thing that i am still dreaming about), and chocolatey goodness for dessert.
highly recommended!  except be prepared to work for the parking.
author: eileen k.

description: The Richmond serves consistently good food at reasonable prices.  The atmosphere was warm and unpretentious.  The wait-staff would come by regularly to check-up on you and the chef would great the customers.  It's not a huge restaurant, but it's cozy!  I will definitely be going back.
author: Daria i.

description:
AWESOME PLACE!!  Such good food it is ridiculous?!?!  My boyfriend and I wanted to get some good food, didn't want to go far, decided to try out the Richmond.  Actually, I have wanted to try it fr about 3 years now, and just remembered it the other day.

SO GOOD for the price.  Amazing food, awesome service, with a well-rounded menu.  Menu doesn't have a huge selection, but there is definitely something everyone likes, and it will be prepared perfectly!

Our service was top-notch, and suggested a perfect wine for our meal.

We got a bottle of wine, two entrees and dessert for $75.  Money well spent!
author: OT S.

description: I have to echo other 5 star reviews. Several visits over the past year have convinced me that this place is one of the best well kept secrets of the SF dining cosmos. To say it is well hidden in the Richmond is an understatement, but I would say easily worth the trip (and I live in Cole valley, no shortage of good dining options). Some distinctive touches include an amuse bouche offering (incredible potato leek soup on the last meal) and a trio of compound butters to go with the superb bread offering. I felt like I was at one of the high end downtown temples of cuisine, but nothing stuffy or pretentious about the setting. Just good folks running a great little jewel. Don't miss the grease less pan fried chicken it it's on the menu!
author: Richard R.

description: What a wonderful find in the Richmond. Hanger steak ... out of this world. Tomato & corn salad .. exquisitely flavored. Halibut OK but the sauce yummy! I can't wait to come back.
author: Gi G.

description: The Richmond is a neighborhood gem.  The atmosphere is cozy.  The food...delicious.  Every time we go for a special occasion dinner, I get the steak; because, if I don't, I am jealous of him.  This time I went out on a limb and got a vegetarian dish.  My hunch was correct: the mushrooms in puff pastry with spinach is delicous!  He was still the winner with the short ribs and potato puree, but my dish was a close second.  For an appetizer, I had the beef carpaccio and asparagus which was super tasty.  He had the fried oysters which were out of this world (he wins again).  For dessert, he had the apple spice cake.  Kinda dense but the cinnamon ice cream was delicous.  I was finally the winner on this one with the panna cotta with lemon curd and graham crackers sprinked on top.  Light and deliciously tart.  We had sparkling wine so I can't speak to the wine selection, but I hope to be back soon!
author: Heather R.

description:
Absolutely amazing food, acceptable service, fairly pricey. It has all the elements of the sort of place you are willing to pay a premium to go to: comfortably upscale setting (very clean, nicely appointed little bathroom), outstanding food, a  wine list that ranges from the completely affordable to the completely insane, and food that is phenomenal and elegantly presented without being pretentious or froo-froo. However, I found the servers to be extremely stiff and lacking in personality. It may come from the chef. He came and politely enquired about our meal, but there was an awkwardness to him that made our short encounter feel, well, awkward. It is a small strike against them, but enough to knock off a star. Had they been personable and welcoming, it would have been a five star review, easily. 
We were their early in the evening on a Tuesday, so it was quiet. We were there with our two year old, which they had no problem with. They had both booster seats and high chairs available. There is no kids menu, but we didn't really expect one. They were happy to bring a glass of milk with a straw and a separate small plate and salad fork for our two year old.
author: Charlie T.

description: cozy little restaurant with a friendly staff and good food...i had the heirloom tomato salad appetizer and the halibut as my main dish, both of which were worth going back for a second trip!  in addition, our server brought us a salmon appetizer, compliments of the chef.  that, of course, was a great first impression!
author: Amy K.

description: One of the highlights of Balboa Ave., along with the Balboa Movie Theatre and Simple Pleasures Cafe. Cozy spot, lovely ambience. We've been several times, and every time the chef has come out to say hello. Impressive wine list, unbelievably reasonable prices on the diverse set of simple, elegant entrees. If you're in the mood to go low-brow, there's even a gorgeous burger on the menu for less than you'll pay at Cable Car Joe's. Fabulous for date night.
author: Michelle P.

description: I feel like in a city with as many amazing places to eat and drink as San Francisco has, restaurants need stop taking their customers for granted and give them a reason to keep coming back. The Richmond is a perfect example of one of those places that I am excited to go back to. My husband I stopped in here to get a glass of wine before dinner reservations at Chapeau. The host knew we were just getting wine, but he offered us a table (even though the place was filling up quickly and is pretty tiny) rather than immediately seating us at the bar. We decided to sit at the bar anyways and he offered to pour tastings of any of their wines by the glass. After deciding on wine, he sent us out these delicious little crab rangoons compliments of the chef. While we were drinking our wine the chef/owner came out of the kitchen to make sure we were okay. We were only here for 45 minutes and spent $20 but felt completely appreciated and taken care of, more so than at many restaurants where I've spent $200 on 5 course meals. Everything about the place was very genuine and not stuffy at all and we can't wait to return for dinner.
author: Lindsay B.

description: My brother lives in the neighborhood and had been meaning for some time to stop by. We called late in the afternoon and took the 9:30 reservation slot, hoping it was worth the wait. It was fantastic! The vegetarian option (whiskey barrel) was the best vegetarian dish I've had anyplace for ages. My brother liked his hangar steak, and was very happy with the oxtail appetizer. The wine list is varied and reasonable, the service was fantastic, and the restaurant is small but not crammed-full of dining tables. Can't wait to go back.
author: vanessa k.

description: i love this place. great food, great atmosphere and a fantastic wine list! we made a reservation and we were seated on time by friendly staff, and the chef came out to make sure we were enjoying ourselves.....it really is a hidden neighborhood gem!
author: Teri A.

description:
We had a mixed feeling impression about Richmond. After reading all these "outstanding experience" reviews we expected to have a WOW experience too. Might be it was not a good day in the kitchen, but though it was a very good experience unfortunately it wasn't the case of WOW. 
The ambience was nice, cozy and lovely (big + was the quietness @ 5:30pm when we've been there, though the few tables were busy). The service was very good and attentive.
The problem is we were not VERY impressed with the food (as we hoped to be).
We had: a) Fried wontons (looked good, but the middle of them was still cold and not tasty as it could be if it would be heated enough, though we appreciated the offering), & bread with 3 varieties of batter (which we liked a lot) as amuse b.
              b) Roasted beets & cardamom carrots salad + Whisky braised oxtail & scallops for appetizers (good but not great, puff pastry in the salad was cold and impression was it was pulled out of the fridge instead of freshly baked, and 2 scallops were not big or tasty enough to impress) as appetizers.
              c) Seared Hunger steak (was OK just not memorable) + Wild Mushrooms stuffed in Puff Pastry (now THAT was the dish I will remember because it was delicious) for entrees.
               d) Panna Cotta for dessert was just OK (I would like it better with some kind of sauce or fruit compote, it was too "dry" for me).
               e) Wine suggested by the waitress was very good.
The best feature of the restaurant is the value: very reasonable prices and a lot of offerings.
So all together experience was good, but there is some room for improvement I guess. Is it a neighborhood gem? YES! Is it a foodies place? We'd say not yet, but it has a potential.
author: Tatyana M.

description: I came here for my birthday dinner and I thought it was great.  It's a nice neighborhood restaurant with good food and at a good price.  I was really impressed and I plan to go back.
author: klb l.

description: My rating is closer to 3.5 stars than 4. Bottom line is that the food is good but not great. All of the dishes were tasty but nothing really stood out. Our party ordered the short ribs in wine sauce, the pan fried chicken and the bacon wrapped New York steak (which turned out to be the prettiest dish).  For appetizers, we ordered the foie gras which I tried the tiniest piece of as I'm not a big fan and the hot dogs three ways.  The hot dogs three ways was unique as it featured a mini corndog, a mini chili dog and a mini pig in a blanket.  Unique in that I've never seen it before but the taste was similar to a full sized one.  I would have expected this restaurant to put it's own twist on it but unfortunately there wasn't.  One last thing I wanted to note was that Yelp reviewed raved about the pork which wasn't on the menu so I will have to come back again when they have it on the menu.  Hopefully I can upgrade this rating to a 4 when I do try that dish,
author: Dan W.

description: how random is this classy joint?  i don't know about you, but the inner richmond is not necessarily where i would head for caviar and tuna tartare.  however, they pull this off flawlessly without an ounce of pretension or snobbery.  the service was excellent and my steak melted in my mouth.  small, intimate and quiet this would be a perfect place for a date.  very solid.  minus one star for the random residential neighborhood that doesn't offer much to do after the meal.
author: calamity d.

description:
has it been a while since you've been ogled by a really old dude? do you miss the way his eyes shoot straight up your skirt even though his wife is sitting right next to him, or the hush that falls over a room when the only ethnic minorities not over 50 enter the restaurant? maybe we came on a weird night, but it felt like a bridge tournament at the senior center in here. 

oh, but those sweetbreads sure were tasty!
author: D M.

description: This place is a great find. Unexpectedly upscale food for the neighborhood, but the atmosphere is very comfortable. I went early on a weeknight with a friend and got in without a reservation. Great service. The burger is really tasty and reasonably priced. Delicious seafood too. I will absolutely go back again!
author: Tina C.

description: Intimate atmosphere, great service, awesome food! They have creative wine box decor that reflects an intelligent wine selection.  I had dinner here with my boyfriend and we were impressed with every plate, even the bread!  We talked and lingered at the table long after we finished eating. I can't wait to go back.
author: Kittarae S.

description: This place is alittle out of my price range, but I was fortunate enough to have a brother who received a gift certificate from work to The Richmond. I don't know how many times I've walked by this place without glancing at the menu (insert "idiot" from napoleon dynamite). Anyhow, the atmosphere is nice, definitely a good spot for a date. There were three of us and they sat us down at a nice table. There was a party of about 5 women behind us and I don't know what the deal is with the place but somehow I felt as though I could hear everything they were saying, from gossip to shopping...Anyways the wait staff were friendly. The menu was good (i.e. they had a flank steak dish, pork loin, your typical seared ahi dish, a cod dish, a burger and something else...). We were eating on the cheap and split the cheese plate which was fine I ordered the flank steak, asked for medium and it came out great (i used to order medium rare but have had some bloody beef in the past). We ordered the cheapest red wines (I honestly forget which ones, again, we were eating on the cheap, some bottles there go for like six hundo, pretty expensive...). One thing that did occur (but i could have cared less), was that when it came to delivering the food, they totally messed it up (i mean, that's a small error). They gave my cousins dish to me, then after they gave it to my cousin, they gave me my brothers dish (I found it humorous if anything). Anyhow, I enjoyed my meal (good presentation) and was totally satisfied. Cheers to The Richmond!
author: Cameron R.

description: This place ROCKS!!! If you haven't been here yet, do it soon. You are missing out. The food is very affordable considering the exceptional quality and the wine list rivals anywhere in SF. This is a no brainer. Only thing is that parking in the neighborhood isn't that easy so plan ahead or take the Balboa or Geary bus lines.
author: Suneil T.

description: Stopped in here on a whim for dinner.  This is probably the best French food in SF!  The baguette was presented in such a manner, I thought it was one of the dishes I ordered! AND..it was baked perfectly...just like in PARIS!  We couldn't decide on a main course and were trying to keep it light, so my friend and I sampled four of the starters and shared everything.  OMG...everything was flavorful and presented in a wonderful manner.  I cant wait to go back and try a main course!
author: Lisa F.

description: This place is a lovely little gem.  Every dish was amazing and the waite staff were awesome.  I'd put it up on my top 10 fave places list.  Only drawback is parking...there is none and finding a spot in the neighborhood is a nightmare.
author: L S.

description: Great neighborhood gem!  Friendly staff, cozy atmosphere, and classic, well-prepared food are all reasons why the Richmond is a great restaurant.  The chef comes out every time to check that everything was prepared to your liking. Sometimes free desserts show up at the end of the night- never a bad surprise!  Great wine list.  Not a huge menu, but changes seasonally and always is diverse enough to please all.  Moderately fancy, I'd say, with white table clothes, but not the pretentious attitude.
author: Stephanie H.

description:
THE RICHMOND:  GUILTY OF SHAMEFUL PRACTICE
When I called to make a reservation at The Richmond for a party of 12 for a Saturday, I was told that 6:30 or 8:30 was available.  I made the reservation for 6:30pm and was told to call back later in the week if I wanted  to see if my party could be seated at 7:00pm instead.  When I called back on Thursday, I was told that they could not accommodate my group which was a total surprise to me.  Shocked and Indignant,   I asked the guy, at what point where you going to call me to let me know?  Previously, I had given them my phone number and no one called or even bothered to leave a message that they were not honoring our reservation.   My husband and I have  eaten in many fine restaurants and to date, we have never experienced this type of low class/shabby treatment, a restaurant canceling our reservation without the decency and courtesy of notifying us.  After this unfortunate experience, we would never consider The Richmond.  Fortunately, we were able to get a reservation at Tommy Toy's Chinoise Restaurant to accommodate my daughter's family birthday celebration.  Maybe I should have listened to my brother before I booked the reservation because when I called to tell him where the birthday celebration was being held, he said that he ate at The Richmond  on 2 separate occasions and he said the food was only okay.  If you're planning a nice dinner for a large party, I would advise you to seriously look elsewhere.  Even if you're able to make a reservation, the question is whether The Richmond will pull the rug out from under your feet without notice and leave you totally stranded.
author: May N.

description: I heard this was a good neighborhood restaurant and it is! However, if you do not live in the neighborhood, I think it is worth the cab ride. The service was amazing. Everyone was so helpful, attentive and knowledgeable. The potato leek amuse-bouche was fantastic. At first glance, the menu did not seem up to par however everything we ordered was fantastic. The quality of food for the price (especially in SF) was great. I will definitely eat here again.
author: Marie N.

description: YUM!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! This place may be pricey, but it's worth it! I DEFINITELY recommend the Ox Tail and Scallop for the appetizer. You HAVE to try it!
author: Thao C.

description: simply a little treasure in the inner richmond. first off, reservations are a must, but if you don't have one, they might set up a special window-seat table. the homemade butter spreads are a treat and a nice variation on the same-old-same-old. not only is every dish amazing, but the chef/owner (john) creates personal touches to die for. at christmas time, he brought out homemade, toasty apple cider as well as samples of a new soup. the service is excellent, and the wine list top-notch. good place for either a romantic night or dinner with the family.
author: Bee H.

description: I decided to take my fiance on a date night - and since we are creatures of habit and like to stay in our hood I decided I'd turn to YELP for a new place to venture too.  99 reviews and a 4 star average, AND within walking distance made The Richmond my pick.  I made reservations via Open Table (although I don't think we really needed them on a Wednesday night).  We got there early - they sat us no problem, and we got a seat right next to the window in a cozy little corner. The Chef came by while we were selecting our wine, asked what we liked and told us he had about 40 wines not on the menu. He then asked our price range and red or white and we left it up to him. He came back with a wonderful bottle for a reasonable price which complimented our meal wonderfully. The service was very attentive, the staff very friendly, and I loved the interaction with the chef.  It's a small restaurant, but quite charming and it could be a new romantic spot for us. The music filled the room, but I could still have a converstaion although a party of six behind us starting gabbing about politics - and I could have done without that! So I just drank my wine a little faster! ha!  They started us with a deviled egg (How did the waitress know I love those!) - and then some bread with a sea salt butter, kalamata olive spread and a parsley spread. Nice.  He had the Potato Leek soup - which was great. The salad, Good. The food fantastic. We had no room for dessert and we definatly felt they gave us our space and let us enjoy - some places you go to in SF they try and turn and burn you - this is no such place.  The pricing was reasonable - about 80 dollars for both of us (this includes a bottle of wine) and we will definately go back.
author: J S.

description: Great for a first date or anniversary. small yet quiet location. staff is very friendly and no rush to get you out of there. Although menu items are limited, food is prepared very well. the apps provided to us were mmmm....good. parking is a hassle. would definitely go here again if i'm in the area.
author: Oo O.

description: This place is amazing. Comped 2 glasses of wine because we had to wait an extra 4 or 5 min to be seated which we didn't mind at all. Very friendly. The Whisky Braised Oxtail & Maine Diver Scallops with creamy polenta & green beans was one of the best things I have eaten in my life. Totally unbelievable and a great wine list starting as low as $18.00
author: D. S.

description: Another romantic restaurant for the boyfriend and me. Long wait time for the food, but it's the Richmond District? Is there anywhere else to go? I love the steak with the brie dough.
author: Olivia B.

description: Absolutely outstanding.  Attentive service, exceptional food, impressive wine list, and a warm, inviting atmosphere that still manages to be upscale - even though it's a decidedly neighborhood restaurant.  We'll definitely be back!
author: Leyla F.

description: My mistake was going here when I was already starving.  The service was slow slow slow.  The fact that the tables were not even all full at the time we arrived (and there are probably only about 10 tables total in the house) made it all the more problematic.  It took over 30 minutes for us to get some bread on our table, and this was only after we asked for it because I was about to pass out from hunger (the bread plate is actually cool, comes with three types of butter, and served with a side of deviled eggs).  So minus one star for all that.  The food was actually good.  We ordered the seared sonoma fois gras, crispy skin arctic char, and cheeseburger.  The fois gras was served on a french toast type of bread, and it was rich and very tasty.  Although, I should mention that I consider fois gras such an indulgence and don't think I have ever had it bad.  The char was like a salmon, served on a celery-type puree, and it was very fresh.  There were also oyster mushrooms and sunchokes which I think made the dish.  The cheeseburger was good, not stupendous.  The fries were soggy though.    Overall a decent dining experience, and I would go again, but definitely not on an empty stomach!
author: JoKr M.

description:
What a wonderful restaurant to stumble upon. My husband and I went here for our anniversary (we just kind of picked a few places out of Zagat's, and this one seemed to appeal to us the most and they were open on a Monday!), so we didn't know what to expect. The food was wonderful- the small menu had several things that we were interested in trying, and plenty for both vegetarians and non-vegetarians. It's small, cozy, and informal, but the quality of the food was certainly fit for a more upscale place. The combination of flavors was interesting and delicious! Even better, we shared two appetizers, two entrees, and a bottle of wine, and our bill was under $100! The wine list was excellent (one of the reasons we chose to come to The Richmond)- there were lots of high end bottles on the list, but the lower end bottle we chose was delicious. The waitstaff was friendly and attentive. When they found out it was our anniversary and we were too full to order dessert, they brought us a complimentary serving of their lightest dessert- it was strawberry sorbet, which was wonderful (and I don't normally like strawberry desserts very much!)
The chef came out and said hello to us, and showed us their new menu, which looked great. We will definitely be coming back, and are so happy to have found this little jewel!
author: Meredith W.

description: This place is top notch.  They were slightly slow on the service, but they apologized (instead of ignoring it like most places) and the chef came out to thank us for our patience.
